titleStmt.title: The famous history of the life of the renowned Prince Palmerin of England: or, The glory of knightly prowess In three parts. Containing his parentage, birth, education, travels, strange adventures, noble exploits and victories; combats with monsters, gyants, armies, and armed knights, dissolving inchantments, delivering distressed ladies; and his success in love. The whole being a compleat series, inter-woven with the heroick actions of many valiant emperours, kings, princes, and knights of undoubted fame, whose matchless deeds have won them immortal honour. A book worthy the perusal of either sex. Written originally in French; and now faithfully done into English (for the better satisfaction of the reader) by J.S.
Palmerin of England (Romance). Part 2. English.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE FAMOUS HISTORY Of the Life of the Renowned Prince PALMERIN OF ENGLAND: OR, The Glory of Knightly Prowe≈øs. In Three Parts. Containing his Parentage, Birth, Education, Travels, Strange Adventures, Noble Exploits and Victories; Combats with Mon≈øters, Gyants, Armies, and Armed Knights, Di≈ø≈øolving Inchantments, delivering Di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Ladies; and his ≈øucce≈øs in Love.

The whole being a compleat Series, inter-woven with the Heroick Actions of many Valiant Emperours, Kings, Princes, and Knights of undoubted FAME, who≈øe Matchle≈øs Deeds have won them immortal Honour. A Book Worthy the Peru≈øal of either Sex.
Written originally in French; and now faithfully done into Engli≈øh (for the better ≈øatisfaction of the Reader) by J. S.
London, Printed for William Thackeray, in Duck-Lane and Thomas Pa≈ø≈øinger on London-Bridge. MDCLXXXV.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
YOU have before you a Book that has been in great E≈øteem in mo≈øt Nations, there being but few Europian Languages, in which at this day it is not Extant: therefore ≈øeeing it written by others, in the honour of our Country, I thought it highly convenient that my Country-man ≈øhould expre≈øs him≈øelf in his native Language, or ≈øtand or fall by the Cen≈øure of the Judicious Natives of this famous Sea-≈øurrounded I≈øle. I mu≈øt confe≈øs there are many tracts of this Nature abroad in the world; but among≈øt the number that have proceeded, if I may freely pa≈øs my judgment, none have exceeded, if any have hitherto Equalized it. The ≈øubject is Arms and Love, to which are joyned State-Policies, Stratagems and Machavillian-Machinations, things worthy to be ob≈øerved by the wi≈øe≈øt and worthie≈øt of Mankind; yet was it not ≈øo much written for profitable practice, as Plea≈øure and Recreation, though it may more then indifferently ≈øerve for both, being fitly quallified for all Capacities of either Sex, no where charged with Ob≈øcenity, or any thing misbecomming the per≈øons, who≈øe Charracters it lively repre≈øents, but handing their ≈øame down to future Ages. If I pre≈øage aright, it ≈øhall live till time is no more. If brave Exploits in Warr, or ≈øingle Combates,
if you ≈øeek here, you may behold it lively repre≈øented, as if you hazarded your ≈øelf in the bloody field of Mars to ≈øatisfie that curio≈øity. If Court≈øhip plea≈øe you, Venus her ≈øelf, nor her winged Son, have not the power to give you a better ≈øatisfaction. If Beauty, behold it as in a Mirror, If Con≈øtancy and Inviolate faith. rewarded with all terre≈øtial felicity, you prize, here it is to be found. If State-pollicies, &c. you are de≈øirous to dive into, ≈øee the Councels of Emperors and Kings lay'd open, and all mi≈øteries worthy the highe≈øt Earthly thought unraveled. And to be brief, there is nothing of this nature that can be rea≈øonably de≈øired, but it is to be found in this plea≈øant mi≈øterious Arcania; which makes him the bolder to recommend it to your good likeing. Who is

closer.signed: Your Friend to ≈øerve you, J. S.

div.head: THE Famous Hi≈øtory OF The Renowned PRINCE Palmerin of England, Part, the Fir≈øt.
CHAP. I.

argument.p: How Don Edoard (Son to Frederick, King of England) haveing obtained in Marriage the Prince≈øs Flerida, Daughter to Palmerin Emperour of Greece; returning home, was lo≈øt in pur≈øuing an Inchanted Boar; How he was led to the Ca≈øtle of a Gyant called Dramu≈øia ‚Ä¢ d, and there underwent a tedious impri≈øonment.

div.p:
DOn Edoard, having a long time left his Native Country to War again≈øt the Turks and Sarazens that invaded the Greek-Empire, fell in love in the end with a beautiful Lady, Daughter to Palmerin the Greek Emperour, and ≈øo won upon her affections by his Behaviour and many Noble Atchievements in Feats of Arms, that ≈øhe (with the con≈øent of her Father) ≈øurrendred her ≈øelf into his arms, to the great joy of all men; when
having with his fair Prince≈øs ≈øtayed a while in all manner of Delights, he greatly de≈øired to return into his own Country, to do which, he procured leave of the Emperor his Father-in-Law, and ≈øo with a great Train of Nobility Imbarqued; When after being ≈øome time detained by contrary Winds at Sea, they Landed in Enlgand, to the great joy of Fredrick the aged King, and all his Nobles; ≈øo that the Fea≈øting was ≈øo great, that the like in any age had not been known: Yet the ≈øudden change of Air, and long Voyage at Sea, together with her Teeming, ≈øo altred the fair Prince≈ø≈øes Con≈øtitution, that falling into a Feaver, it much abated the former joy; but e≈øpecially of Don Edoard, who ≈øending for the mo≈øt Skilful Phy≈øicians, he commanded them to u≈øe their utmo≈øt skill for her recovery: Whereupon, after much ob≈øervation, they told him, the plea≈øante≈øt Air that could be found, would be the mo≈øt contributing to her Health; and that none could be better than near ≈øome Forre≈øt, River, or in a plea≈øant Meadow: In complyance with which, he that would ≈øpare no Charge to give her ea≈øe, who was as dear to him as life, commanded a Royal Pavilion to be made, and afterwards to be carryed with all things nece≈ø≈øary and fit for the Entertainment of the Prince≈øs, to the Verge of a plea≈øant Grove, by which run a Silver trill of Water, Meandering the flowery Meads: And hither was the Prince≈øs brought in a Chair of State, and things made in as ample manner for her Reception as if ≈øhe had been in her Lords Pallace: But as Fortune would have it, when ≈øhe began, through the means that were daily u≈øed to recover her Health and Strength, a fearful noi≈øe was heard in the Forre≈øt, which the Prince and his Nobles ≈øuppo≈øing to be made by ≈øome Wild Bea≈øt, Armed and Mounted on Hor≈øe-back, when immediately they e≈øpyed among≈øt the Thickets, a mon≈øtrous Wild Boar, with horrid Tusks and flaming Eyes; whereupon the Dogs were uncoupled, and the Prince followed ≈øwiftly after the flying Bea≈øt, in≈øomuch that his Nobles ≈øoon lo≈øt ≈øight of him; nor could they, notwith≈øtanding the loud ≈øhouts they made, have any an≈øwer; ≈øo that night coming on, they re≈øolved to return to the Pavilion, for thither they imagined their Lord would come; yet were they greatly perplexed lea≈øt he ≈øhould ≈øu≈øtain any damage: How≈øoever, return they did,
and comforted the Prince≈øs in the be≈øt wi≈øe, lea≈øt through grief, ≈øhe might Relap≈øe.

The Prince ≈øeperated from his Nobles as afore≈øaid, and night coming fa≈øt upon him, he having wandred in vain to find the Pavilion as long as the night continued; by this time being weary and faint, having al≈øo lo≈øt his Game, de≈øcended from his Hor≈øe, and fa≈øtening him to a ≈øpreading Beach, laid him≈øelf down upon the Gra≈øs, thinking with the mornings Dawne to be upon his way; when re≈øtle≈øly pa≈ø≈øing over the tedious Dark, in often con≈øidering the affliction the Prince≈øs would be in for want of his Company, up he gets the next morning, and pa≈ø≈øes along the ≈øide of a plea≈øant River, till he e≈øpy'd a fair Ca≈øtle, at which he intended to inquire his way: Where upon his arrival, he found the Gates open, and a Porter ≈øtanding before them, who welcomed the Prince, de≈øiring him to enter, which he did, and found it to be a ≈øpacious place, richly adorned, and in ≈øuch good order, that he could not refrain wondring thereat; when as he no ≈øooner pa≈ø≈øed through a great Hall, but entring the next Room, he was encountred by a beautiful Lady, who appeared to be Governe≈øs of the Ca≈øtle, to whom he made low obedience, and ≈øhe returning the like Complement, welcomed him in a courteous manner, demanding his Name, Country, and the occa≈øion of his coming thither; all which he told her; whereat ≈øhe ≈øeemed wonderfully plea≈øed, and intreated him in all love, to honour her Ca≈øtle for that night with his pre≈øence, and that the next morning ≈øhe would di≈ømi≈øs him with a guide to the place he ≈øought. The Prince invited in this manner by a beautiful Lady, could not in point of Genero≈øity, refu≈øe ≈øuch a Courte≈øie, though his heart was ≈øtill with fair Flerida: And thereupon the Tables were ≈øpread with Provi≈øion of every ≈øort, and Wine in abundance, all brought in by invi≈øible ways; and over and above, the mo≈øt Melodious Mu≈øick was heard, but no per≈øons or In≈øtruments ≈øeen; which rai≈øed an admiration in the Prince what it ≈øhould mean; yet being a Man of a daring re≈øolution, he re≈øolved if po≈ø≈øible, to ≈øee the utmo≈øt of the Adventure verily believing, as indeed it was true, that the Lady was an Enchantre≈øs; and that whate're he had ob≈øerved was created by the power of Magick: Yet down he ≈øat,
and immediately perceived all the Seats filled with either Sexes, in rich Attire, who to his thinking, were really ≈øo; and that they fed heartily as him≈øelf imagined he did. The Banquet tnded, they ro≈øe up to Dance, and after that vani≈øhed; whereupon the Lady came to the Prince and bid him be of good chear, entertaining him with amorous glances, and night being come, ≈øhe demanded of him, whether he would be conducted to his Lodging? To which, by rea≈øon of his long Travel, and all-nights Lodging before, he readily con≈øented: When divers ≈øeeming Gallants attended him, as al≈øo did the Lady and her Damo≈øels; ≈øo that in his Fathers Court he never was more Nobly attended; when entring his Chamber, he found divers Lamps of Gold burning, who≈øe flames were fed with Naptha and Apthaltis, all the Ceeling appearing to be fretted Gold, and the Walls hung round with curious Pictures, repre≈øenting Wars and Stories of Knights: The floor was Cedar, and the Bed of Purple Velvet, Fringed with Gold, and all Embroidered o're with Pearl and Stones, that dazled by reflected Light, the admiring Princes eyes, who had never ≈øeen the like before: Yet to Bed he went, and ≈øoon by Magick Spells, was Charmed into ≈ølumber; when as Eutrope the fair Enchantre≈øs, ≈øent her Virgin to fetch the Princes Sword which he had put under his Beds-head, to re≈øi≈øt any Enchantment that might be practi≈øed upon his Per≈øon; that Sword being of ≈øuch vertue, that no Spells had power to injure him whil≈øt it was in his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; the which the Damo≈øel having effected, the Enchantre≈øs ≈øent it to Dramu≈øiande her Kin≈øman, a Mon≈øtrous Gyant, and one that ≈øought the ruine of Don Edoard for the death of his Father, ≈ølain in an attempt by Fredrick the Princes Father; who upon notice of what had pa≈ø≈øed, ha≈øted to the Ca≈øtle, and rudely pre≈ø≈øing into the Princes Chamber with many Exclamations, awaked him, threatning to revenge what had happened by the hand of the Father, upon the Son; whereat the Prince ≈øtarting from his ≈ølumber, and perceiving him≈øelf in danger, groped for his Sword, but finding it gone, he, like a Lyon be≈øet with Hunters, ≈øcorning to be afraid, gra≈øped a Pillar of the Bed, and tearing it down, laid at his Mon≈øtrous Foe, but being oppre≈ø≈øed by multitudes, was forced to
yield; and thereupon the Gyant at the in≈øtance of Eutrope, granting him his life, ca≈øt him into Irons, and conveyed him into a ≈øtrong Pri≈øon on the top of the Ca≈øtle, where in great mi≈øery he continued many years, as will in the ≈øequel appear.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: How Don Edoard ≈øuffered in Pri≈øon, and who the Gyant was: How the Prince≈øs Flerida was delivered in the Pavilion of two fair Sons, which were taken thence by a Savage Man, to feed the Lyons; and what happened to Sir Fridos, Son to the Duke of Gauls, during his riding in que≈øt of Don Edoard.

div.p:
THE Prince being thus taken as it were in a Snare, bewailed not ≈øo much his Captivity as it grieved him to thinke how the Prince≈øs and his Father would take his ab≈øence; yet with a Manly Courage he re≈øolved to brave his Fate, ≈øeeing ≈øorrow would be nothing available. Now the cau≈øe why the Grant Dramu≈øiand's Father fell, was this: The Emperor of Greece, named Palmerin, and Trineus, Son to the Emperor of Germany, being in England, the latter fell in love with the fair Prince≈øs Agricola, Daughter to Fredrick, and Si≈øter to Don Edoard, who ≈øo far prevailed, that he was in great likelihood to have her in Marriage: But ≈øo it happened, that the Prince≈øs and divers Knights and Ladies, attending the Queen and Prince≈øs Agricola to a neighbouring Forre≈øt, there to Recreate them≈øelves: Frenaque a mon≈øtrous Gyant, Father to Dramu≈øiand, de≈øirous to get the Prince≈øs in Marriage, and having been taking the opportunity of their being unarmed, came upon them with twenty of his followers, and in ≈øpight of the re≈øi≈øtance they made, took from them the Queen and Prince≈øs; of which King Fredrick having notice, cau≈øed them all to Arm them≈øelves, and pur≈øued the Gyant, when overtaking him, a fierce Combat began, in which the Gyant and almo≈øt all his followers, were ≈ølain, and divers of the Princes and Knights on the other hand, ≈øore-wounded;
≈øo that the Queen and Prince≈øs were at that time re≈øcued, which made the Enchantre≈øs Eutrope, Si≈øter to Frenaque, vow revenge, and incite the Son to take ≈øatisfaction for his Mothers Blood upon any of the Kingly race, where ever he could conveniently meet them; the Enchantre≈øs in the mean while u≈øing her utmo≈øt endeavour to bring them into his power, which ≈øhe fir≈øt effected upon the Prince, as is before ≈øaid: Yet ≈øoon after, the Gyant a little relenting, took off his Irons, and gave him liberty to walk about the Ca≈øtle; yet ≈øo great was the grief of the Prince≈øs for his lo≈øs, that after divers Knights had ≈øearched for him in vain, and chiefly for Sir Pridos, Son to the Duke of Gauls, who had notice of his being alive, by Argonida the Enchantre≈ø≈øes Daughter, but not of the place of his re≈øidence, ≈øhe fell in Labour, and was delivered of two fair Sons, one of which was, by her expre≈øs command, Baptized by the Name of Palmerin, according to the Name of her Father; and the other Florin du De≈øerta, or Florin of the Forre≈øt; the better for the future to put her in mind of the hard≈øhip ≈øhe had ≈øu≈øtained: At what time being per≈øwaded by her Ladies to leave that ≈øolitary place, and retire to the Court, ≈øhe re≈øolved upon it; when in the mean time, by the power of the Enchantre≈øs, the two Infants were taken from her by force in this manner.

A Fellow, who from his Infancy being nouri≈øhed among≈øt Wild Bea≈øts, with whom he became ≈øo familiar, that the fierce≈øt would fawn upon him: E≈øpying the Pavilion on the Verge of the Forre≈øt, in which he had a Cave, came boldly into it, and ≈øeeing the two Infants lying in the Cradle, took them in his arms and bore them thence in ≈øpight of the weak re≈øi≈øtance the unarmed Knights and ≈øhrieking Ladies made; which redoubled the Prince≈ø≈øes grief, who weak as ≈øhe was, crept out of her Bed, and ≈øent her eyes after him, till by ≈øpeedy flight he was ab≈øconded among≈øt the thicke≈øt Trees.

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: How Sir Pridos came to Court, and declared the unwelcome News, and of the grief that thereon en≈øued; what became of the young Prince≈øs, and how upon notice of Don Edoards Lo≈øs at Con≈øtant ‚Ä¢ nople, Prince Primalion, Son to the Emperor, went in ≈øearch of him.

div.p: SIR Pridos having a long time in vain ≈øearched after his good Friend, and not being able to di≈øcover the place of his aboad, and having acquainted the Prince≈øs with the words of the Damo≈øel, he went to Court as to prepare for the beautiful Flerinas Reception, and to give the King and Queen what information he could, when during his ab≈øence, the Children were taken away.

This good Knight arriving at the Court, and affirming what before was rumoured with much uncertainty, filled every Brea≈øt with grief, e≈øpecially the Queens, who for lo≈øs of her Son, took on beyond mea≈øure; ≈øo that long it was e're the King could comfort her; yet in the under≈øtanding he was alive, and that in time his deliverance would be wrought, ≈øhe began to be more temperate, and to expect the be≈øt: Whereupon order was taken to fetch the di≈øcon≈øolate Prince≈øs to the Court; upon who≈øe arrival, the lo≈øs of the Royal Infants being known, drew ≈øecond ≈øtreams of tears from many eyes: Nor would the Prince≈øs be comforted, but as often as ≈øhe might, retired, and greatly bewailed her ≈øad misfortune; de≈øiring that the Emperor her Father and Prince her Brother, then re≈øiding at Con≈øtantinople, might be made acquainted with what had happened: Which Reque≈øt of hers was granted; and Sir Argolant, Son to Duke Horten, charged with the doleful Me≈ø≈øage, Embarquing, ≈øoon arrived; and to the great grief of all that heard it, became the relator of the doleful News, as will hereafter appear.

Now the Savage-Man that took the young Children being about to give them to the Lyons that he kept to Hunt with, moved with remor≈øe, became more mild, pittying the Innocents, who ≈ømiled
upon the grim-fac'd Wretch, and opened their pritty Arms, as it were to Embrace him; in≈øomuch, that altogether altering his determination, he delivered them to an Old Woman that lived in a Cave in that Forre≈øt, to do with them as ≈øhe plea≈øed; not knowing to whom they appertained, brought them up as well as ≈øhe might, in who≈øe protection I ≈øhall for a while leave them.

Argolant, as it is ≈øaid, arriving at Con≈øtantinople, it ≈øo happened, that at the ≈øame time great Triumphs were acting for joy of the Birth of Polinarda, Daughter to the Prince Primalion; there being pre≈øent divers Kings and Princes: But when he produced his Letters of Credence, and related the doleful Story, they was turned into Mourning, e≈øpecially the Emperor and his Son made great moan; the latter vowing in the pre≈øence of them all, that he would ≈øpend the greate≈øt part of his life in ≈øearch of the worthy Don Edoard; and with him joyned divers of the Nobles; nor could the tears of their Ladies, nor any per≈øwa≈øions of their Friends, obliege them to alter their determinations.

The Prince not to be le≈øs then his word, having ≈øettled his Affairs, and taken leave of his Friends, Armed him≈øelf as did the Nobles that attended him; and ≈øo furni≈øhed in the be≈øt manner, they ≈øecretly left the City, each Knight having his E≈øquire; when being without the Gates, they took ≈øeveral ways, re≈øolving to ≈øearch in the Courts of Princes for the ab≈øent Prince, and not return till they had heard tydings of him; and ≈øo Sir Argolant was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed with many rich Pre≈øents.

div.head: CHAP. IV.

argument.p: How Prince Primaleon in his Adventures, met the ≈øorrowful Funerals which Pendritia made for being rejected by Don Ed ‚Ä¢ ard, why he led a ≈øolitary life, and how young Florin ≈øtraying from his Nur≈øes Cave, was found by Sir Pridos, and brought to the Court.

div.p:
PRimaleon now ≈øeperated from his Company, Travelled (only attended by his E≈øquire) through divers Countrys, inquiring and making diligent ≈øearch for his ab≈øent Brother-in-Law; when in the end, arriving in the bottom of a Valley in
the Territories of Lacedemon, about the Suns declining, it on a ≈øudden grew ≈øo dark, and the Shade ≈øo high, that he was minded not to enter the Forre≈øt which ≈øtood in his way: But whil≈øt he was mu≈øing, and Night coming fa≈øt on, there i≈ø≈øued out of a ≈ømall Lodge, a Troop of Ladies all in Mourning, with Torches in their hands, following a Mourning Coffin; at which the Prince much wondred, e≈øpecially in ≈øuch a ≈øolitary place; wherefore approaching them, and e≈øpying one more Beautiful then the re≈øt, he addre≈ø≈øes him≈øelf to her in this manner:

Fair Lady, let me as a Stranger, intreat you to ≈øuffer me to under≈øtand the rea≈øon of this Mournful Object, in a place where I deemed no Mortal had dwelt; and why tho≈øe Clouds of ≈øorrow ≈øit on a face ≈øo lovely, which neverthele≈øs is beautiful in Tears; and if you have been injured, I ≈øwear by my Knighthood to do you Iu≈øtice, at the hazard of my Life.

Vpon this Reque≈øt, the Lady having well noted his comely Per≈øonage, mode≈øt Speech, and courteous Deportment, fetching a deep ≈øigh, replyed: Sir Knight, my Name is Pandritia, Daughter to the King of Lacedemonia, who≈øe unfortunate ha ‚Ä¢ it was, to fall in Love with Don Edoard, who delivered my Brother King Ternaes by his Valour, out of the Inchanted Ca≈øtle of Des noires Oi≈øeaux: But that Prince having before given his heart to the happy and fair Flerida, in≈øtead of the Sub≈øtance, left me only his Picture, which being dre≈ø≈øed in Funeral Weeds, I am about to Interr, hoping by that means, to delude my grief for the ab≈øence of him I love as dear as life. This ≈øaid, Primaleon lifting up the Paule, ≈øaw there, to his amazement, the lively Portraiture of his dear Friend; in≈øomuch that at fir≈øt he verily believed it was: he Whereupon comforting the Lady, he him≈øelf attended that Fanta≈øtick Funeral to a dole≈øome place covered all with black. and hung round with the Pictures and Tragick Stories of Vnfortunate Lovers; but into it the Prince was denyed entrance, unle≈øs he would devote his future days to Mourning; which he refu≈øing, kindly took his leave, and pa≈ø≈øed on in ≈øearch of the Sub≈øtance, whom Pardri ‚Ä¢ ia upon notice of his lo≈øs, ≈øuppo≈øed to be dead, where we mu≈øt leave them for a while, and return into England,

Don Edoard not being yet relea≈øed from his confinement, though twelve years had pa≈ø≈øed, great ≈øearch was made after him; when as Sir Pridos coming to the Forre≈øt, near unto which the Prince≈øs Flerida had lo≈øt her Children, he e≈øpyed a Beautiful Youth ≈øitting very Pen≈øive, re≈øembling Don Edoard ≈øo much, that at a di≈øtance he verily believed it to be him; when coming clo≈øer, he demanded the cau≈øe of his ≈øadne≈øs, and what brought him to that de≈øolate place? To which he replyed, That he had been Hunting in the Forre≈øt, and had lo≈øt both his Game and him≈øelf, not knowing how to find the way to his Cave. Cave! ≈øaid Sir Pridos, Why! do you live in a Cave? Yes, replyed the Youth, I was brought up in this Forre≈øt ever ≈øince I can remember, by an Old Woman and a Savage Man, who daily Hunts with Lyons, and Shoots Wild Bea≈øts.

By this means Sir Pridos verily conceived it was one of the Prince≈øs Fleridas Sons; wherefore he ≈øo dealt with him, that mounting him behind him, he brought him to the Court clad in a Harts Skin only, and pre≈øented him to the King, who ≈øeeing the lively Image of his Son portrayed in his face by Natures Pencil, comforted the Prince≈øs, and a≈ø≈øured her, that it mu≈øt by all Circum≈øtances, be one of her Sons: Whereupon ≈øhe greatly rejoyced, and Dre≈ø≈øing him in Princely Attire, cau≈øed him to be in≈øtructed in all things nece≈ø≈øary for accompli≈øhment, ≈øo that it ≈øoon appeared by his ≈øingular Carriage and Demeanour, that he was of Noble Birth; and did afterwards happen to be Florina du De≈øerta, the younge≈øt Son of Don Edoard, and his Prince≈øs Flerida, as ≈øhall in the Series of this Hi≈øtory, be made manife≈øt.

div.head: CHAP. V.

argument.p: How the Savage-Man was grieved for the lo≈øs of Florina: How the young Prince Palmerin, walking to ≈øeek his Brother, departed thence with Polendos, King of The≈ø≈ø ‚Ä¢ lia, who carried him to Con≈øtantinople; and how it was revealed by a Damo≈øel, what he ≈øhould afterwards be.

div.p: YOung Florina as afore≈øaid, being taken from the Forre≈øt, the Savage-man was extreamly grieved for his ab≈øence, ≈øuppo≈øing his Lyons, who returned all bathed in the blood of a Hart, had ≈ølain him; ≈øo that in a de≈øperate mood, he ≈ølew them by way of Revenge: But what did more increa≈øe his Rage, was, for that young Palmerin going with Sylvan the Savage-mans Son, to ≈øeek his Brother, was ≈øoon after wanting, being carried away in the following manner. The two Youths Travelling till weary, beheld a fair green Bank, which overlookt from a ri≈øing Hill, the Calm and gentle Ocean: Where repo≈øing them≈øelves, and falling a≈øleep, a Gally came to ≈øhore, in which was Polendos King of The≈ø≈øaly, then in ≈øearch of Don Edoard and Primaleon; who viewing a pair of ≈øuch lovely Youths in ≈øo de≈øolate a place, took them on Board; and having caught ≈øome Veni≈øon, and taken in fre≈øh Water, ≈øet Sail, and Coa≈øting many Countrys, at la≈øt returned to Con≈øtantinople, where all was yet in heavine≈øs; when upon their Landing, the King pre≈øented the Emperor with young Palmerin, who for his Beauty and Strength, was admired by all: When as the Emperor conceiving an unu≈øual joy at the Reception of ≈øuch a Pre≈øent, ≈øent him to his Grand-Daughter, the fair Polinarda, who Entertained him as her Servant, and for the love of whom the Prince did Wonders, as in the Sequel will appear.

The young Prince now flouri≈øhing in the Grecian Court, and gaining the e≈øteem of all; it happened on a day, at a high Fea≈øt where a number of great Per≈øonages were pre≈øent, that a Damo≈øel in Armour came riding upon a White Steed, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ
lighting in the Yard before the Pallace, de≈øired an Officer to introduce her into the Emperors pre≈øence, which being done, ≈øhe deliver'd a Letter from Thra≈ømenia the Inchantre≈øs, wherein was pre≈øaged the future Greatne≈øs of young Prince Palmerin, as followeth.

body.head: To the Mo≈øt Renowned and Invincible Palmerin, Emperor of Greece, Salutations.
body.p: AT who≈øe Name the Enemy trembles, and good Subjects rejoyce; in who≈øe Court Fame is the Riches of the Valiant, and Friend≈øhip the reward of the Vertuous and Venterous: I wi≈øh thy State as permanent as thy Deeds have been Pui≈ø≈øant, and the Unanimity of thy Friends to pro≈øper in long amity of happy Fortune. The young Prince you have received into your Court, although you may judge it incredible, yet ≈øhall you find it certain, (when Fate is ripe for Birth) is de≈øcended of two of the mo≈øt Pui≈ø≈øant Princes the World affords; and him≈øelf ≈øhall prove as great and Victorious: wherefore let his Entertainment be ≈øuch as his Honour Merits, and his E≈øtemation according as his Valour does declare; for he it is that mu≈øt defend your Imperial Diadem when it ≈øhall be in greate≈øt danger, and render you the Darling of Fortune; beloved of thy Enemies as of thy neare≈øt Friends. By his means likewi≈øe, ≈øhall two Unfortune Princes enjoy thir Liberty, none (him≈øelf excepted) being able to deliver them; fora≈ømuch as he ≈øhall mount highe≈øt in the favour of Fortune, and be the Glory of Knighthood. So leaving what has been premi≈øed, to be fulfilled when time has Circuled the Minutes ≈øet by De≈øtiny, wi≈øhing all Felicity to your Imperial Maje≈øty, I re≈øt

closer.signed: Your a≈ø≈øured and faithful Friend and Servant, THRASMENIA.

div.p:
This Letter did not a little amaze the Emperor, though inwardly he greatly rejoyced; for he had heard much of the Skill of this famous Inchantre≈øs, and therefore relyed the more upon the verity of her Predictions, ≈øo that changing the Prince from that of a
Servant to a higher Degree, he cau≈øed him to be put in a ≈øplendid Equipage, and recommended him to the Tuition and Society of his Nobles; in≈øomuch that he greatly profited, not only in Feats of Arms, but Learning, to that Degree, that none in Court exceeded him; which made the Emperor more and more place his affections upon him; in≈øomuch that he highly recommended him to his beautious Grand-Daughter, advi≈øing her not to ≈ølight the motions of his Love if he offered it; yet ≈øhe being of tender years, did not ≈øo well regard him as ≈øhe ought, but made him for her ≈øake, undertake many difficult and dangerous adventures, which he performed to ≈øuch admiration, that in the end, with the con≈øent of all, he gained the intire affections of that incomparable beauty, as in this Hi≈øtory will at large appear.

div.head: CHAP. VI.

argument.p: How Vernar Prince of Germany, riding in ≈øearch of Don Edoard, met with many ≈øtrange Adventures; and what happened between him and Belcar Duke of Duras, in the Unfortunate Forre≈øt, &c.

div.p:
AMong≈øt many Princes and Noble Knights that were in ≈øearch of Don Edoard; Vernar the Emperor of Germany's Son, was one who undertook it at the in≈øtance of his Mi≈øtris the fair Bazilia, being likely to run the hazard of her di≈øplea≈øure if he ≈øucceeded not: When the Prince having been in divers Countries and heard no Tydings, he began to di≈øpair of accompli≈øhing his Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes de≈øire and thereupon thought it ≈øhame to return to her again if he ≈øhould fail; which cau≈øed troops of melancholly thoughts to mu≈øter in his Brea≈øt, and to revolve many things: But whil≈øt he was Riding in that mood, only attended by his E≈øquire, near the Unfortunate Forre≈øt where the Prince was lo≈øt, he at a di≈øtance, beheld a Knight, attended likewi≈øe by a Squire, ride towards him, but minding his way, he did not much regard him, though he perceived he had Guilt Armour that glittered, by
the reflections of the Sun, and upon it divers Leopards portrayed; his Shield was Silver, and in it the Figure of a fiery Serpent.

The afore≈øaid Knight coming up to the Prince, Saluted him, but he regardle≈øs of any thing but his Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes commands, returned not the like Salutation, which cau≈øed the Knight to give him many unbecoming words; yet the Prince made him no other An≈øwer, but that he had other Affairs to trouble his mind, then to addict him≈øelf to complement; nor believed he it was in the power of any Knight, to oblige him to any thing contrary to his mind: Then would the Knight of the Serpents know what Secret po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed his brea≈øt: Then ≈øaid the Prince, I ≈øhall not let you know, neither by fair means nor force ≈øhall the ≈øecret be wre≈øted from me. Vpon this, high Words ari≈øing, they betook them to their Spears, and running a full Cour≈øe broke them, ≈øo that the Shivers flew into the aire; whereupon they drew their Swords, and began the Combate ≈øo fiercely, that many Wounds were given and received; in≈øomuch, that through lo≈øs of blood, they were obliged to pau≈øe a little: at what time the Knight of the Serpents well viewing the Princes Shield, on which was portrayed to the Life, the Picture of the Beautiful Bazilia, with many other quaint Devices, which made him ≈øuppo≈øe he had formerly ≈øeen that Shield, and that it was with ≈øome Friend of his he fought; wherefore with gentle words, he began to per≈øwade the Prince to di≈øcover him≈øelf, who as ≈øtrongly refu≈øed: So that having breathed, they began the Fight again ≈øo furiou≈øly, that they had certainly ≈ølain each other, had not their E≈øquires come running in and be≈øought them to forbear, for that they had either of them ≈øufficiently tryed their Strength; and ≈øo it happened, that the Princes E≈øquire dropped ≈øuch words, as gave the Knight of the Serpents, knowledge with whom he fought, ≈øo that laying down his weapon he ran and Embraced him in a mo≈øt loving manner; in≈øomuch that the Prince marveliing thereat, returned the like Courte≈øie, and then drawing up the Beavers of their Helms, they, to their great joy, knew each other, and grieved that they had made that ra≈øh Encounter; when having ≈øuffered their Wounds to be dre≈ø≈øed, and refre≈øhed them≈øelves at an adjacent Ca≈øtle, they rode in ≈øearch of the ≈øtrayed Prince.

div.head: CHAP. VII.

argument.p: How Eutrope gave Dramu≈øiand to under≈øtand, the approach of Prince Primaleon; and how upon his arrival, he Ju≈øted again≈øt Don Edoard; and by what means they came to know each other: How the Prince in attempting to deliver him, Combated with the Gyants, and was him≈øelf taken Pri≈øoner.

div.p: PRince Primaleon, Son to the Emperor of Greece, having ≈øought his beloved Brother-in-Law in divers Countries, at length came to the Engli≈øh Court, where he was highly Welcomed, as well in re≈øpect of his Nobility as Valour; yet not being at quiet till he had heard ≈øome News of him for who≈øe ≈øake he had undertaken many Adventures, he re≈øolved to ≈øearch every corner of this I≈øland; of which, by the ≈øecrets of her Art, Eutrope the Enchantre≈øs having notice, advized her Kin≈øman, that one of the Valiante≈øt Knights of the World would ≈øuddenly approach his Ca≈øtle, and try ≈øtrange Adventures for the recovery of Prince Edoard: Therefore ≈øhe coun≈øelled him to put him≈øelf and his Ca≈øtle into the be≈øt po≈øture of defence he might, le≈øt he run the hazard of loo≈øing it: Which Coun≈øel the Gyant neglected not to ob≈øerve; So that Arming his two Gygantick Brethren, viz. Pandare and Alligan, with divers other of his Friends: He al≈øo obliged Don Edoard, upon the Oath of his Knighthood, which he knew he would not violate, to oppo≈øe in Arms any that ≈øhould attempt to enter the Ca≈øtle; Barring all, unle≈øs one Gate that opened to the River, on which the Ca≈øtle was ≈øcituate, yet only a narrow Bridge to pa≈øs; and here the Gyant placed the Valiant Prince, who ≈øat mounted on Hor≈øe-back in Sable Armour, having for his Device, a Flaming Heart portrayed in a Silver Shield.

The Prince Edoard had not long been upon the Bridge, with his Spear ready in his Re≈øt, e're Primaleon came Riding up in Green Armour, and for his Device, in a Gold Shield he bore the troubled Ocean, ≈øo artificially drawn, that to the beholders the
Waves ≈øeemed to move: When addre≈ø≈øing him≈øelf to Don Edoard, he ≈øaid; Sir Knight, What place is this? or how is it called? This is, ≈øaid the Prince, the Ca≈øtle Perilous. Then ≈øaid Primaleon, I mu≈øt enter it: That you may not do, ≈øaid Prince Edoard, unle≈øs I fir≈øt am Vanqui≈øhed; no, nor then neither, unle≈øs you fight again≈øt and overcome divers Mon≈øtrous Gyants. All this will I attempt to do, ≈øaid Prince Primaleon, rather then lo≈øe my de≈øire; whereupon the Princes prepared, and run ≈øo fiercely at each other, that they both fell from their Hor≈øes, to their great amazement, neither of them before that time having felt ≈øuch Prodigeous ≈øtrength; when drawing their Swords they Charged again, but long they had not fought, e're ≈øome words falling between them, Don Edoard knew Primaleons voice, and ≈øaid, Mo≈øt Valiant Sir, I would not, tru≈øt me, injure you for any thing, I might thereby aquire, and am ≈øorry I have oppo≈øed the mo≈øt accompli≈øhed of Minkind, and my beloved Brother, both by Marriage and in Arms. Primaleon hearing this, ≈øtood no longer doubtful who it was, but ca≈øting down his Sword, would have Embraced him, had he not been hindred by the coming of Panda ‚Ä¢ e, a terrible Gyant, who commanded Prince Edoard upon the Oath of his Knighthood, which he had given to Dramu≈øiand, to retire, which he did; and then Prince Primaleon would have followed, but the Gyant churli≈øhly thru≈øt him back, and ≈øtood to oppo≈øe him, which ≈øo enraged the Prince, that Charging upon the Mon≈øter with his Glittering Sword, that giving him a fierce blow, he made him ≈øtagger three Paces back; whereat the Gyant ≈ømoke the Prince on the Shield and clove it in ≈øunder, leading him unguarded unle≈øs with his Sword; yet nothing daunted, he fought ≈øo manfully, that he ≈øoon brought his Foe into great di≈øtre≈øs, and had ≈ølain him, had not Alligan his Brother, a Gyant more fierce, come to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance: Then wi≈øhed the Prince for his Brothers aid, who by rea≈øon of his Oath, could not a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, though in his heart he wi≈øhed him ≈øucce≈øs; yet not di≈ømay'd, the Grecian Prince ob≈øtinately continued the Combate, till this ≈øecond Gyant was greatly di≈øtre≈ø≈øed; in≈øomuch, that Dramu≈øiand doubting to whom the Victory would fall, came Armed to the Combate; yet admiring the Valour of the Heretick Prince, he fir≈øt
by ≈ømooth deceitful words endeavoured to win him to accord, that ≈øo he might have him in his power, but finding his Rhetorick no way forcible to work upon an invincible re≈øolution, for he had ≈øet down his Re≈øolution, either to free his Friend, dye, or remain Pri≈øoner with him; the latter of which, after a dreadful Combat, and many wounds on either ≈øide fell to his Lot, for the Prince having maintained the Combat again≈øt ≈øo many fre≈øhmen (at la≈øt fainting through lo≈øs of Blood) was ≈øeized by the three Gyants and carried into the Ca≈øtle, yet having him in their power, prizing his Valour at a high rate, they u≈øed him courteou≈øly, comforting him, and dre≈ø≈øing his wounds, not forbiding him to ≈øee his dear Friend Edoard, for who≈øe ≈øake he had hazarded his Life, with hopes in time of hath their deliveries; and ≈øo for many years they continued together, till they were delivered; as the Sequel of this Hi≈øtory will appear.

div.head: CHAP. VIII.

argument.p: How Palmerin the Emperor Knighted Prince Palmerin, and divers other young Princes and Lords, and appointed a Turnament, which they began, where two Strange Kts. arrived in Green Armour, and what el≈øe befell during the pa≈øtime.

div.p:
THe Young Prince Palmerin is now grown to mans E≈øtate, and having well approved his Strength and Courage, the Emperor re≈øolved no longer to withhold him from the Order of Knighthood, and that he might be the more Graced thereby, he cau≈øed a Royal Fea≈øt to be made, and A≈ø≈øembled divers Noble Princes and Lords, and vpon Ea≈øter Day, after Divine Service was done, the Emperor took the Prince in his hand, and declared his intent. Whereupon all the En≈øigns of Knighthood being brought, Frizel King of Hungary fa≈øtned on his Spurs, and what mo≈øt plea≈øed the Prince, the Fair Polinarda Girded his Sword about him by her Fathers command, for who≈øe ≈øake afterwards the Prince did wonders. Then were divers other Princes and Lords Knighted, as Gracian Son to the French King, Berolde Prince
of Spain, as al≈øo were Oni≈øtalde and Dramian his two Brothers, E≈øtrelant Son to the Hungarian King, Don Rou≈øel, Ble≈øart, Son to Belcar, Belizand Son to King Ter≈øius, Lyman of Burgundia, Son to the Duke of Tyrole, Francian, Son to the King of The≈ø≈øaly, Francilinus Polinardus, Son to the German Emperor, Adrian Son to Majortes, Germaine Son to the Duke of Orleance, Attenebrant, Son to the Duke of Tirendos, Attremoran, Son to the Duke Lece≈øin, Frizold, Son to Duke Drapos of Normandy, and Nephew to the King of Hungary, with many others that had been trained up in the Emperors Court.

The Order of Knighthood conferred on the afore≈øaid Heroick Youths, Suits and Armour was ordered for them, of the Riche≈øt that might be had, when as in honour of them, a Sumptuous Fea≈øt was made, and every one of them placed in the Great Hall, acording to their degrees; which ended, they prepared for Turnament; the place for that purpo≈øe being before alotted, divers expert Captains being ordered to Mar≈øhal them, the Emperor having appointed Palmerin to Lead the Gallant Troop, who in bright Armour Studded over with Diamonds and other Precious Stones, ≈øhewed like a Star, when as to ≈øee them the Emperor, Empre≈øs, and the Beautiful Prince≈øs Gridonia and Polinarda, with divers other of Quality, and Tran≈øcendent Beauty took their places, at what time, all the Princes being in a readine≈øs, Young Palmerin Advanced, and Couched his Spear again≈øt Libu≈øan, a reputed Famous Grecian Knight, and in his full Career, hiting him on the Brea≈øt, tumbled him from his Hor≈øe, which greatly rejoyced the Emperor, but more, the Beautious Prince≈øs Polinarda: by his example, all the other Knights Iu≈øted, and did brave Exploits, to the plea≈øure and amazement of the Spectators; but above all, the young Prince Palmerin bore away the Prize, not only at the Launce, but at the Sword, u≈øing it ≈øo Dexterou≈øly, that it was admirable but in the heighth of the Pa≈øtime, entred two ≈øtrange Knights in Green Armour, who dealt ≈øo furiou≈øly, that they overthrew divers of the Princes Train, which he perceiving, bowed to his Fair Mi≈øtris Polinarda, and ≈øetting his Spear in his Re≈øt, advanced to oppo≈øe them; one of the≈øe Knights had Portrayed in his Shield a Savage Mare, leading a Brace of Lyons, and from thence was Stiled the Knight of the
Savage man, but the other bore no device: again≈øt the former the Prince addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf, but found ≈øuch oppo≈øition, that he wondred greatly, for either of their Spears ≈øhivered in the Air, yet neither of them were ≈øo much as moved; upon which, drawing their ≈øwords, they began a fiercer Combat, which the Emperor fearing might end in the hurt of either of them, ≈øent to require them to forbear, for that they had ≈øufficiently proved each others ≈øtrength; but they made it their ≈øupplication that they might try it, and ≈øo continued without gaining upon each other, fighting to the Amazement of the Spectators, till it was duski≈øh, at which time the Emperor cau≈øed the retreat to be ≈øounded, and that every Knight ≈øhould retire to the Pallace, as for the other Green Knight, he was Encountred by Platire, Son to Primalion, and ≈øoon overthrown.

This days Iu≈øts being ended, and night come on, all but the two Green Knights returned to the Pallace, where di≈øarming them≈øelves and fea≈øting ≈øumptuou≈øly, they fell to dancing with the Ladies, performing it with great Dexterity, but here the Prince through ba≈øhfulne≈øs mi≈ø≈øed of his wi≈øh, for he verily hoped to have been honoured with his Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes fair hand, but whil≈øt he ≈øtood doubting, her Brother cho≈øe her, and ≈øo each by his example taking the Lady that fell to his Lot, or that he be≈øt liked; all that night was ≈øpent in pa≈øtime and Iolitry.

div.head: CHAP. IX.

argument.p: How the Sage Aliart of the Ob≈øcure Valley, ≈øent a Shield to the Prince Palmerin, which was taken from a Damo≈øel on the way, by the Knight of the Savage man, and how the Prince recovered it: Who Sage Aliart was, and why ≈øhe ≈øent the Shield.

div.p: MOrning come, as all the Knights were preparing for the Turnament, a Damo≈øel both Beautiful and Richly attired came into the Hall, and having well viewed the Knights, made Obey≈øance to the Emperor, and in words addre≈ø≈øed her ≈øelf as followeth:

Mighty Sir, ≈øaid ≈øhe, having been lately much
abu≈øed in your Dominions, and knowing that it is the Flower of Knighthood to revenge the Quarrels of injured Damo≈øels, I come to your Court to have Redre≈øs, then know dread Sir, I being ≈øent by Sage Aliart of the Ob≈øcure Valley, who wi≈øheth all happine≈øs to you, and your Po≈øterity, with a Shield, as a pre≈øent, to the Noble Prince Palmerin. As I pa≈ø≈øed through the Forre≈øt of Clear-Fountain, I met with a Knight in Green Armour, having a Savage man leading two Lyons, Portrayed in his Shield, who unkindly took it from me, ≈øaying, that if any of the Knights of your Maje≈øties Court was ≈øo hardy as to win it from him, he would abide their coming in that place for the ≈øpace of three days, wherefore that it may be adventured, for I make it my reque≈øt. The Dam≈øel having made this Relation, the Emperor and all the Knights pre≈øent were greatly troubled, but Prince Palmerin was at that time waiting upon his Mi≈øtri≈øs; when as every one did offer to undertake the Adventure, yet the Emperor would ≈øuffer none to do it till he had acquainted the Prince therewith; but divers envying his ri≈øing Glories, contrary to the knowledge of the Emperor, ≈øtole from the Court, and finding the Green Knight. Iu≈øted with him, but were not able to ≈øtand before him; when in the end, the Dam≈øel being highly Rewarded, the Prince attended by divers Knights, mounted, and Rode to the place; where he found tho≈øe that had advanced without order, overthrown, Hor≈øe and man; which cau≈øed him to make ready for the Charge, but the Green Knight who before had tryed his ≈øtrength, and having knowledge from the Dam≈øel that the ≈øhield could be worn by no other Knight, he retired, and ≈øuffered him to take it down, by which means he found it appertained to him. Then they kindly embraced, and the Prince cau≈øed the Green Knights Wounds to be dre≈ø≈øed, and favourably Invited him to the Court, but he refu≈øed to go, as not being at that time willing to be known.

The Prince having recovered the Shield, in the mid≈øt of which was a Palm Tree, Lively Portrayed; returned in Triumph, and was highly welcomed, and honoured of all: When as a ≈øecond Turnament began, in which he behaved him≈øelf more Valiantly then before, and at that time intirely won the Affections of the Fair polinarda, on whom he was extreamly Enamoured, though ≈øhe long hid her Love, which cau≈øed him to undertake many great
and dangerous Adventures. The Sage Aliart of whom we before made mention, Son to Manoda a great Sorcere≈øs, who from his Infancy trained him up in her Devili≈øh Art, ≈øo that by that means, he ≈øoon exceeded her in Witchcraft, in≈øomuch that he had perfect knowledge from all places what had happened, and of future Fate. This Aliart, for his better retirement, Built him a Ca≈øtle in a di≈ømal gloomy Valley, over≈øpread with Trees, and Walled on either ≈øide with Craggy and inacce≈ø≈øable Mountains, where he Studied, and by Spirits had frequent notice what Eutrope and Dramu≈øiand did, who≈øe Inchantments he ≈øtrove to fru≈øtrate, and deliver the Knight by his Superiour power, but found that the Fates had perfixed a certain time, and the man that was to effect it; wherefore that Prince Palmerin might be free from all enchantments, he ≈øent him the afore≈øaid Shield.

div.head: CHAP. X.

argument.p: How Prince Verner, and Duke Belchar, in the Company of Polendos, King of The≈ø≈øaly, arrived at Dramu≈øiand's Ca≈øtle, where entring Combate, they were all taken Pri≈øoners: How Recinde King of Spain, and Arendos King of France, travelled in Search of Don Edoard, and of the Adventures that befell them.

div.p:
PRince Verner, and Duke Belchar, having cured the wounds they received fighting again≈øt each other, re≈øolved to pa≈øs on thorough the Perillous valley in ≈øearch of Don Edoard, and ≈øo long they rode, that they came within ≈øight of the Gyant ‚Ä¢ s Ca≈øtle, who ≈øtanding upon his Guard, determined if po≈ø≈øible to take them Pri≈øoners; when as they were mu≈øing, ≈øo it happened; Polendos King of The≈ø≈øaly, came Riding up
to them, with whom being formerly acquainted, and knowing his Task was the ≈øame with theirs, they kindly Saluted him, and he them, ≈øo that di≈øcour≈øing together, they came to the Ca≈øtle Gate, where upon the Bridge they perceived a Knight in Black Armour, who did them deffante, this Knight was Don Edoard, who by Dramu≈øiands appointment was ≈øet to guard the pa≈ø≈øage; when as the≈øe three Knights ≈øtrained Complements with each other who ≈øhould begin the Encounter; but in the end, Prince Verner obtained his wi≈øh but in the fir≈øt Encounter he was unhor≈øed, whereupon he drew his Sword, but Don Edoard refu≈øed him, ≈øaying, it was the plea≈øure of the Lord of the Ca≈øtle that he ≈øhould have no more than the fir≈øt On≈øet, then Belchar came again≈øt him, but was overthrown as the former was, as al≈øo the third; then he retiring, the Gyant Pandare came again≈øt Prince Verner who was entring the Gate, and forbid him further acce≈øs, which he perce ‚Ä¢ ving, drew his Sword, ≈øo that between them began a dreadful Combat, but whil≈øt Belchar and Polindos were coming to his relief, the Princes Sword with a mighty Stroak he gave the Gyant, broke in the midle, whereupon, his Shield being cleft and he left defencle≈øs, Pandare gave him ≈øuch a ≈øtroak over the head with his Mate, as brought him to the ground, and layed him in a Trance, but by this time, Belchar and Polindos came up, and gave the Gyant divers wounds, which Aligant his Brother perceiving, came running to his Re≈øcue with a mighty Battle-Ax, and ≈øo layed about him, that though him≈øelf received many wounds, and that Pandare through lo≈øs of blood was fallen to the ground, he brought the King and Duke to his mercy, when di≈øarming them, he carried them by main force into the Lodging of Don Edoard and Primaleon, who pittying their hard misfortune, comforted them in the be≈øt manner, and u≈øed ≈øuch means as ≈øoon cured their wounds, acquainting them with the nature of the Ca≈øtle, and all that had happened from the time of their coming thither, till that day. Now it happened that four days after came Recinde King of Spain, and Arendos King of France, in ≈øearch of the Princes, viz. Edoard, and Primaleon, who having ≈øearched divers Courts and Countries, at length arriving in Brittain, and hearing that many brave Knights were lo≈øt in the unfortunate Forre≈øt they greatly fancied the Princes might be there,
confined by ≈øome that dwelt therein; whereupon entring, they rode ≈øo long till they came to a Broad way that led directly to the Ca≈øtle of Dramu≈øiand, when approaching it, they beheld two Knights come again≈øt them the other way, one of which had Armour ≈øpotted with Crim≈øon, and the other all black, bearing for his device a Grey-hound; the≈øe Knights likewi≈øe came in ≈øearch of the Princes, when at the bridge where Don Edoard ≈øtood prepared to receive them, they all met, and re≈øolved upon the Combate; but ≈øo it happened between Arendos and the Black Knight, that they could not agree about prehemenency, who ≈øhould fir≈øt enter the Bridge, but pa≈ø≈øed ≈øo many ≈øharp words, that at length though Don Edoard u≈øed many words to per≈øwade them therefrom, they prepared for the Combate, which Recinde and the other Knight perceiving, did the like, in≈øomuch that in the fir≈øt Encounter being all unhor≈øed, they with great fury drew their Swords, and gave and took ≈øo many deadly wounds, that through lo≈øs of blood they fainted, whereupon the Gyants came upon them, and by ≈øtrength of Arms taking them Pri≈øoners, carried them into the Ca≈øtle, where their wounds were dre≈ø≈øed, and they entertained with Civil re≈øpect by their friends they found there, and their Helmets being off, the two ≈øtrange Knights proved to be Majortes, and Belagris, both Valiant Knights.

div.head: CHAP. XI.

argument.p: How Prince Palmerin departed ≈øecretly from the Emperors Court to ≈øeek adventures, ≈øtiling him≈øelf the Knight of Fortune; how he came to the Inchanted Ca≈øtle, and what adventure befell him.

div.p:
PRince Palmerin being now twenty years of age, greatly de≈øired to win Immortal Fame abroad, as other Renowned Worthies had done, and thereby increa≈øe the e≈øteem Polinarda had of him, yet loath was he to go without her con≈øent; wherefore he watched all advantage to find all time to ≈øpeak to her, which was not long wanting,
for finding her one day fitting melancholly alone, he ≈øat down by her, and after much di≈øcour≈øe, ≈øurcharged with pa≈ø≈øion, thus began.

Fair Mi≈øtris of all my thoughts; that I love you above any earthly Creature, and would willingly prove it, at the hazzard of my Life, I hope you are not Ignorant, for certain it is, none can better de≈øerve my ≈øervice then your Incompareable ≈øelf, who are Natures Chief Ma≈øterpiece, and the wonder of your Sex; but ≈øuch is the thir≈øt of Glory that reigns in Mortals Brea≈øts, that to tell you my ≈øecret thoughts, I have determined for a while to forezo ≈øo great a ble≈ø≈øing, and ≈øeek Renown abroad, when with louder Victory, and gread Atchievements I ≈øhall return with joy, to lay my ≈øelf and Trophies at your feet.

This Speech, greatly ≈øurprized the Prince≈øs, who intirely loved him, and cau≈øed rears to over ca≈øt her Starry-eyes, when fetching a Sigh that almo≈øt rent her tender Brea≈øt, ≈øhe made this Reply; Sir, that I have given you manife≈øt hopes of obtaning my favour, I mu≈øt Blu≈øhing owne, and yet conjecture, that ≈øuch freene≈øs in me, hath created di≈ølike in you, or el≈øe you would not mention leaving my Fathers Court. Not ≈øo, ≈øaid the Prince, for 'tis for your ≈øake I would adventure, that ≈øo I may in ≈øome ≈øort render my ≈øelf worthy of ≈øo great and Ine≈øtimable a Iewel; therefore by you Incouraged, I ≈øhall be the more Fortunate; but I ≈øhall not, replyed the Prince≈øs, con≈øent to your departure: I beg, ≈øaid the Prince, that you would alter your re≈øolves, and in that make me happy‚ñ™ can that make you happy then ≈øaid the Prince≈øs? nay then e'n take your cour≈øe, 'tis a ≈ølight excu≈øe to leave me, becau≈øe you Love me not; therefore ≈øince you light ≈øuch true affection, I here renounce the Love I bare you, and from henceforth charge you to ≈øee my face no more, and thereupon, in a great Rage, ≈øhe flung away, not giving the Prince leave to re≈øpond, but left as one Thunder-≈øtruck, ≈øo far amazed at what he had heard, that it was long e're he recover'd his ≈øtupid Sences, when Recollecting manly Vertue, he re≈øolved upon what he had determined, not doubting to perform ≈øuch Noble Exploits, as might render him worthy of his Mi≈øtre≈ø≈øes Love, and overcome her anger; whereupon, revealing his mind to Sylvian his E≈øquire, who had vowed not to leave him in any Adventure, he
≈øecretly armed him≈øelf, and taking the Shield, ≈øent him by Sage Aliart, mounted, and in the twy-light left the City undi≈øcovered, to the great trouble of the Emperor and the whole Court; and ≈øo under the name of the Knight of Fortune he rode through many De≈øarts, without finding any Adventure; but coming at la≈øt to a Ca≈øtle ≈øurrounded with Trees, and over-grown with green Mo≈ø≈øe, and hearing Mu≈øick therein, he alighted, and gave his Hor≈øe to his E≈øquire, and entered, where he perceived a Knight in mourning Weeds, tuneing to a Lute his Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes prai≈øe, who being highly offended at the Prince's hold in≈øtruction, laying a≈øide his Mu≈øick, ran to arm him≈øelf, vowing to cha≈øti≈øe him, which the Prince perceiving, went out and mounted, there expecting his Adver≈øary, who was not long wanting, ≈øo that a fierce Encounter began; but the Prince, who≈øe Courage was highthened by the thoughts of fair Polinarda, ≈øoon di≈øarmed him, and brought him to his mercy; when as he commanded him (≈øeeing that he had ≈øo unju≈øtly quarrelled with him) to un≈øay all that he had ≈øaid in the prai≈øe of his Mi≈øtri≈øs, or prepare for Death; but finding him re≈øolutely bent, rather to dye than do it, and at the ≈øame time con≈øidering his own ca≈øe, he not only pardoned him, but commended his fidelity, and ≈øo mounting, left the place.
Now this Knight was called The Knight of Death, and bare the Portraicture of Death in his Shield, holding him≈øelf before that time invincible.

div.head: CHAP. XII.

argument.p: Who The Knight of Death was, and the cau≈øe of his ≈øolitary Life: How Prince Palmerin fought for the Pa≈ø≈øage of a Bridge; and of other Adventures.

div.p:
THis Knight of Death was Son to the King of Sardagina, who falling in Love with fair Altea, one of his Mothers Ladies of Honour, and Daughter to the Duke of Goelicia, his Father, to cro≈øs his love (having de≈øigned to marry him to the Queen of Sicilia, and he being avers thereto) cau≈øed the beautious Altea to be Poy≈øoned; whereupon this Knight (named
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ oriman) ≈øtiling him≈øelf the Knight of Death privately retired from the Court, and betook him≈øelf to the ≈øolitary place where the Prince found him, ≈øinging Songs in prai≈øe of her to her Picture, as if ≈øhe had been alive: And there he continued in like manner after the departure of the Prince, till his Father hearing where he was, compelled him to return.

The Prince having left the Knight of Death in his ≈øolitary retirement, much grieving at his foile, pa≈ø≈øed on, till coming to a Bridge, he found three Knights ≈øtriving again≈øt a ≈øingle Knight, for the pa≈ø≈øage, who bare for his Device a Bull-head, and ≈øo pui≈ø≈øant was he, that he foiled them, tumbling them to the Ground, which the Prince perceiving, addre≈øt him again≈øt, but they both meeting with force more than humane, fell from their Hor≈øes, when drawing their Swords, they fought with great fury, till in the end the Knight of the Bull (by a wound he received on his Head) fell to the ground, upon which the Prince ≈øtood up, and bid him at the peril of his Life di≈øclo≈øe his Name, and the rea≈øon of his keeping that pa≈ø≈øage, which he did as followeth: viz.

That his Name was Pompides, Son to Don Edoard and Argolanta Queen of the Inchanted I≈øland; and that he having
received divers wounds from two Knights, whom he had ≈ølain, a beautious Lady living in a Ca≈øtle clo≈øe by cured him, and injoyned him to keep that Bridge, till he met a Knight in red Armour, with a Lyon painted in his Shield, the whom if I conquered, to bring into her pre≈øence; and that having obeyed for three weeks, he had not in many Encounters been foiled before.
The Prince having received this ≈øatisfaction, pa≈ø≈øed on his way; together with his E≈øquire, having before obtained Licence for the other Knights to pa≈øs.

div.head: CHAP. XIII.

argument.p: How the Knight of the Savage Man came into the Tri≈øtfull Valley, and fought again≈øt Blandidon the Knight of the Swan, and of the ≈øorrowful Lady Pandritia: How Floriman the Knight of Death, coming to Con≈øtantinople, pitched his Tent, and in Honour of his Lady Altea, combated and conquered divers Knights.

div.p:
THe Knight of the Savage Man having rere≈øigned the Shield, as afore≈øaid, rode on in ≈øearch of Adventures, when coming into the Tri≈øtful Valley (where the ≈øorrowful Pandritia dwelt) he e≈øpied a Cave, and at the mouth of it broken Spears and Swords, as al≈øo a Tree fa≈øt by, on which hung the Shields of ≈øuch as had been vanqui≈øhed; at which while≈øt he was wondering, there came a Youth to him and demanded his Shield, unle≈øs he would retire or try the Combat, and that if he retired, and would carry his Shield with him, he adjured him upon his Knightly Oath to own his Cowardice wherever he came; to which the Savage Knight replyed, That to retire he intended not, but to try any Combat, if he might meet with a Combatant; when upon the
„Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ a Knight ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ed at all points came out of the C ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ whereupon the Windows of an „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ divers ≈øorrowful Ladies looked „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈øee the i≈ø≈øue of the „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ with the overthrow „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ his name, owning That the Lady of the Ca≈øtle was his Mother and the ≈øorrowful „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ di≈øcovered, and that by her command, „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ me, he undertook to encounter all Knights that pa≈ø≈øed that w ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ , that ≈øo they being vanqui≈øhed, might ≈øimpathi≈øe with his Mother in ≈øorrow, and be bound by Oath to a≈ø≈øi≈øt all ≈øorrowful and di≈øtre≈ø≈øed. Then would the Knight of the Savage Man (after he had told him who he was) have had him gone with him to the Forre≈øt of Great Brittain, to try the ≈øtrange Adventure of the Ca≈øtle, but he not being willing to have his Mother in her di≈øcon≈øolate, condition, it was not accorded, whereupon the Knight of the ≈øavage man pa≈ø≈øed on, and
‚Ä¢ landi ‚Ä¢ on kept his Po≈øt.

By this time
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ orima ‚Ä¢
the Knight of Death having left (by his Fathers command) his ≈øolitary Man≈øion yet re≈øtle≈øs in the place where his beloved Altea had lo≈øt her life, he ha≈øted to the City of Con≈øtantinople, where he pitched two Tents before the Emperors Palace all of black „Äà‚óä„Äâ wrote with Gold, and having of the Emperor obtained leave to Iu≈øt with the Knights „Äà‚óä„Äâ his Court, in honour of his decea≈øed Lady, upon condition, that ≈øuch Knights as ventured to vindicate or ju≈øtifie the≈øe Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes beauty, ≈øhould (if vanqui≈øhed) re≈øign their „Äà‚óä„Äâ , and have their names put into the Sepulchre of Love. The ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ nament began, in which divers were overthrown, and among≈øt the re≈øt, Prince Gratian, and Gueren his Brother,
‚Ä¢ lavian, R ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ndor, and Emerauld, all which were accordingly di≈øarmed, and their names put into the Sepulchre of Love, who „Äà‚óä„Äâ the contrary had won a Rich Tent of Silk, Sables, and Gold.

The Emperor perceiving the prowels of the Knight of Death, and under≈øtanding who he was, highly applauded and approved his valour; and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ding none of the Knights of the
Court could ≈øtand before him, cau≈øed the Iu≈øting to cea≈øe for that day, when retiring into the Court, Prince Floriman was highly fea≈øted, and commended of all the Ladies, but his affection could fix on none, the remembrance of his beloved Altea being ≈øtill fre≈øh in his memory; yet would he not lodge in the Palace, though invited thereto, but (evening being come) returned to his Tent.

div.head: CHAP. XIV.

argument.p: Of the ≈øecond days Ju≈øt, and what happened therein; How the Knight of Fortune met with the Green Knight, that accompanyed the Knight of the Savage Man, and what befell.

div.p: THe Knight of Death bearing away the Palm, cau≈øed many Knights (who had been foiled in the pre≈øence of their Lady) to grieve, and wi≈øh they had been better advi≈øed, than to have entered the Li≈øt again≈øt ≈øo approved a Knight: Yet the next day the Turnament was renewed, and divers Knights tryed their fortunes in favour of their Ladies, as Polinardus, Berolde, the Knight of the Sphere, and divers others, but their ≈øucce≈øs being no better than tho≈øe that had Iu≈øted before them, they were unarmed and lead into the Tent, to offer their name at the Sepulchre of Love.

The Knight of Death by the≈øe Adventures increa≈øing his Fame, re≈øolves no longer to wear his black Armour, but changed it for one more glorious, ≈øtuded over with Gold and Diamonds, having Branches enamell'd on, then Pellicans with Lovers hearts in their Beaks, and in his Shield he bare the Picture of his Lady, being highly honoured for his prowe≈øs and noble re≈øolution of all the Court; where I ≈øhall leave him in his change of Fortune, and follow Prince Palmerin under the di≈øgui≈øe of the Knight of Fortune.

The Knight of Fortune having performed many ≈øtrange Adventures, in the end came into a large Forre≈øt, where he met a Knight in Green Armour, who was in que≈øt of the Knight of the ≈øavage man, which Knight (proud of his ≈øtrength) would needs obliege the Prince to fight, unle≈øs he would tell him the cau≈øe of his travel and ≈øadne≈øs, which he utterly refu≈øing to do, the Combat fiercely began, and continued doubtful for the ≈øpace of an hour, at what time the green Knight (≈øor ‚Ä¢ wounded) fell through lo≈øs of blood) to the Earth; when as the Prince demanded who he was, as al≈øo the Knight of the ≈øavage man, the former of which declared, viz. That he was ≈øon to Sir Pridos of England, had to name Don Ro≈øian de la Bronde; but as for the later, he refu≈øed it, ≈øaying, He was obliged to keep it ≈øecret, upon his Oath of Knighthood, and therefore would rather dye than reveal it; which ≈øatisfying the Prince, he left him to the Cure of a Lady that lived hard by, to have his wounds cured, and rods all he came to another fair Ca≈øtle.

div.head: CHAP. XV.

argument.p: How Palmerin having notice that the Knight of Death in honour of Altea had overthrown all the Knights that Ju≈øted again≈øt him, he in honour of his Mi≈øtri≈øs the fair Polinarda, returned to Con≈øtantinople, and overthrew him.

div.p:
THe Knight of Fortune coming to a beautiful Ca≈øtle, kept by the Lady Rianda, intered, and was there (by the Ladys order) ≈øplendidly entertained, and tho≈øe few wounds he had received in the Encounters dre≈ø≈øed, and well regarded: When plea≈øed with the plea≈øant citivation of, the place, he continued there ≈øo long, till in the end Lucinda (a Lady of the Emperor's Court, and attendant on the fair Polinarda) arrived there, being Ne ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to the
Lady of the Ca≈øtle, who knowing the Prince, ≈øaluted him kindly, and told him what had pa≈ø≈øed, ≈øince his ≈øudden and unexpected departure, and what cen≈øures had pa≈ø≈øed thereon, both by the Knights and Ladies; but above all, informed him what the Knight of Death had done to the di≈øgrace of all the Grecian Beauty; nor did his own Mi≈øtri≈øs the fair Prince≈øs ≈øuffer le≈øs, for want of one to defend her cau≈øe. This news did not a little trouble the Prince, by rea≈øon he knew not how to return ≈øo ≈øuddainly, without a blemi≈øh to his Honour; yet con≈øidering it might be a means to reconcile him to his love, he re≈øolved to return in di≈øgui≈øe to the place where his pre≈øence was ≈øo much de≈øired, and from whence he had been ≈øo long ab≈øent; when as early in the morning taking leave of the Lady and Damzel, without acquainting them which Road they intended to take, Sylvian and the Prince departed, through many De≈øarts and Forre≈øts, till ≈øuch time as they came within ≈øight of the City, where the Prince attired him≈øelf in a rich ≈øute of Armour, though without any Device, that he might be the better concealed: When riding before the Palace, he e≈øpied his beautiful Mi≈øtri≈øs in the Balcony, with many other Ladys, and found at that time the Knight of Death had overthrown a Grecian Knight named Titubant, who ju≈øted again≈øt him, in the honour of his Mi≈øtri≈øs the fair Cardignia, and was leading him into his Tent to unarm him; when as entering the Li≈øt, he bid the Knight of Death defiance, who (angry that his task was not done) made ready to receive him, when meeting with their Spheres, the Knight of Death was ca≈øt to the ground and ≈øorely brui≈øed, which cau≈øed a great ≈øhout, e≈øpecially among the Ladies; and by this means the Prince got the rich Tent, and was loaded with infinite prai≈øes, every one being de≈øirous to know who he was, but he re≈øolving to keep him≈øelf ≈øecret, withdrew, and changed his Armour, ≈øo that he could not be known: When as that night the Emperor made a great Fea≈øt in honour of his Court-Ladies, and the revenge that had been taken on their behalf, by the unknown Knight; but though ≈øearch was made for him, by his Command, yet was he not di≈øcovered, though he fate among≈øt the other Knights, and had
the happine≈øs to ≈øee his fair Mi≈øtri≈øs dance, yet dur≈øt not ≈øpeak to her. Then was the Sepulchre of love brought among≈øt them, which the Ladies ≈øpoiled, every one taking her own Picture thence, which her Knight had forfeited, in attempting to vindicate her beauty; yet Altea's Picture was ≈øet up among≈øt other beautys.

While≈øt this was doing, the Prince finding great enquiry was made after him, took his Hor≈øe and Arms, and with his E≈øquire departed the City; where in ≈øearch of new Adventures I ≈øhall leave him a while, and return to the Knight of the ≈øavage man.

div.head: CHAP. XVI.

argument.p: How the Knight of the ≈øavage Man landed in Ireland, and fought with the Gyant Calfurnine, ≈ølew him, and delivered three Ladies he kept Pri≈øoners in his Ca≈øtle, and gave the Ca≈øtle to them.

div.p:
NOw the Knight of the ≈øavage Man having left Blandidon in the Tri≈øtful Valley, rode through many Countries, with a re≈øolution to try the Adventure of the Unfortunate Forre≈øt of Great Brittain, which by this time began to be Famed in all places, for the lo≈øs of ≈øo many Knights as entred into it; wherefore imbarquing for England, and a contrary wind ari≈øing, he was driven upon the Coa≈øt of Ireland, where beholding the plea≈øantne≈øs of the Countries cituation, he was greatly de≈øirous to land, but the Ma≈øter of the ≈øhip endeavoured to per≈øwade him therefrom, by telling him a mon≈øtrous Gyant inhabited a Ca≈øtle near the ≈øhore, who was wont to kill or take Pri≈øoner ≈øuch as unadvi≈øedly pa≈ø≈øed that way; but this di≈øcour≈øe was ≈øo far from di≈øplea≈øing the Knight, that it (on the contrary) made him the
more de≈øirous, re≈øolving to combat the Gyant if po≈ø≈øible; whereupon cau≈øing the Ve≈ø≈øel to put into a Creek, he leaped on ≈øhore, and having gotten his Hor≈øe, rode towards the Ca≈øtle, only accompanied with his E≈øquire, but arriving there, he found he could not ride to it, but with great hazard and difficulty, by rea≈øon it was placed on the top of a ≈øteep Rock, that had but one vi≈øible a≈øcent; wherefore leaving him below, he mounted, only with his ≈øword; when being on the top, three armed Knights that attended on the Gyant i≈ø≈øued out again≈øt him, and bid him defiance, ≈øwearing his life ≈øhould pay for that bold attempt; but he little regarding their menaces, drew his dreadful ≈øword, and began the Combat ≈øo fiercely, that two of them fell dead, and the other being ≈øore wounded, retreated into the Ca≈øtle; whereupon the Gyant in a great rage came fo ‚Ä¢ th, being armed with a mighty Battail-Ax, ≈øtaring dreadfully, and vowing revenge, to avoid who≈øe fury the Knight of the ≈øavage Man guarded him≈øelf as well as might be, ≈øtill avoiding his mighty ≈øtrokes, till at la≈øt the Mon≈øter growing faint through heat, was the le≈øs able to weild his weapons, yet had he grievou≈øly wounded the Knight in divers places, broke his Shield in peices, and loo≈øened his Armour; but he being nimble, watched his opportunity, and ≈øtruck him a full blow on the Temples, which peirceing his Helmet, brought him to the ground, who falling, made the Earth tremble; then he ≈øtood upon him, and hewed off his mon≈øtrous Head; which the Ladies that he held Pri≈øoners in the Ca≈øtle perceiving, greatly rejoyced, and coming down into the Court, (where by this time the Knight was entered) they fell on their knees, giving him ten thou≈øand thanks, prai≈øing him and calling him their Deliverer; which the Knight perceiving, took them up, and comforted them in the be≈øt wi≈øe; when as they lead him into the Ca≈øtle, and having dre≈ø≈øed his wounds, they ≈øhewed him the plea≈øantne≈øs of the place, with which he was greatly delighted, the Ca≈øtle having been (not many years before) the Palace of one of the Iri≈øh Kings: But that which he was mo≈øt de≈øirous to know, was, how and by what means they came thither, and what they were; to which the beautiful Orianda,
elde≈øt of the three, reply'd, That they were Si≈øters, and Daughters to the Marque≈øs D' Baltamor, inhabiting Ca≈øtles and Rich Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions near that place, but ≈øo it happened, that being in the company of ≈øix Knights, making merry upon the Verge of an adjacent Forre≈øt, in a Rich Pavillion, the Mon≈øter whom he had flain, with his Knights, came upon them as they were unarmed, and ≈ølew three of the Knights, ≈øorely wounding the other three, and ≈øo by force of Arms brought them and the wounded Knights to the Ca≈øtle, and then them≈øelves were de≈øigned for his lu≈øt, and the other as a Sacrifice to his revenge, as ≈øoon as their wounds were healed, but that through his happy arrival Heaven had prevented ≈øo great a wickedne≈øs.

The Ladies having thus far di≈øcovered what the Knight de≈øired, they lead him to the place where the Gyant had cooped up divers Knights in Iron Cages, and kept them in extream mi≈øery, torturing them for his plea≈øure, and often threatning them with death, all which he ≈øet free, commanding them to give their attendance upon the Ladies, and not to ≈øuffer any to in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re them after his departure: And ≈øo having committed the keeping of the Ca≈øtle to fair Orianda, he departed, in order to his vi≈øiting the Unfortunate Forre≈øt, travelling towards which for a while I mu≈øt leave him, and return to Con≈øtantinople.

div.head: CHAP. XVII.

argument.p: How the Emperor comforted the Knight of Death, and obliged him to forget his heavine≈øs, for the lo≈øs of Altea; And how it was made known by what hand he was foiled.

div.p:
THe Knight of Death greatly grieving at the di≈øgrace he ≈øu≈øtained, fell into a violent Feavour; but being well recovered thereof, the Emperor cau≈øed him to be brought to Court, where he Communed with him, and comforted him in the be≈øt wi≈øe; lay≈øing before him the folly
of his greif, for a Lady that could not be recovered from the cold embraces of Death, de≈øiring him not ≈øo vainly to mi≈øimploy his Valour, but to u≈øe it in great atcheivements, worthy the ≈øame of ≈øo good a Knight; ≈øo that by the≈øe and ≈øuch like per≈øwa≈øions he wrought upon him ≈øo far, that he agreed to lay a≈øide his pen≈øive mood, yet not to forget his Lady, vowing never to ≈øet his mind upon any other.

During the≈øe per≈øwa≈øions, Lucinda arrived at Court, and made great inquiry after Prince Palmerin, which made the Emperor very de≈øirous to know the rea≈øon why ≈øhe inquired for him, who was departed long before her ≈øelf; wherefore he ≈øent for her in private, and demanded the rea≈øon, which ≈øhe no ways hiding, declared as followeth: viz.

That the per≈øon who conquered Prince Floriman was no other than the Prince Palmerin, though di≈øgui≈øed under the Title of the Knight of Fortune; for ≈øo it happened: That he coming to the Ca≈øtle of my Aunt Rianda, at what time I went to vi≈øit her, I found the Prince (whom I well knew) very pen≈øive, when inquiring into the cau≈øe, he would not tell me, but I who had been no ≈øtranger to the love he profe≈ø≈øed towards my Lady Polinarda, gue≈ø≈øed it proceeded (as al≈øo did his ≈øurprizing departure) from ≈øome repul≈øe received at her fair hands; when ≈øoon I informed him how all the Ladies beauties were eclip≈øed by the Knight of Death, (which now proves to be Prince Floriman) in honour of his Altea, whereupon the Prince without any more words taking his leave, came to this City, attended with his E≈øquire, and took off that ≈øtain, by overthrowing Floriman, in honour of his fair Polinarda, as he told me, when I met him upon his return from the triumph, and then injoyned me that the Tent he won ≈øhould be delivered to the fair Prince≈øs, to be kept by her in remembrance of his true affections till his return from the Unfortunate Forre≈øt of Great Brittain, whither he ≈øaid he was going, to try that great Adventure. At this unexpected news the Emperor and all the Court greatly rejoiced; nor was the Prince≈øs a little proud, that her Servant had performed ≈øuch a noble Adventure, geeiving that ≈øhe had ≈øo unkindly rewarded his true ≈øervice.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII.

argument.p: How Recaman came to the Emperor's Court, to maintain the Beauty of his Mi≈øtri≈øs Lucinda, again≈øt the Knight of Fortune; And how Tremerion on his behalf combated again≈øt him: How the Knight of Fortune arrived in England, entered the Forre≈øt, and what there befell him.

div.p: IT being noi≈øed abroad who it was that overthrew the Knight of Death, and for what Beauty it had been adventur'd, divers of tho≈øe that had been foiled were angry in them≈øelves; and others hoping to win the good affections of their Ladies by ≈øo hold an undertaking, re≈øolved to try their force again≈øt the Knight of Fortune, whom they ≈øuppo≈øed not to be far from the Court; and among≈øt tho≈øe that were ≈øo minded, the chief was Recaman, Son to the King of Bohemia, who re≈øolved to vindicate the Beauty of his Lady Lucinda above all others, but not finding the Knight of Fortune there, he grew impatient, earne≈øtly inquiring after him, and de≈øiring to Iu≈øt with him, vaunting of his Valour at ≈øuch a rate, that Tremerion Son to Duke Laciffin, and friend to Prince Palmerin, was evil at ea≈øe to hear it, and de≈øired the Emperor that he might undertake the Quarrel of his ab≈øent friend, which with much difficulty was granted, and the Li≈øt made, where after the fir≈øt cour≈øe ≈øhivering their Spheres, they betook them to their Swords, and fought ≈øo long, till through lo≈øs of blood Recaman fainted and fell; when by the Emperor's command the Combat was ≈øtayed, and each of the Combatants carryed to their Lodgings, to be cured of their wounds, and after recovery being made friends, they travelled to try the Adventure of the Unfortunate Forre≈øt.

The Knight of Fortune, as afore≈øaid, having left Con≈øtantinople, travelled ≈øo long, till arriving in France, he ≈øhipped him≈øelf for England, where landing, after refre≈øhing him≈øelf,
