he entered the Forre≈øt, not unknown to him, he having been a part of his Life brought up therein; the which he had no ≈øooner done, but a Hart fleeing before a Lyon, came running and couched at his feet, begging as it were his protection, when ≈øoon after the Lyon came, to oppo≈øe whom he drew his Sword, but ≈øeeing his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, and that he fell down as the Hart had done, he took compa≈ø≈øion on him, but had no time to pau≈øe, e're the ≈øavage Man, that had been his fo≈øter-Father, came in, and according to his rude nature (not di≈øcerning him at a di≈øtance) let fly an Arrow that pierced his Shield, and ≈øtill pre≈ø≈øing on, the Prince oppo≈øed him with his Sword, but upon his nearer approach, he having a better view of him, threw down his Bow and embraced him, leading him to his Cave, and inquiring many things of him, to which he amply an≈øwered; but above all, was inqui≈øitive after the welfare of his Son, whom he told him was near at hand, and that he had left him with the Hor≈øes: Then was the ≈øavage Man de≈øirous to tell him who≈øe Son he was, and how he came by him, but was interrupted by a great cry they heard in the Forre≈øt; upon which the Prince taking his Sword, went towards it.

div.head: CHAP. XIX.

argument.p: How Palmerin found Sylvan in great di≈øtre≈øs, and by what means he delivered him: How he ≈ølew the Gyant Camboldam, and met Sage Aliart of the Ob≈øcure, Valley; and what el≈øe befell him in that place.

div.p:
THe Prince ha≈øtening towards the out-cry, found four men armed, beating and draging Sylvan in a mo≈øt tyrannical manner; whereupon advancing towards them, he commanded them as they loved their lives to relea≈øe him; but they little regarding his words, commanded him likewi≈øe to render, him≈øelf their Pri≈øoner, which the
Prince (who had not been u≈øed to ≈øuch kind of language) disdaining, they ≈øtruck furiou≈øly at him, which occa≈øioned him to draw his Sword, and lay couragiou≈øly about him, in≈øomuch, that they ≈øoon repented meeting with ≈øuch a bold Champion, for within le≈øs than an hour three of them were ≈ølain, and the fourth upon his knees begged life; which the Prince had no ≈øooner granted, but up came a dreadful Gyant with two men leading the Hor≈øes Sylvan held, and finding his men ≈ølain and wounded, with great fury ran at the Prince, who as nimbly avoided his ≈øtroke and gave him a wound on his right arm, that made him drop his Sword, of which the Prince taking the advantage, ≈ømote him upon the Helmet with ≈øuch force, as cleft it, and the Sword pa≈ø≈øing three Inches into his Scull, brought him to the ground, which advantage the Prince perceiving, ≈øtood upon him, and ≈ømote off his Head; which the men that held the Hor≈øes perceiving, fell upon their knees and begged their lives, ≈øaying, That they were con≈øtrained to attend the Gyant, who was Brother to Calfurnine, ≈ølain by the Knight of the ≈øavage Man, and for that cau≈øe had vowed revenge on all he met: Vpon this ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion the Prince taking the Hor≈øes, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed them, and rode towards the Unfortunate Forre≈øt; where he found by the ≈øide of a Grove four Knights combating, the which he endeavoured to part, but could not, till Sage Aliart, by the power of Mageck, ca≈øt a Cloud over them, that they could not ≈øee each other; and then placing them in a Chariot, bare them through the Ayr, and cured their wounds; at what time the Sage appeared to the Prince, and informed him who the Knights that fought were, (viz. Pompides, Platire, Floriman, and Blandidon;) and afterward conveyed him to his Ca≈øtle, where he in≈øtructed him in future fate, and let him under≈øtand what great and amazing Atchievements he ≈øhould undertake and perform, and that all the wounded Knights ≈øhould recover.

div.head: CHAP. XX.

argument.p: How the Knight of the Savage Man arrived in England; And what befell him by the means of Eutrope the Inchantre≈øs.

div.p: EUtrope the Inchantre≈øs hearing that a great number of good Knights were come into England, to fini≈øh the Adventure of the Ca≈øtle, and that the Gyant her Nephew would be hard put to it, to defend him≈øelf, u≈øed her utmo≈øt diligence to create a wrong under≈øtanding between them, and by that means ≈øet them at variance to de≈øtroy each other: Whereupon ≈øhe ≈øent one of her Damo≈øels with feigned ≈øtories, who ≈øo exa≈øperated them, one again≈øt another, that they frequently fought, to the great effu≈øion of each others Blood: And among≈øt the re≈øt, flying before Polinardus, Son to the Emperor of Trincus; and meeting the Knight of the Savage Man, (who by this time was arrived from Ireland) ≈øhe begged him to re≈øcue her out of the hands of one that attempted to ravi≈øh her; which he undertaking to do, ≈øhe found two other Knights, (viz. Francian and Gracian) and ≈øet them upon the Knight of the Savage Man, ≈øaying, He had treacherou≈øly ≈ølain her Father, and now was about to do the like to her Brother; who fighting together, had been mo≈øt of them ≈ølain, had not Fredrick, King of England, been hunting in the Forre≈øt, and came in to pacifie them in time; yet ≈øuch was the cunning of the Damzel, that ≈øhe was withdrawn quite out of ≈øight, and could not be heard on afterward. But ≈øo it happened, that the wounded Knights being well regarded, recovered their healths ≈øoon after; as likewi≈øe did Oni≈øtaldus and Dramian, who by the like delu≈øion had combated each other; and to know the rea≈øon thereof Polinardus had followed her, when ≈øhe met the Knight of the Savage Man, and ≈øhe fal≈øly informed him.

div.head: CHAP. XXI.

argument.p: How the ≈øage Aliart brought the Bodies of Floriman, Platire, Pompides, and Blandidon, having healed them of their wounds, and ≈øet them in the ≈øame place again, where he found them fighting: How they got new Hor≈øes and Armour; And what happened to the Knight of Fortune in the Ca≈øtle of ≈øage Aliart.

div.p: SAge Aliart having conveyed the Bodies of the afore-mentioned Knights, to his Ca≈øtle, committed them to the care of divers Damo≈øels, who ≈øo well tended and dre≈ø≈øed them, that within two days they were all perfectly cured; when as he ca≈øt them into a deep ≈øleep, and in the ≈øame manner as he brought them, conveyed them to the place where they fought; at which they awakeing, greatly wondered, and ≈øtood long gazing upon each other, e're any of them broke ≈øilence, much marvelling to find them≈øelves unarmed, and that the place was in a manner paved with their broken Weapons, Blood, and Armour.

But whil≈øt they mu≈øed upon the matter, a Virgin approached them, and demanded how they came into that condition; but they not being able to relate the matter, and ≈øhe perceiving as much, proffered them Hor≈øe and Arms, if they would undertake to fini≈øh on Adventure, on the behalf of a ≈øorrowful Lady, who mu≈øt otherwi≈øe (as ≈øhe avered) fall into great calamity; the which they vnanimou≈øly undertook to do; whereupon leaving them a while, ≈øhe returned amply furni≈øhed, and to attend them, brought for each an E≈øquire; whereupon having returned their thanks, they mounted, and followed her; in pro≈øecution of which Adventure, I ≈øhall for a time leave them, and return to the Knight of Fortune.

Prince Palmerin, commonly called The Knight of Fortune, having continued for ≈øome time with Sage Aliart, and obtained from him a promi≈øe to be ever at hand, to a≈ø≈øi≈øt him, when need
≈øhould require; as al≈øo that he ≈øhould e're long fini≈øh the Adventure of the inchanted Ca≈øtle, and know his Birth and Parentage: He having taken leave, departed towards the Kings Palace; when being belated, he betook him≈øelf to the Hou≈øe of an Aged Gentleman, who gave him entertainment to his ≈øatisfaction; but long he had not been there, e're a ≈øtrange Lady arrived, in ≈øearch of him, who no ≈øooner beheld him, but with her eyes brim-full of tears, ≈øhe fell at his Feet, and de≈øired he would undertake to revenge the Injury ≈øhe had ≈øu≈øtained; at what time gently rai≈øing her, he bade her be of good comfort, promi≈øing her to comply with any rea≈øonable reque≈øt, de≈øiring her to relate the cau≈øe of her grief, which ≈øhe did after this manner:

Know, Worthy Sir, who≈øe Fame is rai≈øed above the Clouds for Matchle≈øs Deeds, That I had once a Son, hardy and bold, who performed many Noble Feats in Arms; but at la≈øt it ≈øo fell out: That he falling in Love with a Beautifull Lady, and gaining her good Will, a Knight, that had been her former Sutor, was ≈øo exa≈øperated thereby, that he defied him to combate, wherein my ≈øon was Conqueror, which heightened the Ladys good e≈øteem more and more, and made the Knight's envy increa≈øe, ≈øo that through many fal≈øe ≈øugge≈øtions he procured the Knight of the ≈øavage-Man to fight him, who having brought him to his Mercy, without all pity, unkindly ≈øundered his Head from his Body, to my un≈øpeakable Grief. Now my reque≈øt is, That you would undertake the Combate, on my behalf, again≈øt the Knight of the ≈øavage-Man, who now re≈øides at London, and revenge his uncourteous dealing.
The Lady having ≈øaid thus much, the Prince greatly pittying her, vowed by his Knighthood to undertake her Quarrel, re≈øolving to be at London the next morning.

div.head: CHAP. XXII.

argument.p: How the Knight of Fortune arrived at London; And of his kind entertainment: How he challenged the Knight of the ≈øavage-man; And the i≈ø≈øue of the Fight between them.

div.p:
PRince Palmerin having promi≈øed to undertake the afore≈øaid Quarrel, ha≈øted to London, to make ≈øhort of the matter, and the rather he covered to be in action, by rea≈øon that Knights great Deeds began to eclip≈øe his Fame; wherefore he ≈øent Sylvan his E≈øquire, to bid him defiance, and to give and receive the Gages; which done, the Knight of Fortune retreated him≈øelf with an ancient Hermit, till the time appointed came di≈øcour≈øing of various matters: But when the King under≈øtood that tho≈øe couragious Knights re≈øolved upon a combat, fearing the lo≈øs of one or both of them, he would be hardly induced to admit of it, nor would he have done it, but at the earne≈øt reque≈øt of the Knight of the ≈øavage-Man, who pleaded, that his Fame and Glory would ≈øuffer by refu≈øal; whereupon at the day appointed they met each other, and after ≈øome parly, took a full curreir, ≈øhivering their Spheres in a thou≈øand pieces but neither di≈ømounted nor lo≈øt their Stirups; whereupon they drew their Swords, and fought like Tygars, hewing and cutting each others Armour in pieces, in ≈øo piteous a manner, as made the hearts of the ≈øpectators tremble, and each one fear that they would both have dyed in the place, e're either would have yielded; for when they were weary of ≈øtriking, then would they graple with each other, ≈øo that they lo≈øt Blood in abundance, which made the King and Prince≈øs Flerida ≈øtep between them, and intreat them to Sheath their Swords, to do which with much difficulty they prevailed; whereupon the Knight of the ≈øavage-Man was conducted to the Court, and the Knight of Fortune returned to his former Lodging, where his wounds were cured: But coming to inquire
after the Lady who had occa≈øioned this Combate, they found her not, for it was altogether fictitious that ≈øhe had ≈øaid, and a contrivance of Eutrope the Inchantre≈øs, to endanger the lives of tho≈øe Knights ≈øhe knew to be de≈øigned for fini≈øhing the Adventure of the Ca≈øtle, where the Princes were detained; who likewi≈øe by another device a≈ø≈øembling divers Knights that were in que≈øt of the ≈øtrayed Princes, before the Ca≈øtle, and by the means of fal≈øe rumours, ≈øhe divided them into two Parties, ready to ingage in mortal Battail, which they had done, had not Sage A ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ o counterplotted her Inchantment, and removed the occa≈øion of Quarrel.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII.

argument.p: How the Knights (after skirmi≈øhing with each other) were inchanted, and all taken Pri≈øoners: How Eutrope practi≈øed with the Soldian of Babylon to invade the Greek Empire: Of the Adventure of the Knight of the Savage-Man, at the Ca≈øtle of Dramu≈øiand; And how he ≈øped in that doubtfull and dangerous attempt.

div.p:
THe Inchantre≈øs Eutrope being greatly de≈øirous to fru≈øtrate the de≈øigns of the Adventurous Princes, by Spells, ≈øpread ≈øuch di≈ø≈øention among≈øt them, and at the ≈øame time changing (to appearance) their Armour, and Devices, by ca≈øting a Mi≈øt before their Eyes, that they ≈øuppo≈øing each other to be Enemies, charged furiou≈øly in Partys, and layed on ≈øuch heavy ≈øtrokes, that their Armour and broken Swords flew in the Ayr; of which Sage Aliart having notice, covered them with darkne≈øs, and ≈øo ≈øtupified their ≈øen≈øes with Spells, that they fell to the ground, and there lay groveling, as not able to ri≈øe, till ≈øuch time as the Gyant with his noble Attendants came out of the Ca≈øtle, and took them Pri≈øoners;
when taking off their Helms, they found them to be Friends and Kin≈ømen; whereupon they embraced each other with great Ioy, yet grieved to find them≈øelves in bondage.

Eutrope the Inchantre≈øs greatly maligning Palmerin the Emperor, who was one of tho≈øe that ≈ølew her Brother, ≈øent divers Letters, full of in≈øinuation, to the Soldian of Babylon, to let him know, that he could find no fitter time to invade the Emperor's Territories, for that ≈øhe had all his be≈øt Knights in her po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and that tho≈øe that remained in his Court, were of no account, and that if he would come down with an Army, he might ea≈øily take the City of Con≈øtantinople; of which the Soldian took the advantage, though to little purpo≈øe, as ≈øhall be hereafter related.

The Knight of the Savage-Man being by this time healed of the wounds he received, in the combate again≈øt the Knight of Fortune, re≈øolved no longer to delay trying the Adventure of the Forre≈øt; and thereupon furni≈øhing him≈øelf with all things nece≈ø≈øary, he ≈øolemnly took his leave of the King, Queen, Prince≈øs, and all the Nobles, and mounting, rode to the Valley of Perdition, ≈øo called, by rea≈øon who entered it, returned no more, but were detained in the Ca≈øtle, all the ways being ≈øet with Spells of Inchantment. When being entered, he rode pen≈øively, till he came within fight of the Ca≈øtle, in the Court of which he perceived divers Knights, gloriou≈øly attired, preparing to Iu≈øt, which made him verily believe (as indeed it was true) that this was the Ca≈øtle, wherein the Princes, and Flower of Europian Chivalry, remained; ≈øo that pa≈ø≈øing on, he found the Bridge guarded by divers Knights, at what time (contrary to cu≈øtom) Recinde King of Spain, had obtained of the other Princes to have the fir≈øt Encounter, if the Knight approached; ≈øo that couching his Speare, he ran furiou≈øly again≈øt him, but met with ≈øuch re≈øi≈øtance, that he recoiled divers paces, and was thrown over and over; whereupon Arnedes King of France, grieving to behold his Companion in that plight, addre≈ø≈øed him in like manner, but fared no better than the former; which Prince Primalion ≈øeeing, and doubting the event, with a ≈øtrong Speare came again≈øt the Knight of the
Savage-Man with great force, but was overthrown as the fir≈øt. This made Prince Edoard much marvel, yet re≈øolved to try that Force, that had effected ≈øuch wonders, and thereupon ran again≈øt him with a ≈øtrong Speare, when being received in the like manner, both their Speares ≈øhivered in the Ayr, and their Hor≈øes recoiling, fell to the ground, though the Knights kept upon their backs, but ≈øoon recovering their feet, they would have drawn their Swords, but by Dramu≈øiand's command Don Edoard was oblieged to retire; Pandare advancing to ≈øupply his place, bade the Knight of the Savage-Man yield to his mercy; but he with disdain refu≈øing it, a dreadfull Conflict began, which continued with ≈øuch fury, that after many wounds given and received, the Gyant fainted, and fell, when as the Knight ≈øtood upon him to take off his Head, but was prevented by the ≈øuddain intru≈øion of Aligan, who defied him to the fight, ≈øo that leaving the wounded Gyant, he charged upon the other, who often bade him yield to his mercy, though in vain, for our couragious Knight within a ≈øhort time brought him into as bad a plight as was the other, though him≈øelf at the ≈øame time was not free from wounds; ≈øo that now there remained no more than Dramu≈øiand to combat with, who came fiercely upon the Knight, yet (having taken breath) he received him more fiercely than he could expect from one in his condition, when after a furious Combate their Swords broke, whereupon they grapled, and fell (≈øore brui≈øed and wounded) to the ground; when as Sage Aliart being at hand, ca≈øt ≈øo dark a Fogg over them, and having ≈øeparated them, ≈ønatche the Knight of the Savage-Man up, in a flaming Charriot, carrying him in a Tempe≈øt through the Ayr; which the Knights and Gyants perceiving, in great amazement came to Dramu≈øiand, and carried him into the Ca≈øtle, in order to the healing of his wounds.

div.head: CHAP. XXIV.

argument.p: How the Knight of Fortune, leaving his Ho≈øt, found the Knight of the Savage-Man in a Pavillion, lying as dead: How he came to know him to be his Brother; And wherefore he was borne thence; With what el≈øe happened on that occa≈øion.

div.p: THe Prince, (or Knight of Fortune) after the ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an between him and the Knight of the Savage-Man, being cured of the wounds he had received the ‚Ä¢ en ‚Ä¢ , took ‚Ä¢ eave of his Ho≈øt to ≈øearch new Adventures; when travelling with his E≈øquire, late in the Evening, by a Forre≈øt ‚Ä¢ ide, he at a di≈øtance e≈øpyed divers Lights on a heap, whereupon he made towards them‚ñ™ and found them placed in a little Pavillion, which he entered, and there found a comely Knight, lying upon a Bier, and an armed Knight ≈øtanding by him, who made great moan; when looking upon the armed Knight, he knew him to be Don Ro≈øian D' la Bronde, Nephew to King Frederick; whereupon he demanded who the Knight on the Bier was, to which the other replyd: It was the Knight of the Savage-Man; who trying the Adventure of the Unfortunate Ca≈øtle, had (by the force of divers Knights and mon≈øtrous Gyants, after a terrible Combate, in which much blood was ≈øhed) been ≈øo mi≈øu≈øed, but how he was brought thither he could not inform him, as being him≈øelf arrived at the Pavillion but a little before.

This news made the Knight of Fortune ≈øad, who greatly e≈øteemed the Knight of the Savage-Man for his Valour, and was de≈øirous of nothing more, than to enter into Friend≈øhip with him; wherefore he vowed revenge on tho≈øe that had ≈øo abu≈øed him, for he well perceived by his mangled Armour, the fearful Combate he had ≈øu≈øtained; then with a Torch looking more wi≈øhfully on his face, many thoughts aro≈øe in him, that it could be no other than his Brother Florian, under the di≈øgui≈øe of the
Knight of the Savage-Man; which opinion of his was more and more confirmed by Sylvan, the Savage-Man's Son, who had been nouri≈øhed with the Princes; ≈øo that hiding his ≈øorrow as well as he might, he demanded of Don Ro≈øian D' la Bronde what the true name of the Knight was, who replyed, he was ignorant therein, but that he had told him, he was in his younger days brought up by a Savage-Man, though he could not believe him to be his Father, and therefore he had named him≈øelf the Fatherle≈øs, till he could have further knowledge of his Birth; and that ≈øtraying out of the Forre≈øt, he had been carryed to the King's Court, by one Sir Pridos, where he had been liberally educated, and of the King received the Order of Knighthood.

This Speech ab≈øolutely confirmed the Knight of Fortune's doubt, and it grieved him extreamly, that his Brother Florian ≈øhould be ≈øo untimely ≈ølain, e're he had knowledge of him, yet vowed Revenge, though at the hazard of his Life; but ≈øo it hapned, that whil≈øt he was mu≈øing, the Tent and Bier were in a Whirlwind carried into the Ayr, and ≈øo out of ≈øight; whereupon the two Knights ≈øtood gazing at each other a long time, e're they broke ≈øilence, which in the end they did, and then the Knight of Fortune demanded of the other, whether he would accompany him in the Adventure, to which he replyed, That he had been injoyned to bear the Armour of the Knight of the Savage-Man to King Frederick, and inform him of all that had happened; whereupon after friendly ≈øalutation they departed, the Knight of Fortune on his way to the Adventure, and D' la Bronde to the Court; where, upon his arrival, the Death of (as he ≈øuppo≈øed) the Knight of the Savage-Man being made known, ≈øo great was the Grief, that 'tis almo≈øt unexpre≈ø≈øible; yet in Honour of his Fame, the King commanded his Armour to be hung up in the hou≈øe of En≈øigns, among≈øt the Armour of the Kings and Noble Knights, and underneath in Characters of Gold his Noble Exploits to be recorded to Po≈øterity.

div.head: CHAP. XXV.

argument.p: How the Knight of Fortune arriving at the Inchanted Ca≈øtle, undertook the Adventure, killing Aligan, and overcoming the others that oppo≈øed him, whereby he di≈ø≈øolved the Inchantment, and delivered the captive Princes; And of the vniver≈øal Joy that in≈øued upon that occa≈øion.

div.p:
THe Knight of Fortune leaving D' la Bronde on his way to the Court, entered the Perilous Valley, where having rode a whole day, he had ≈øight of the Ca≈øtle, the which (by the de≈øcription he had of it) he knew to be the ≈øame in which the Princes were confined; whereupon he determined to re≈øt that night, that he might have the whole day before him, to fini≈øh that great Adventure, on the performance of which his Honour and Immortal Fame was ≈øtaked. The night he ≈øpent upon a Mo≈ø≈øy Bank, under a ≈øpreading Beech, in contemplating on the Beauty of his fair (though cruel) Mi≈øtri≈øs, the Prince≈øs Polinarda, as al≈øo on the Task he was to undertake: But when Aurora's Blu≈øhes u≈øher'd in the Sun's bright Beams, he aro≈øe, and took a ≈øurvey of the dangerous place, which he found invironed with Mon≈øtrous ≈øhapes, the Works of Inchantment, and that the pa≈ø≈øage was exceeding narrow; yet re≈øolving at the hazard of his Life to prove his Prowe≈øs, he advanced, having the Shield of the Palm Tree on his Arm, which was ≈øent him by Sage Aliart; ≈øo that coming to the Bridge, he found his unknown Father, Don Edoard, ready to receive him, whom in the fir≈øt careir he unhor≈øed, and alighting, would have ingaged him with his Sword, but that Pandare the Mon≈øtrous Gyant advancing, interpo≈øed his mighty Shield, ≈øo that a fearful Combate between the Knight of Fortune and him began, in≈øomuch that the Gyant was grievou≈øly wounded, by rea≈øon his Sword would not enter the Inchanted Shield, whereupon the Gyant roared
like an inraged Bull, yet could get no advantage, but fainting at la≈øt, through lo≈øs of Blood, fell down, which Aligan of the Ob≈øcure Cave ≈øeeing, came running to his Brothers re≈øcue, who≈øe Head had el≈øe been ≈øundered from his mon≈øtrous Trunk: Then the Knight of Fortune addre≈ø≈øed again≈øt him, and after the exchange of ≈øix blows, ≈ømote him ≈øo full on the Helm, that cutting it through, and the Sword entering three Inches, down he fell, like an Earthquake; when as the Knight of Fortune being nimble, ≈øtood upon him, unbuckled his Helm, and e'r Dramu≈øiand could come in, cut off his Head.

Dramu≈øiand ob≈øerving this evil ≈øucce≈øs, concluded that this was the Knight, his Aunt had ≈øo often told him, ≈øhould fini≈øh the Inchanment, wherefore he (greatly feared) yet came forward, and commanded the Knight of Fortune to yield him≈øelf Pri≈øoner, who replyed, with a noble disdain, That he could not hearken to any ≈øuch terms, whil≈øt he was able to weild that Sword, that never in any Adventure had failed him: Whereupon ≈øo ≈øtrong an Encounter began, as made the Earth (with the forcible ≈øtrokes) to tremble, and the Eccho to re≈øound from the Hills, Caves, Rocks, and Ca≈øtle-wall; Dramu≈øiand, who had never felt the like force before, greatly wondered at the Prowe≈øs of the Knight, and ≈øuppo≈øing him more than Mortal, began to repent he had entered the Battail again≈øt him, for growing faint, the ≈øweat and blood flowed from him in ≈øuch abundance, that he was little a≈ø≈øured of his Life; wherefore thinking the Knight of Fortune as much ≈øpent as him≈øelf, he again moved him to a ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, but found his admonition no ways forcible, to work on him, who was re≈øolutely determined either to end the Adventure or his Life; and ≈øo much Fortune favoured her Darling, and was aver≈øe to Dramu≈øiand, that the Gyant (≈øpent with lo≈øs of blood, wearine≈øs, and wounds) fell to the Earth whereupon Voices, Thunder, and Lightning, filled the place, at which while≈øt the Knight was wondering, the Captive Princes came & be≈øought him to ≈øpare the Gyant's life, for that he had of late u≈øed ≈øuch kindne≈øs towards them, that they could (in honour) do no le≈øs than interceede for him in his extremity; to which reque≈øt the Prince (as he was going
to ≈øtrike the dreadful blow) hearkening, with-held his hand, and yielded to their de≈øires; immediately in a Tempe≈øt, as loud as Fighting, Winds, or cattling Thunder, the Inchantments vani≈øhed; whereupon all the Princes returned their thanks to the Knight of Fortune, for their deliverance, and in triumph conducted him into the Ca≈øtle, whither by this time they had brought the wounded Gyants, all who≈øe wounds were ≈øoon after cured, unle≈øs Aligan's, who returned no more to tell his Tale.

This happy Deliverance wrote, Prince Floriman was cho≈øe by the re≈øt to go to Court, and inform the King, Queen, fair Flerida, and all the Noble Lords and Ladies, of all that had happened, who joyfully undertaking the Task, armed him and rode with ≈øpeed: When upon his arrival, having from point to point declared his Me≈ø≈øage, and averred the truth of it, upon the Oath of his Knighthood; the Ioy was ≈øo great, that it is impo≈ø≈øible to expre≈øs it every man prai≈øing the Knight of Fortune, and ≈øinging him Triumphant and Victorious, ≈øounding loud Mu≈øick, ringing Bells, and turning night to day with ≈øhining Fires; but above that of the King, Quam and Prince≈øs, exceeded the re≈øt, as does the Suns bright beams the pale and watery glimering of the Moon; whereupon at the reque≈øt of the later, that the ≈øatisfaction might be general, the King ≈øent Argolant to Con≈øtantinople with more welcome tydings than he had before been Me≈ø≈øenger of; and ≈øo far they plea≈øed the Aged‚ñ™ Emperor Palmerin, that upon the relation of all the Princes ≈øafeties, tears of Ioy bedewed his Eyes, his heart being too full other ways to expre≈øs it. And now Polinarda did not repent the wondering of her Love, but highly applauded his brave Exploits; wi≈øhing ≈øhe had been kinder to him than ≈øhe was yet hoped at his return ≈øo to be have her ≈øelf, towards him‚ñ™ as became her Mode≈øty and High Decent.
And, thus may we behold how true Valour and courteous Behaviour ‚Ä¢ mounts Men on the Wings of Fame, and ≈øets them on a Piramide.

div.head: CHAP. XXVI.

argument.p: How Eutrope's Inchantments being fini≈øhed, the Princes re≈øtored Dramu≈øiand his Ca≈øtle, and came to King Frederick's Court, where they were Nobly entertained, and were there vi≈øited by divers Pontentates.

div.p:
NOw the Prince having thus long continued in the Ca≈øtle, had at the intreaty of Prince Edoard, con≈øented to re≈øtore it again to Dramu≈øiand, upon condition that he ≈øhould not retain it to the prejudice of any Knight, nor hearken to the malicious advice of his Aunt Eutrope, and that from that time, it ≈øhould in honour of the noble Knight that fini≈øhed the Adventure, be called The Ca≈øtle of Fortune; to all which, when he had con≈øented, and ≈øolemnly ≈øworn‚ñ™ to ob≈øerve, they delivered him the Keys, and then taking their leaves, rode towards London, where the King and his Court re≈øided, who≈øe approach being known, thou≈øands of people of all Capacitys flocked to meet them, greatly rejoycing, and highly applauding them as the Flower of Chivalry; but greater was the Triumph at Court, for there the King, Queen, and all the Nobilitys Armes were open to receive them; and when the Prince≈øs Flerida beheld her Lord, from whom cruel Fortune had ≈øo long divorced her, ≈øhe ran into his Armes, and ≈øunk down in a≈øwound, but he rai≈øed his beautious Love, as dear to him as Life, comforting her in the be≈øt manner, promi≈øing to make amends for the defects of envious Fortune, and ≈øo with many kind ki≈ø≈øes and embraces revived her fading ≈øpirits; when as a ≈øumptuous Fea≈øt was made, accomodated with odoriferious Perfumes, and melodies of Mu≈øick, nor was the night Crowned with le≈øs Iollitry of Ma≈øque-Dancing, and each rare delight; when in the morning the King determined to ≈øend a Power, to overthrow the Ca≈øtle of Dramu≈øiand, and utterly rai≈øe it; but the Princes interceding on his behalf, and
declaring the kind u≈øage they had received at his hands, the King was content to lay a≈øide his purpo≈øe, yet was he greatly de≈øirous to ≈øee him, promi≈øing, notwith≈øtanding the trouble he had put the whole Nation (nay all Europe) to, he would, upon his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, grant him a Pardon: Whereupon Sir Pridos and four other Knights were ≈øent to fetch him, having the Kings Letter for his ≈øafe conduct, upon notice of which leaving the Ca≈øtle in the Cu≈øtody of his Brother Pandare, he accompanied them to the Court, where (at the in≈øtance of the Princes) he, upon his ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion, was received into favour, and had the order of Knighthood conferred upon him.

While≈øt this Iollitry la≈øted, Trineus the German Emperor, with his Empre≈øs, arrived in England, to compleat the general Ioy, and were received with all re≈øpect and reverance, and for their better entertainment, a Turnament was ordained, wherein none but young Knights ≈øhould try their Valour; and ≈øo well was all things managed, that they afforded high ≈øatisfaction to the ≈øpectators.

div.head: CHAP. XXVII.

argument.p: How a ≈øecond Turnament was held by the Prince; And of the Adventure of three ≈øtrange Knights, who proved to be the Sage Aliart, the Knight of the Savage-Man, and Pompides: And how it was made known, that Palmerin and Florian the Knight of the Savage-Man, were the Sons of Don Edoard and Flerida.

div.p:
THe fir≈øt days Turnament having been performed with applau≈øe, it was re≈øolved among≈øt, the Princes, That in Honour of their re≈øpectivee Countries, a Turnament might be held among≈øt them, to which the King according, all things were put in a readine≈øs, and the place prepared; the Knights bravely mounted, entered the Li≈øt, and divided into two Partys, the one ≈øtiling them≈øelves the Engli≈øh,
and the other the Grecian Knights; whereupon they ran their cour≈øes with various ≈øucce≈øs, in≈øomuch, that many a couragious Hero was tumbled on the ground; but in this Turnament was neither the Princes Edoard, Primalion, nor Palmerin. When as they having ≈øtrove long, and tho≈øe of the Engli≈øh part being in a manner put back, three ≈øtrange Knights came in, and did ≈øuch wonders, that unhor≈øing all they met, the intirely re≈øtored the Turnament, when as the Grecian Knights went to wrack on all ≈øides, lying on the ground, both Hor≈øe and Man; which the King perceiving, (lea≈øt that friendly Diver≈øion ≈øhould create Emulation, and be the ground of future Quarrels) he cau≈øed the Retreat to be ≈øounded on either ≈øide, all the ≈øpectators highly applauding the Courage of the three Knights, and were as de≈øirous to know them: Nor was it long e're it was made known who they were, viz. The Knight of the Savage-Man, (who had been by Sage Aliart recovered of his wounds) Pompides, and the Sage, who in his Youthful days addicted him≈øelf wholly to Feats of Arms; upon this news the Ioy was redoubled, fora≈ømuch as the Knight of Fortune had declared Florian, the Knight of the Savage-Man, who was ≈øuppo≈øed to be dead of his wounds, to be his Brother; ≈øo that the Triumphs were renewed, and all the Tables ≈øpread for ≈øuch as would be at the entertainment. When amid≈øt the Iollitry, Sage Aliart taking the King by the hand, lead him into the Pre≈øence-Chamber, promi≈øing to reveal ≈øuch a ≈øecret, as ≈øhould greatly rejoice him; when being there, he intreated him, that he would ≈øend for the Queen, Prince Edoard, the Prince≈øs Flerida, Primalion, and the Knights of Fortune and of the Savage-Man, which being accordingly done, he took the two later by the hands, and leading them to Prince Edoard and his Prince≈øs, ≈øaid: Behold, you Royal pair, the Noble I≈ø≈øue of your Happy Wedlock: The≈øe are the Princes, who in their Infant≈øie were taken from the Prince≈ø≈øes Tent, and have been ever ≈øince pre≈øerved as the pledges of Fortune, and the Honour of Knighthood. This unexpected di≈øcovery cau≈øed ≈øo great amazement, that the like before had not happened; nor could it gain belief, till he had related all the pa≈ø≈øages, from time to
time, how they were ≈ønatched away, and nouri≈øhed by the appointment of a Savage-Man, who dwelt in the Unfortunate Forre≈øt; and the better to confirm the truth, he had cau≈øed to be brought thither (by his Art) the Wild-Man, and by Spells ≈øo allayed his wildne≈øs, that he was become calm: This man (by the Kings Command) being introduced, ≈øtareing round about him, and at length e≈øyying the Princes, ran to them and embraced them with ≈øuch fervent affection, that he wanted words to expre≈øs it; after which, the Sage Aliart commanded him to relate to the Royal A≈ø≈øembly, from the fir≈øt to the la≈øt, what had befell them, which he accordingly did, with ≈øuch a feeling ≈øence of ≈øorrow, for the lo≈øs of their company, that he confirmed the Auditory in the truth of what was ≈øaid; whereupon the King ordered he ≈øhould live in the City, and have an hundred Mark a year for his maintenance, but he (more de≈øirous to continue his ≈øavage life, and ≈øpend the remainder of his days in ≈øolitarine≈øs) refu≈øed the offer, and obtained leave to depart, having fir≈øt ≈øeen and embraced his Son Sylvan, whom he recommended to the King and the Princes pre≈øent.

Vpon this di≈øcovery the Prince≈øs Flerida embraced her ≈øons with tears of Ioy, as likewi≈øe did the Prince her Husband, and they (as in ≈øubmi≈ø≈øive duty bound) humbled them≈øelves at their feet, when being rai≈øed, they were embraced by all pre≈øent, and Proclamation made of their Birth, Names, and Parentage, which cau≈øed the City to ring with acclamations, ≈øo that no triumph was ever more compleat, after ≈øo long Misfortunes and Anxiety.

div.head: CHAP. XXVIII.

argument.p: How the King and his Nobles, together with their Ladies, pa≈ø≈øed to ≈øee the Ca≈øtle where the Knights had been captivated; And of the ≈øtrange Adventures they met with.

div.p: THe Ioy of the Court being dayly heightened with ≈øo many happy di≈øcoveries, and the Triumph being pretty well over, it was re≈øolved, that (to plea≈øe the Ladies) they ≈øhould be attended to take a view of the Ca≈øtle, where the Knights had been confined, and in order thereto all nece≈ø≈øaries, as Provi≈øion, Pavillions, Hor≈øes, Armour, &c. were provided, and ≈øent before; ≈øo that the fir≈øt night they pitched by the River where the Prince≈øs Flerida re≈øided, when the unhappy misfortune befell her ≈øelf, her Lord, and her Children, when delighted with the change of Fortune, ≈øhe was greatly de≈øirous to ≈øee the Cave, wherein her Royal Offspring was nouri≈øhed, which ≈øhe ≈øignifying to her Lord, he con≈øented to ≈øatisfie her therein; and the next morning they were conducted thither by Aliart, where they found the Savage-Man, who perceiving them, came forth, and ca≈øt him≈øelf at their feet, when as the Prince rai≈øing him, he opened wide the doors, which di≈øcovered many ≈øpacious Roomes, hung round with the Skins of Bea≈øts, ≈øo that entering, they found it contrived Labyrinth-wi≈øe, with many goodly Lights, de≈øcending through Thickets of Bu≈øhes, that could not be di≈øcerned above, and upon inquiry, found it to be the Cave of the Inchantre≈øs Mellia, who left it at her decea≈øe to her Son, and he not (from his Infant≈øie) under≈øtanding Civility lived wild in the Wood with his Si≈øter‚ñ™ on whom he begat Sylvan, but would not practi≈øe. Inchantments, being affrighted therefrom in his Youth, by the appearance of ugly Spirits; yet ≈øo ≈øtout was he, that all the wild Bea≈øts trembled at his pre≈øence.

The ≈øatisfaction above≈øaid being had, the Princes and Ladys
returned to their Pavillions, and from thence ≈øet forward toward the Ca≈øtle of Dramu≈øiand; when coming within ≈øight of it, as they began to admire the ≈øtateline≈øs of its building, they beheld a Knight, attended only with one E≈øquire, bravely mounted, and well appointed at Arms, ≈øtanding before the Bridge, which made them marvel, e≈øpecially by rea≈øon he was not then known; in his Shield he bore the Portraicture of a beautious Lady naked, which appeared ≈øo lovely, that Venus Picture, drawn by Appelles, could not compare to it. This Knight, as the glorious Train approached, ≈øent his E≈øquire to inform them, that he having heard wonders, of the Inchanted Ca≈øtle, for his Ladys ≈øake had left his Country, to try the Adventure, but finding the Inchantment di≈ø≈øolv'd, he would not return, if he could otherways help it, without a Wreath of Lawrel, therefore made it his Reque≈øt, that if any Knight e≈øteemed his Lady, and would maintain her Beauty, he would Iu≈øt with him. This Challenge was ≈øoon accepted, and every one ≈øtrove who ≈øhould fir≈øt enterprize the matter; but Prince Floriman being neare≈øt, and having his Spear in his Re≈øt, got the ≈øtart of the re≈øt, ≈øo that ru≈øhing furiou≈øly together the Prince was di≈ømounted, whereat Berolde advanced, but had the like misfortune, as al≈øo had divers others, until it came to Florians turn, who in the careir overthrew the Knight; whereupon in great anger he departed, ≈øuppo≈øing none had known him; but the Sage Aliart di≈øcovered him, and who the Lady was, as followeth.

May it plea≈øe this Noble Company; The Knight you have ≈øeen is of Noble Decent, and his Name is Don Bonoricadius, who travelling into Spain, had a view of a beautious Lady, Daughter to Prince Arlae, called Miragarda, who≈øe perfections ≈øo inthralled him, that he vowed to accompli≈øh her de≈øire; whereupon ≈øhe injoyned him to fini≈øh the Adventure of the Inchanted Ca≈øtle, which he undertook; but finding it ready done to his hand, was greatly di≈øplea≈øed; wherefore that he might not return without any Adventure, he de≈øired the Combat with ≈øome of this Company.

This being known, they were highly ≈øatisfied, and thereupon
in good order entered the Ca≈øtle, which they found builded in a ≈øtately manner, repleni≈øhed every where with Gardens, Fi≈øh-Ponds, Dove-hou≈øes, and plea≈øant Fountains; when having Fea≈øted there in the be≈øt manner, they left it to the Charge of Dramu≈øiand, and departed; when by the way the Sage Aliart conducted them to his Man≈øion, where by his Art he ≈øhewed them ≈øuch rare Devices, as highly plea≈øed them; for at once he rai≈øed Fountains of Water, and ≈øtately Bowers, covered with clu≈øtering Vines, and accomodated with all Rich Banquets, the Trees di≈øtiling every where odoriferious Gums, and the Birds warbling their ≈øweet Notes, then divers airy Phantomes danced to an invi≈øible Harmony; and ≈øo delighted were they with this Recreation, that they ≈øtayed two days, at the end of which they departed.

When as divers of the Princes, de≈øirous to ≈øee their own Countries, e≈øpecially by rea≈øon they had notice that commotions were ri≈øen among≈øt their Subjects, they ≈øolemnly took their leaves and departed, declaring in all places what had happened, by which means the ≈øorrowful Pandritia had notice of Don Edoard's deliverance and welfare; wherefore hoping that ≈øhe might again injoy his company, ≈øhe left her Ca≈øtle, called The Hou≈øe of Mourning, ≈øcituate in the Tri≈øtful Valley, and betook her to one more plea≈øant, called The Garden of Virgins.

div.head: CHAP. XXIX.

argument.p: How Primalion (≈øeeking Adventures) met the Knight he encountered before Dramu≈øiand's Ca≈øtle, who proved to be his Son Flor ‚Ä¢ ndos, and of the combat he had with him: How they left the Man≈øion of Pandritia, the one returning towards Con≈øtantinople, the other towards Spain: How the Soldian Bellagris certified the Emperor Palmerin of the Treachery of the Soldian of Babylon.

div.p:
PRince Primalion having taking his leave, pa≈ø≈øed the Seas, and travelled ≈øo long, that arriving in Lacedemonia, he happened on the Tri≈øtful Valley, where the ≈øorrowful Pandritia dwelt, at the entrance of which he beheld a Knight
≈øitting under a Cypre≈øs Tree, greatly bewailing him≈øelf, when drawing near, he li≈øtened, and heard him complaining to the Portraicture of his beautiful Mi≈øtri≈øs in the≈øe words:

Divine≈øt Creature, how have you captivated my Heart! how have your Beautious Eyes ≈øhot Beams of Love into my Soul, and made me all o're tran≈øport! Yet you know not your power, nor the Fever that I indure, but may, when I have proved my ≈øelf worthy of ≈øo much Felicity: O my Miragarda! well thou art ≈øtiled The Mirrour and Perfection of Beauty, that with one look could captivate a Soul like mine. And here he ended with many ≈øighs; whereupon Primalion, who had ≈øtood all this while un≈øeen, advancing, ≈øaluted him and de≈øired him to de≈øi≈øt and relinqui≈øh ≈øuch vain pa≈ø≈øion; which ≈øo inraged the Knight, that he hid him defiance, and having his Hor≈øe at hand, mounted, upon which both couching their Spears ran furiou≈øly at each other, in≈øomuch, that they were both unhor≈øed; when drawing their Swords, they encountered with great fury, giving to each other many grievous wounds, ≈øo that in the end Primalions Helmet unbuckling, fell off, upon which he being di≈øcovered to his Son the Prince Florendos, he ca≈øt down his Sword, and falling at his feet, begged his pardon, and confe≈ø≈øed an intire ≈øorrow for oppo≈øing, through ignorance, his Princely Father; Primalion hearing this, and perceiving the Knight he fought with to be his Son Florendos, rai≈øed him from the ground in his Armes, and embraced him, greatly rejoycing he had found in him ≈øuch haughty courage. Then want they to the Ca≈øtle of the ≈øorrowful Lady, who upon notice of what they were, came down and ≈øaluted them, in loving wife, cau≈øing her Damo≈øels to dre≈øs their wounds, and inquired after divers Knights, but above all after Don Edoard, for who≈øe ≈øake ≈øhe had betaken her ≈øelf to that ≈øolitary manner of living.

To the Reque≈øt of the Lady, Prince Primalion an≈øwered, That the Adventure of the Unfortunate Ca≈øtle was fini≈øhed, and that the Knights that had long been impri≈øoned therein, were fat at liberty; and among≈øt the re≈øt, Prince Don Edoard, in ≈øearch of whom ≈øo many Knights had left their Country;
and that he at pre≈øent flouri≈øhed in his Father's Court, in the embraces of the fair Flerida. This news greatly revived the ≈øorrowful Lady, who ≈øaid ≈øhe joyed in nothing more than to hear of the Princes ≈øafety, whom ≈øhe long ≈øince ≈øuppo≈øed to have been dead, though he had proved mo≈øt unkind to her, in leaving her after ≈øhe had fixed on him an unalterable love; yet ≈øtace there were ≈øome hopes left that ≈øhe might once more ≈øee him, ≈øhe would from thence forward mitigate her grief; And ≈øo, ≈øoon after the Prince's departure, ≈øhe betook her ≈øelf to the Garden of Virgins, a place ≈øo called for its plea≈øant ≈øcituation.

The Princes (cured of their wounds) in a re≈øpectful manner took their leaves of each other, as al≈øo of the Ladies, the one for Con≈øtantinople, and the other for Spain, where his fair Miragarda re≈øided. Prince Primalion riding through divers Countries, without meeting with any Adventure, at length arrived at the Fanous City of Con≈øtantinople, which in the evening he entered Incognito, and continued till the next morning, at what time he gave notice to the Secretarys, that they ≈øhould inform the Emperor, that a Knight arrived from the Court of England, was de≈øirous to wait upon him; this known, the Emperor greatly rejoyced, fora≈ømuch as he had not heard from thence of a long time; yet Primalion keeping his Helmet cla≈øp'd, delayed to di≈øcover his knowledge, till ≈øuch time as the Empre≈øs Gridona and all the Ladies were pre≈øent, who being immediately ≈øent for, and greatly de≈øirous to hear the long expected news, the Prince declared from point to point all that had happened, and above all, how Palmerin, who fini≈øhed the Adventure; was Son to Don Edoard and his Daughter Flerida. Then the Emperor earne≈øtly inquired after his Son Primalion, ≈øaying he could have no re≈øt ≈øince his departure; whereupon the Prince, loath to ≈øuffer his Father longer to grieve, pulled off his Helmet, and di≈øcovered him≈øelf, to the Ioy of all pre≈øent, and of the whole Empire.

But long it had not continued, e're a Me≈ø≈øenger came from the Soldian Bellagris with Letters-Credentials, to inform the Emperor, that the Soldian of Babylon (at the in≈øtigation of Eutrope the Inchantre≈øs) had leavyed a great Army to invade
the Imperial Territories, but had been diverted by ≈øome of his own Subjects, who cau≈øed a mutiny, by rea≈øon of the exce≈ø≈øive Taxes he had rai≈øed on that occa≈øion; therefore he advi≈øed his Maje≈øty to be upon his Guard.

This occa≈øioned no little con≈øternation in the Court; but in con≈øideration the Princes were relea≈øed, and upon their re-return, the mo≈øt Valiant rather de≈øired a War than feared it; yet preparation were made on all hands, not only defen≈øive, but offen≈øive.

div.head: CHAP. XXX.

argument.p: How Florendos became Amorous of the Lady Miragarda: And what Adventures befell Prince Palmerin, upon his ≈øecond departure out of England.

div.p:
FLorendos (before mentioned to be the Son of Primalion) upon notice of his Fathers being lo≈øt in the Forre≈øt of Great Brittain, leaving Con≈øtantinople, and by cro≈øs Winds being driven upon the Coa≈øt of Spain, travelling by a Forre≈øt-≈øide, at length came within ≈øight of a fair Ca≈øtle, to which he purpo≈øed to go; but as he was pa≈ø≈øing on in a fair Arbour, under a Tuft of Trees he e≈øpied divers Ladies, tuneing their Voices to melodious Lutes; when among≈øt the re≈øt, one appeared more lovely than Venus or Diana, which made ≈øuch an Impre≈ø≈øion in his ≈øoul, that pouring out his pa≈ø≈øion to him≈øelf, he ≈øtood like a lifele≈øs Statue, not daring to approach them; ≈øo that being un≈øeen of them, he kept his po≈øt, till ≈øuch time as they ari≈øing from their ≈øhady Bower, entered the Ca≈øtle, the which when they had done, he followed, but found the Gates fa≈øt clo≈øed, which made him repent his ba≈øhfulne≈øs; but ca≈øting his eyes about, he in the end e≈øpyed a Shield hanging upon a Tree, with the Portraicture of the beautiful Lady he had ≈øeen, ≈øo lively painted, that it ≈øeemed to want nothing but Life and Motion, and under it in Golden Letters MIRAGARDA,
with this Motto: Let the Takers beware: But he had ≈øcarce time to view it, when Almorol a mon≈øtrous Gyant approached, and bid him defiance, at which the Knight (little daunted) drew his Sword, and fought with him ≈øo long, that the Gyant through wounds and lo≈øs of blood fainted; when as he was about to ≈øtand upon him to ≈øtrike off his Head, the Gates of the inner Court opened, and out of them i≈ø≈øued the Lady he before had ≈øeen, with her beautious train, and ≈øhreiking bade him hold his hand, who not being able to deny her (on whom his heart was ≈øo firmly fixed) any thing, de≈øi≈øted, and laying down his ≈øword, kneeled at her feet, begging her leave to love her and be her Knight, which ≈øhe granted, and gently rai≈øed him up; then he intreated her to tell him how ≈øhe came thither, and for what cau≈øe the Ca≈øtle was guarded by that Gyant; (to which ≈øhe con≈øented, provided he would help to carry the Gyant into the Ca≈øtle, who≈øe reque≈øt he readily obeyed.

The Gyant being in the Ca≈øtle and committed to her Damo≈øels, to cure his wounds, ≈øhe ≈øate down by Prince Florendos, and ≈øaid: Sir Knight, ≈øeeing your demands are ju≈øt, I an≈øwer you; That I am Daughter to Prince Arlae, a Prince of Spain, and was brought up in the Court of King Recinde, till the Nobility fell at ≈øtrife for me, and fought many mortal Battails; when to prevent farther mi≈øchief, my father committed me to the cu≈øtody of this Gyant, till his further plea≈øure is known, who was never foiled before; my picture you have upon the Shield, which you may bear for my ≈øake; and if you can fini≈øh the Adventure of Great Brittain, or any other Noble Exploit, I am at your devotion. This fireing the Prince, made him vow to her the future ≈øervice of his life: But leaving him a while, I ≈øhall return to Prince Palmerin.

The Adventure being fini≈øhed by the Noble Prince Palmerin, and he having obtained leave of his Father and Mother, and of the Aged King Frederick, re≈øolved to leave England, in ≈øearch of new Adventures; when pa≈ø≈øing the Seas with his E≈øquire, he came (after a long travel) into a de≈øolate Valley, where he found a Knight lye wounded, without any attendance,
which not a little moved him to know the Adventure, when to his amazement he found it to be Prince Gracian, who informed him, that he having fought again≈øt a Troop of Kis. and Gyants, in defence of two Ladies they were ha ‚Ä¢ ing to a Ca≈øtle, not far di≈øtant thence, it fortuned as he fell, Platire and Floriman came, who having notice of what had happened, ≈øwiftly pur≈øued the Varlets. Vpon this news Prince Palmerin left his E≈øquire with his Cozen Gratian, and followed hard after them, where when he came, he found the Knights combating with the Gyant Dramacon and his Companions, having ≈ølain divers of them; wherefore the Prince, not to defer the matter, ≈øeeing his friends ≈øore wounded, ran with his Spear at the Gyant, and overthrew him; then drawing his dreadful blade, he ≈øo layed about him, that at every ≈øtroke one or other died, or fell much wounded, which made the Ladies tremble and look pale; when by this time Prince Gracian having gotten a Sword of Sylvan, and mounted on his Hor≈øe, came (feeble as he was) to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his Friends, Revenge in≈øpiring him with Courage; ≈øo that Dramacon and mo≈øt of his men being ≈ølain, tho≈øe that remained begged their lives on their knees, excu≈øing them≈øelves on the compul≈øion of the Tyrant their Ma≈øter, and by that means obtained (at the intreaty of the Ladies) their pardons; when entering the Ca≈øtle, they found only two old women, whom they they ≈øpared; then ≈øetting it on Fire, they departed in the company of the Ladys, who ≈øtraying in the Woods, had been ≈øurprized by the Tyrant Dramacon.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI.

argument.p: How Palmerin ≈øailing towards Con≈øtantinople, was by Storm driven upon a ≈øtrange I≈øland: And of the ≈øtrange Adventures he met with, contained in his Fight with Wild Bea≈øts and many fearful Mon≈øters.

div.p:
THe Prince having left his three Companions to conduct the Ladies to the Ca≈øtle of their Mother the Lady Diame≈øia, rode to the Sea-≈øide, where he found a Ship ready to ≈øet Sayl, on which imbarquing, together with Sylvan, he ≈øayled before the Wind towards Con≈øtantinople; when about midnight ≈øuch a Tempe≈øt aro≈øe, that all Creation ≈øeemed unhinged, which in ≈øpight of the Ma≈øter drove the Ve≈ø≈øel upon a ≈øtrange I≈øland, where Landing, he could perceive no Inhabitant, which occa≈øioned him to walk on foot for recreation, the ≈øtorm being now allayed: But far he had not gone, e'r entring a fair Medow, he e≈øpyed a Pillar of Ia≈øper, on which was engraven, Take heed thou pa≈øs no farther this way: at which the Prince marvelling, and not ≈øeeing any to let him, re≈øolved not to ≈øuffer his courage to faint, but on he went, till coming to a Tuft of Trees, under who≈øe ≈øpreading Branches he e≈øpyed a plea≈øant Fountain, ≈øpouting Waters as clear as Cry≈øtal out of the mouthes of many Bea≈øts of dreadful form, Artificially engraven in Marble, and clo≈øe behind it live Dragons, Lyons and Tygers chained which ≈øomewhat apaled him; when looking about he e≈øpyed a Pillar, with Letters of Gold engraven thereon, viz. Behold the Fountain of the wi≈øhed Water: and near to that another, with this in≈øcription: He that hath the Courage to drink of this Fountain, ≈øhall bring to pa≈øs any Enterprize of Honour and Fame; but over again≈øt it was likewi≈øe engraven the≈øe words: Pa≈øs, and drink not. The≈øe In≈øcriptions made the Prince mu≈øe with him≈øelf what it ≈øhould mean, yet in the and he re≈øolved to try the Adventure; wherefore
taking courage, he drew his Sword, and pa≈ø≈øed towards the Fountain, when as the cruel wild Bea≈øts ≈ølipping their Chains at will, furiou≈øly with≈øtood him and in ≈øpight of all his force, plucking his Shield from him, ≈øorely rent his Armour with their Claws; yet furiou≈øly laying about him, he in the end brought them ≈øo under, that ≈øome he flew, and others being wounded, fled with hideous crys into an adjacent Grove, of whom he never after heard; whereupon pa≈ø≈øing to the Fountain, he took up the Water in his Helmet, and having therewith refre≈øhed him≈øelf, followed the path, which brought him to a fair Ca≈øtle, before which ≈øtood four Pillars, and on them four Shields; when going to the fir≈øt of them, he found engraven on it the≈øe words, viz. No Man dare conceive the courage to take me down; but he not ≈øtanding to complement, (having before re≈øolved to fini≈øh the Adventure or lo≈øe his life) ≈ønatched it from its place; whereupon the Gates flew open, and out came a Knight on foot, ≈øtrangely Armed, ≈øpeaking many big words to the Prince, but he nothing di≈ømayed, prepared to receive him, when as a fearful combate began between them, but in the end the Prince prevailed, and layed the Knight for dead. When going to the ≈øecond Shield, he found engraven thereon the≈øe words, viz. I am more perilous, and therefore worthy to be feared, for in me con≈ø ‚Ä¢ ≈øteth the greate≈øt danger; but not ≈øtanding to pau≈øe, he drew it from its place, as he had done the former; when as a ≈øecond Knight advanced, with a dreadful countenance, demanding how he dur≈øt remove the Shield, for which pre≈øumption nought but his life could make ≈øatisfaction; but the Prince (not to be out-dared) ≈øtanding upon his guard, bid him come on, ≈øo that a fierce combate in≈øued, whereas either received wounds, but in the end the Prince forcibly ≈øtriking him on the Head, his Helmet flew in pieces, and the Sword entering, down he fell dead upon the ground. Then going to the third Shield, he found thereon engraved, By me is to be gotten the Honour of this Adventure; yet without any Ceremony, down he rent it; whereupon the third Knight advanced with many dreadful menaces, but ≈øoon was queli'd.

The Prince ≈øuppo≈øing the other Shield would fini≈øh the Adventure,
boldly ≈øtepped to it, to have the ≈øooner done, when he found engraven on it, In me remaineth the Happy Victory, which he ≈øoon took down, and prepared to encounter the fourth Knight, which after a long and dreadful Fight he did. And now being tyred, he re≈øted him a while, and then entered the Ca≈øtle, where ≈øuppo≈øing he had no more to deal with, he unexpectedly found a mon≈øtrous Gyant, armed in a Coat of Mael, who with a Battail-Ax in his hand, came in with great fury again≈øt him, but the Prince in a place of danger ever ≈øtanding upon his Guard, avoiding his ≈øtroke, ≈ømote him on the head ≈øo fiercely, that redoubling his blow, he brought him to the ground and ≈ømote off his Head; when as he heard a lamentable voice, proceeding from a Woman, following the Direction of which, he came to a place, where he found two Knights cooped in an Iron Cage, whom he delivered, and found to be Baziliart and German of Orleance, who had been taken Pri≈øoners in attempting the Adventure, and greatly rejoyced at ≈øuch their happy deliverance, for that the Gyant every day threatned them with death and had in his fury ≈ølain divers Knights of the Emperors Court, who were driven in by Tempe≈øt, and had e≈ø≈øayed to fini≈øh the Adventure.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII.

argument.p: How the Ship (upon the Prince's Landing) was driven to the contrary Shoar; And how divers Knights upon knowledge of what had happened, went in ≈øearch of him.

div.p:
SO it happened, that the Prince was no ≈øooner on ≈øhoar, but the Wind ≈øuddenly turning about, the Cable whereby the Ship was fa≈øtened to the Rocky ≈øhoar, broke, and it (e'r any could land) drove to Sea, where, after many days uncertain ≈øayling, they came to the ≈øelf≈øame Port from which they brought the Prince; whereat Sylvan greatly bewailed the ab≈øence of his Lord, acquainting all
Knights he met with what had befallen him, which cau≈øed divers to go in ≈øearch of him, as they had done of Don Edoard, his Father; during which time, he was fini≈øhing the great Adventure: For having freed the Knights, he ≈øtill followed the Female voice, till pa≈ø≈øing up many ≈øtairs, and through divers ≈øpacious Roomes, at length he e≈øpyed upon the Pinacle of the Ca≈øtle, a Woman ≈øtanding, with di≈ølevell'd Hair, exclaiming in this manner: Wretched me! How have the fates deceived me, who thought by my Art to have accompli≈øhed my Revenge, for the Death of my Brother Frenaque, but now have been twice foiled by one and the ≈øame Knight, therefore I will no longer keep this hated breath; and with that crying out‚ñ™ I come ye Furies, ≈øpirits of Eternal Night; ≈øhe ca≈øt her ≈øelf headlong into the Lake that was on that ≈øide the Ca≈øtle, and there ≈øunk like Lead, ending there her wicked life.

The Prince, by what he had heard‚ñ™ knowing her to be Eutrope the Inchantre≈øs, was ≈øatisfied that the Adventure was fini≈øhed; and ≈øo taking leave of the two Knights he found there, was about to return to his Ship, when as he ≈øaw two Knights riding towards him, which made him doubt there was more work to do; but he was ≈øoon undeceived, by knowing them to be Francian and Oni≈øtalde, who greatly rejoyced to have found him, and more that the Adventure was fini≈øhed; and he by that means knew what had happened to the Ve≈ø≈øel he left at Author, and how he had lo≈øt his Hor≈øe and E≈øquire, yet re≈øolved to leave that Perilous I≈øland, and pa≈øs the Seas in the Ship tho≈øe Knights had brought, which he accordingly did, and having a good for-wind, arrived upon the Coa≈øt of Spain, which made the Prince de≈øirous to have a v ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of the fair Miragarda, of who≈øe Fame ≈øo much had been blazed ‚Ä¢ broad.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII.

argument.p: How Prince Palmerin arriving at the Ca≈øtle of Almorol the Gyant, overcame the Tri≈øtful Knight; And what el≈øe hapned: How Dramu≈øiand arrived there, and overcame Almorol, &c.

div.p: PRince Palmerin, after long travel, arrived at the wi≈øhed Ca≈øtle, where he perceived a Knight bravely mounted, ready to receive him; when coming near to each other, they ran with ≈øuch fury, that both of them fell to the ground; when drawing their Swords, they charged upon each other with great courage and bravery, neither re≈øolving to yield, ≈øo that their Armour (≈øhattered by the forcible ≈øtroaks) fell peice-meal to the Earth, and in the end (through lo≈øs of blood) the Tri≈øtful Knight gave back, not being able longer to maintain the combat; whereupon the proud Lady (though he had expre≈ø≈øed his manhood to a high degree, and been victorious till that time) ≈øent to demand his Shield, and charge him to depart the Ca≈øtle; to who≈øe commands (though with a heavy heart) he yielded obedience, and with a mournful countenance departed to the adjacent Valley with his E≈øquire Armillo, and there uttered many heavy complaints, that might have melted Marble to relent; but the ambitious Lady, though ≈øhe had notice thereof, would not re≈øtore him to her favour; wherefore ≈øending his E≈øquire (who was greatly unwilling to leave him in that condition) every where to proclaim his death, he betook him≈øelf to the ≈øolitary company of a Shepherd, who fod his Flocks in the Flowery Vales; where for a while I ≈øhall leave him.

Prince Palmerin having obtained this, the Shield was offered him, but he refu≈øed it, re≈øolving in that nature to defend no Beauty, but that of his fair, Mi≈øtri≈øs Polinarda; wherefore having taken leave of the Lady, he departed towards Con≈øtantinople.

Long it was not after the departure of the Prince, e're Dramu≈øiand
the Gyant having notice of the Prince's lo≈øs in the Perilous I≈øland, came in ≈øearch of him, and ≈øo travelled, that he fortuned to happen on the Ca≈øtle of Almorol, where he found that Gyant ≈øtanding before it, with the Shield that ≈øhe had given him upon the Prince's refu≈øal; whereupon after defiance bid, a dreadful combat happened between tho≈øe Mon≈øters of Men, but in the end Dramu≈øiand (who had been trained up in Feats of Arms from his Youth) prevailed, yet at the Ladys reque≈øt ≈øpared Almorol's life, and had the Shield be≈øtowed on him, which he accepted and became her Champion, upon notice that the Prince had fini≈øhed the Adventure of the Perilous I≈øle, and was returned in ≈øafety.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIV.

argument.p: How Dramu≈øiand combated Don Rou≈øel and Prince Gracian; And how Prince Palmerin falling a≈øleep in a plea≈øant Valley, was bound by four Ladies, and carryed to their Ca≈øtle: How Don Florian intreated the King, on the behalf of the Ladies he had delivered from Calfurnine the Gyant; And how they were re≈øtored to their Inheritance: How taking leave of his Father, he arrived at Miragarda's Ca≈øtle, where he combated Dramu≈øiand; And how in the combat they came to the knowledge of each other, and were reconciled.

div.p:
DRamu≈øiand had not long kept the Shield e'r Prince Gracian and Don Rou≈øel ≈øeeking Adventures, came before the Ca≈øtle, and under≈øtanding the cu≈øtom, Prince Gracian prepared him≈øelf for the combat; whereupon a ≈øharp conflict began between them, in≈øomuch that the Prince's Helmet was bur≈øt, and fell from his Head, which gave Dramu≈øiand opportunity to know him when laying a≈øide his ≈øword, he cryed, Hold my friend Gracian, I am Dramu≈øiand; whereupon they all three embraced each other, which made the Lady Miragarda, who was a ≈øpectator of the combat, greatly wonder: Then began they to di≈øcour≈øe of divers affairs, but above all of the Adventure of the
Ca≈øtle, and what the Prince Palmerin had atchieved in the perilous I≈øland; and ≈øo after divers di≈øcour≈øes the Knights pa≈ø≈øed on, to overtake the Prince, and the Gyant remained to guard the Ca≈øtle.

The Prince Plamerin riding alone, having lo≈øt his E≈øquire in the Adventure of the perilous I≈øland, at length came to a plea≈øant Valley, over-≈øhaddowed with Trees, and enamelled with fragrant Flowers, where repo≈øing his weary Limbs, he unloo≈øed his Helmet, and fell into a ≈ølumber; at what time came four Ladies, who kept a Ca≈øtle not far di≈øtant, who beholding his rare perfections, one of them became ≈øo enamour'd of him, that ≈øhe per≈øwaded the re≈øt to a≈ø≈øi≈øt her in conveying him into the Ca≈øtle; which being agreed on, the better to do it, they ≈øprinkled an Inchanted Iuice over him, which ca≈øt him into a dead ≈øleep, then binding him hand and foot, they conveyed him to their Rocky Man≈øion, and layed him on a Couch, fea≈øting their eyes with his Beauty and War-like ≈øhape, till at la≈øt the Charm being fini≈øhed, he awoke, and looking round about him, found him≈øelf invironed with beautiful Ladies, whereat being ≈øomewhat aba≈øhed, he began to excu≈øe his ≈øluggi≈øhne≈øs; but attempting to ari≈øe, found him≈øelf fa≈øt bound, which made him begin to ≈øu≈øpect ≈øome treachery; when as the mo≈øt beautiful among≈øt them addre≈ø≈øed her ≈øelf to him in this ≈øort:

Sir, you have wounded a Virgins heart ≈øo deep, that nothing but your Love (or Death) can cure the Fevour ≈øhe indures. Alas (replyed the Prince) fair Lady, you ≈øpeak ≈øo my≈øterious, I under≈øtand you not. Nay Sir, (≈øaid ≈øhe) if you are a worthy Knight, as you ≈øeem, you cannot but be ≈øen≈øible of my meaning, Know then, That (breaking the Rules of Mode≈øty) I am the Virgin you have wounded, and unle≈øs you grant me your Love, I mu≈øt langui≈øh and dye, ≈øo irre≈øi≈øtible is the flame that has ≈øurprized me. Forbid it Heaven, that any Virgin ≈øhould dye for me (replyed the Prince); but as for my love in that way, Madam, 'tis the only thing I cannot grant, becau≈øe it prepo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed; the Lady on whom my affections are linked, though di≈øtant from hence, ≈øo charms my heart, that except her fair ≈øelf none can have entrance. Vpon
this the „Äà‚óä„Äâ one ≈øelf into a great pa≈ø≈øion, weeping bitterly, and ≈øtill „Äà‚Ä¶„Äâ pre≈øence, whereupon two Gyants entered, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Prince, conveying him to a deep ‚Ä¢ ungeon; where for a while I mu≈øt leave him bewailing his ≈øluggi≈øhne≈øs, and return to Prince Florian, ≈øo lately known by the Title of The knight of the Savage-Man.

Prince Florian, as yet remaining in the Court of King Frederick, beg ‚Ä¢ n to call to mind the three Ladies that were in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Gyant Calfurnine, whom he delivered, and thereupon related that Adventure to the King, making it his reque≈øt, that they might be ≈øent for to the Engli≈øh Court, and be re≈øtored to their Father's Inheritance, which (for ≈øome high misdemeanour by him committed) had been ≈øeque≈øtred; to which reque≈øt the King conde≈øcending, they were brought over and entertained by the Queen; when as their beauties grew into ≈øuch great e≈øteem, that within ≈øhort time they were all marryed to per≈øons of Honour.

The Prince, grown impatient of ea≈øe, made it his ≈øecond reque≈øt, that he might depart in ≈øearch of new Adventures; but long was it e're he could get leave, yet at length he prevailed; and cro≈ø≈øing the Seas, travelled ≈øo long that he arrived at the Ca≈øtle of Miragarda, and there encountered with the Gyant Dramu≈øiand, but after a hard skir ‚Ä¢ ≈øh they knew each other by their voices, and ≈øo de≈øi≈øted, the Conque≈øt falling to neither ≈øide, which made the Lady Miraga ‚Ä¢ da wonder more than before: Yet after they had embraced, the Prince having notice from Sylvan that his Brother was Pri≈øoner, left Dramu≈øiand, and accompanyed with Sylvan only he rode to adventure his Deliverance; and ≈øo long he travelled, till he came to the Ca≈øtle of Ar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ te, he ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to which he found Po ‚Ä¢ pides, who came upon the ≈øame adventure; when having di≈øcour≈øed about the matter, they came to the Gate and ≈øounded a Horn that was hanging, ≈øaid by, which „Äà‚óä„Äâ do all the Ca≈øtle each, when open flew the gate, and out bur≈øt two Mon≈øtrous Gyants, with Iron Clubs of an exa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ whicht, and d ‚Ä¢ manded what ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ prudence provoked them to di≈øturb the Quiet of the≈øe Ladies, but the Princes nothing aba≈øhed, „Äà‚óä„Äâ their Swords, and furiou≈øly charging
tho≈øe Mon≈øters of Men, brought them in a ≈øhort ≈øpa ‚Ä¢ e to the ground, when hewing off their Heads, they entered the Ca≈øtle, and with their drawn-Swords pa≈ø≈øed through divers places, till at la≈øt they came to an Iron Gate, which they bur≈øt in ≈øunder with one of the Gyants Clubs, when de≈øcending into a di≈ømal place they beheld the Prince lye bound in Irons, and almo≈øt fami≈øhed; (≈øo cruel is Womans revenge, when love turns into hatred, or that they cannot aquire their ends;) when having unbound him, they inquired how that misfortune befell him, which he related in the manner before recited, which ≈øo inraged the Princes, that had he not intreated the contrary, they would have fired the Ca≈øtle; for the Ladyes knowing their guilt, upon the Gyants being conquered, were fled through a Vault into the Woods: So that refre≈øhing them≈øelves with what provi≈øion they found there, they departed to ≈øeek more honourable Adventures.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV.

argument.p: How ≈øome days after Prince Palmerin was departed from the Ca≈øtle of Arnalte, he met a Damo≈øel, who intreated him to fini≈øh an Adventure; And how he was followed by Florian and Pomoides: How the Prince delivered three Ladies out of the Ca≈øtle of Duke Ron≈øilion, who were to be put to death; And what el≈øe remarkably happened in that Adventure.

div.p:
PRince Palmerin, Pompides, & Florian, travelling together, met a beautious Lady named Florinda Daughter to Arnedes King of France, who in the company of twelve Knights was travelling towards her Father's Court, when as one of them advancing ≈øaid, It was his Ladys plea≈øure, that a Tent ≈øhould he pitched, and that the Knights ≈øhould Iu≈øt before her with any that dur≈øt encounter them; this offer was ≈øoon accepted, ≈øo that three ad ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ing, the three Princes „Äà‚óä„Äâ again≈øt them and ca≈øt them to the ground Hor≈øe and Man; as likewi≈øe a proce≈øs of time they did the othermine; whereat the Prin ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ marvelling, would know their ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ es, but they
refu≈øed to declare them, but having a ‚Ä¢ ≈ø ‚Ä¢ ed her hand, pa≈ø≈øed on, promi≈øing if they came that way‚ñ™ to vi≈øit her Fathers Court. When no ≈øooner they had left her, but they e≈øpyed a Damo≈øel in Mourning, come towards them, making great laments, and no ≈øooner ≈øhe approached them, but ≈øhe with floods of tears implored them to follow her, which they promi≈øed; and ≈øo ≈øwift ≈øhe rode, that ≈øhe and Prince Palmerin out-≈øtript the other two, and arrived at a great and well-fenced Ca≈øtle, wherein the Damzel informed the Prince, three Ladies of ≈øingular beauty were kept pri≈øoners by Duke Ron≈øilion, and that he ≈øeverely threatned them, having murthered their Father for refu≈øing to give them to him and his two Brothers in Marriage; ≈øwearing likewi≈øe, unle≈øs they could find a Knight within a month to fight with and vanqui≈øh his three Knights, him≈øelf, and his two Brethren, or con≈øent to the marriage, (which they greatly di≈øliked) he would clap them up in Dungeons, where? (during life) they ≈øhould never view the light; therefore had ≈øhe at their earne≈øt tears ≈øought for a champion that might deliver 'em.

This hard u≈øage to Ladys highly offended the Prince; wherefore entring the Bridge, he overthrew the fir≈øt Kt. and with his Sword (after a hot di≈øpute) layed the other two breathle≈øs; when mounting a pair of ≈øtairs, he entered a ≈øpacious Hall, and there he found the Duke and his Brethren, threatning the Ladies with many cruelties; whereupon with a loud voice he cried, Turn hither, vile wretches! who dare thus abu≈øe the tender Sex, yet dare not fight with their avenger: This ≈øound amazed the Duke and his Brethren, e≈øpecially when they knew the Knights were vanqui≈øhed; yet running to their Arms, they came furiou≈øly to charge the Prince, who re≈øolutely defended him≈øelf, till by many grievous wounds he had brought them to his mercy; yet upon their falling pro≈øtrait, and begging their lives he (who won more Fame by clemency, than by the ≈øword) ≈øpared them; when as the ≈øorrowful Ladies, now ravi≈øhed with joy, time and fell at his feet, ≈øtileing him their Deliverer, but he that was not u≈øed to behold Ladies ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ el, took them up, and comforted them in the be≈øt wi≈øe, commanding the Duke and his Brethren to „Äà‚óä„Äâ them forgivene≈øs, and be heartily ≈øorry for the
injury they had done them, which accordingly they did, and then having ≈øworn never to injure Ladys more, they had their pardon.

By this time Prince Florian and Pompides were arrived at the Ca≈øtle, where ≈øeeing a Knight lye dead, in much the ≈øame Armour that Prince Palmerin wore, they ≈øuppo≈øed it was he, and thereupon vowed revenge: But entring the Hall, ju≈øt as they were about to fall upon the Duke and his Brethren, the Prince appeared and de≈øired them to hold their hands, ≈øaying, He had pardoned them; when at the Duke and his Brethrens humble ≈øupplication the Prince ≈øo wrought with the Ladies, that they giving up them≈øelves wholly to be governed by him, he concluded a Marriage; ≈øo that what the Duke's threats could not procure, the Prince's bravery and noble temper accompli≈øhed; when having joyned their hands in wedlock, he and his companions left the Ca≈øtle, being highly rewarded by the Duke at their departure, who took their way towards Con≈øtantinople.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVI.

argument.p: How Targiana, Daughter to the Great Turk, ≈øent her Knight Albayzer to fetch the ≈øhield of fair Miragarda; And how he (not being able to overcome Dramu≈øiand) ≈øtole it away by night; And how he was pur≈øued by the Gyant: How Florendos hearing of what had pa≈ø≈øed, together with the ≈øhepherd, bent them≈øelves to travel.

div.p:
THe Great Turk's Daughter being much offended that ≈øome Knights had prai≈øed the Beauty of Miragarda above hers, re≈øolved to di≈øgrace her if po≈ø≈øible; therefore calling to her Albayzer her devoted Servant, ≈øhe commanded him upon pain of her di≈øplea≈øure to fetch the Shield that was ≈øo much famed, which he (proud of ≈øuch an opportunity to increa≈øe his Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes favour toward him) joyfully undertook, and providing all things nece≈ø≈øary, departed, and pa≈ø≈øed through divers Countries, without meeting any Adventure, till he came to the place where the Shield hung; when e≈ø≈øaying to take it down, Dramu≈øiand came again≈øt him; whereupon he
prepared for the Encounter, but was the fir≈øt on≈øet overthrown, ≈øo that coming to the Sword, he being wor≈øted infinitely more than before, yielded him≈øelf conquered, and re≈øigned his Shield, ≈øeeming to depart: But ≈øo it happened, that he not daring to return without his own Shield, or that which had the Portraicture of the Lady, watched in the adjacent Wood, till he perceived the Gyant retire to dre≈øs his wounds, approached, and hid him≈øelf in the hollow part of the Tree till evening, at what time coming forth, he took that Shield and his own, and fled into the Wood; when as Dramu≈øiand, as his cu≈øtom was, attended by divers Damo≈øels with lighted Torches, came to convey it into the Ca≈øtle, he found it gone, as al≈øo the Shield of the Knight he la≈øt conquered, wherefore he concluded he had ≈øtole it away, and therefore made great ≈øorrow, declaring what had happened to his beautiful Mi≈øtri≈øs, who on pain of her di≈øplea≈øure commanded him to pur≈øue the Cowardly Knight, and take ≈øevere revenge, who≈øe commands he in≈øtantly obeyed.

Florendos, who had re≈øided in the plea≈øant Valley near the Ca≈øtle, and had heard day by day what had pa≈ø≈øed, hearing the Shield was lo≈øt, betook him≈øelf to travel; and with him went the Shepherd, who was ≈øo delighted in his company, that he had vowed never to leave him; and pa≈ø≈øing through divers Countries, they met with many Adventures, though none as yet worthy of note. Wherefore leaving them, I ≈øhall follow Palmerin, Florian, and Pompides.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII.

argument.p: How Palmerin, Floria ‚Ä¢ , and Pompides travelled under the guidance of a Damo≈øel to the Ca≈øtle of Dramorant the cruel, where they found Albayzer with the Shield of Meragarda; and of the Exploits he had performed: How Florian and Albayzer challenged each other; And how the Combat was decided in the Emperor's Court.

div.p:
Three Princes travelling long without meeting any con≈øiderable Adventure, in the end met with a Virgin, who ≈øeemed to be in great di≈øtre≈øs, of whom they demanded the cau≈øe, but ≈øhe appearing to be in a fright, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d them flee, or they would be all ≈ølain; Not ≈øo, fair Lady (≈øaid
the Prince) flight is a thing we are not accu≈øtomed to; but let me intreat you to tell me the cau≈øe of your fear. O ≈øir! (≈øaid ≈øhe) Twelve Knights ≈øet upon me, to carry me into the Ca≈øtle of Dramorant the cruel, a man who delights in Blood and Villany, when as a Knight came to my re≈øcue, and behaved him≈øelf ≈øo well, that I found means to e≈øcape; but I fear, in endeavouring to ≈øave me, him≈øelf, e're this, is ≈ølain, or in great danger. Shew us (≈øaid the Prince) where we may find the combatants: That will I do (≈øaid ≈øhe) with a Good Will; whereupon ≈øhe lead them to the place, where they found the combat very unequal, yet had the ≈øingle Knight ≈ølain divers of them, & de≈øired the Princes that they would ≈øtand Newters, and not eclip≈øe his glory; and in ‚Ä¢ eed he ≈øo well behaved him≈øelf, that he ≈øoon brought them into ≈øubjection; whereupon Dramorant with a mighty Battail-Ax, being armed in a Coat of Mael, advanced, again≈øt whom Prince Palmerin would have tryed his fortune, but the Knight would not ≈øuffer it, but began the fight with fre≈øh courage; ≈øo great prowe≈øs was ≈øhewed on either ≈øide, till at length the Gyant, (being a burly man) through ≈øweat and effu≈øion of blood, fainted, in≈øomuch that the Knight taking the advantage, (notwith≈øtanding the interce≈ø≈øion of the Princes) hewed off his Head, which greatly grieved Florian; upon which di≈øgu≈øt of his, the Knight (who became haughty through his conque≈øt) bid him defiance, and in ju≈øtification of what he had done, promi≈øed to fight him in the Emperors Court, whither he was going; which challenge the Prince accepted, and ≈øo they parted. When not long after they under≈øtood it was Albayzer, and that he had taken away the Shield of Miragarda, boa≈øting that he had overcome Dramu≈øiand.

The Princes now riding to ≈øeek Adventures, they chanced to meet a Coach covered with mourning, in which lay a dead Kt. in green Armour; whereupon Florian was very inqui≈øitive to know how he came dead, and of the Adventure; but tho≈øe that were about him being in ha≈øte, would give no other an≈øwer, but that if he would go with them, he might ≈øee; wherefore taking leave of his Brother and Pompides, he followed that mournful Bier; and not long after a Damo≈øel coming to Palmerin and Pompides, the later undertook the Adventure ≈øhe related.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII.

argument.p: Of Florian's Adventure; And of the Adventure that hapned to Palmerin, in his way to Con≈øtantinople; And that of Pompides.

div.p: FLorian accompanying the Coach ≈øtill, was inqui≈øitive to know the rea≈øon of what had happened, and who it was lay ≈ølain; to which one of the E≈øquires with a deep ≈øigh, and tears in his eyes, replyed, That the Knight he ≈øaw dead was Sortibran, Son to K.
