Fri≈øol, who≈øe enemies laying wait for him, had unawares ≈øet upon him and ≈ølain him; whereupon the Prince vowed revenge, but had ≈øcarce determined, e'r a Damo≈øel came running to a≈ø≈øure them that their Lords death was revenged by the good Knight Pompides, who had ≈ølain the Murderers as they were about to ravi≈øh a beautious Lady in the Unfortunate Wood; which made them greatly rejoyce; whereupon they pa≈ø≈øed on to interr their Lords body, and the Prince to meet Albayzer; but in his way met Arduramant, ba≈øtard-Brother to Albayzer, who was in ≈øearch of him; when under≈øtanding the Prince had promi≈øed to encounter him at Con≈øtantinople, he with a ≈øtern countenance charged him to avoid him as his death, for that there was not a Knight upon Earth, that could ≈øtand before him; but this not at all di≈ømayed the Prince, but rather encouraged him; which the Pagan perceiving, grew in wrath, and proffered pre≈øently to try the combat with him, which was accepted by the Prince, but then the Pagan would not fight, but in the Great Turk's Court, where he ≈øaid the ≈øaid Targiana re≈øided; to which the Prince replyed, that if he departed ≈øuddenly, he could not keep his word with Albayzer; to which Arduramant made an≈øwer, that he would excu≈øe him to his Brother; whereupon the Prince, de≈øirous to get Fame abroad and try ≈øtrange Adventures, con≈øented, whither we will leave them on their journey, and return to the Noble-Prince Palmerin of England.

The Prince Palmerin travelling through many De≈øaris, at length came into a great Plain, where he beheld a great many Knights & Ladys near a Fountain, as he thought, in merriment, when on a ≈øudden a fierce combat began between them, whereupon he bare up, being de≈øirous to know the occa≈øion, when
he perceived a mon≈øtrous Gyant and ten Knights fighting again≈øt two, who were conducting ≈øeveral beautiful Ladys, whom the Gyant would have from them, which unequal dealings (and e≈øpecially becau≈øe one of the Knights was fallen dead) ≈øo moved the Prince, that couching his Spear, he ran again≈øt the Gyant and overthrew him, and ≈øo dealt with his ≈øword, that he brought the Knights into ≈øubjection by killing ≈øome, & mortaly wounding others; when as A≈øtapardo & ten other Knights i≈ø≈øued out of the Ca≈øtle, to revenge what had hapned, who had certainly di≈øtre≈ø≈øed the Prince, had not Albayzer at that time come to his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, who knowing the Prince, dealt ≈øo furiou≈øly, that the ≈øecond comers were ≈øoon ≈øent to keep their fellows company.

The Fight being over, they upon inquiry found the fir≈øt Gyant to be Bracandor, Lord of the adjacent Ca≈øtle; and that the chief Ladys were the Dutche≈øs of Pontus and Durachium, who were travelling to the Court of their Father, under the conduct of Prince Datree, and Abdumelech their Brother, and that they had been ≈øet uyon by that cruel Gyant, who de≈øigned to di≈øhonour them. When having thanked their deliverers, and heaped a thou≈øand good wi≈øhes on them, they departed with the body of the ≈ølain Prince, which they got ≈øome Country Pea≈øants in the neighbouring Villages, to carry on a Bier.

div.head: CHAP XXXIX.

argument.p: How Prince Florian arriving at the Turk's Court, entered the Combat again≈øt Arduremant, and vanqui≈øhed him; And how Albayzer came to Con≈øtantinople, and what conditions he made to begin his adventurous intent.

div.p:
ARduramant having by one of his E≈øquires certified his Brother why Prince Florian could not m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t him at Con≈øtantinople, they ha≈øted to the Great Turk's Court, where re≈øided fair Targiara, when arriving there, they were received in courteous wi≈øe, and introduced into the Prince≈ø≈øes pre≈øence, where Arduramant having the honour to ki≈øs her hand, vainly boa≈øted, that he had brought a Knight with him out of a ≈øtrange land, to cha≈øti≈øe him in her pre≈øence, for that he had abu≈øed her ≈øervant Albayzer, in ≈øaying, he had not by his valour won the Shield of Miragarda, but taken it by fraud; then began he to extoll that Princes Fame, ≈øaying, that in his travels he had heard of ≈øuch wondrous atchievements
wrought by him, as no Knight in the world could boa≈øt the like.

Prince Florian hearing the Pagan vaunt at this rate, replied that he mu≈øt confe≈øs great things might have been done by Albayzer, but as for the ≈øhield of Miragarda, it was taken by him from Dramu≈øiand by fraud, and not force, for that Albayzer had been vanqui≈øhed by him; and that he was ready to defend what he ≈øaid at the point of his Launce, either again≈øt him or Albayzer. This ≈øpeech of the Prince's ≈øo inraged Arduramant that he had no patience, but began to cur≈øe and bla≈øpheme at a ≈øtrange rate, de≈øiring immediately the combat, which was granted in the pre≈øence of the Prince≈øs and the Great Turk, together with the Ba≈ø≈øa's and their Ladies: When as the combatants running furiou≈øly at each other, Arduramant was ≈øent to the ground, and the Prince a little ≈øhaken in his Saddle, who ≈øeeing his Foe on foot, alighted al≈øo, and drew his ≈øword, whereupon a dreadful combat began, in which the boa≈øting Pagan was infinitely wor≈øted; yet a≈øhamed to yield in his Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes pre≈øence, though the Prince offered him life, till fainting, through lo≈øs of blood, he fell; and being carried off upon his Shield, ≈øoon after dyed of his wounds.

The Battail fini≈øhed, the Prince≈øs ≈øent for Prince Florian, and highly commending his Valour, de≈øired to ≈øee him unarmed, to which reque≈øt of hers (after ≈øaluting her fair hand) he con≈øented; when as his youthful beauty and manly limbs appeared ≈øo brave, that from that time ≈øhe became amorous of him, and ordained him her Kt. giving him at the ≈øame time many rich pre≈øents, to keep for her ≈øake; ≈øo that in her ≈øervice leaving him a while, I ≈øhall return to Albayzer, who ha≈øted to Con≈øtantinople.

Albayzer parting with Prince Palmerin, ha≈øted towards Con≈øtantinople, to keep his word with Prince Florian; but riding through a Wood, he met the E≈øq of Arduramant, who informed him, that he was gone to the Court of the Great Turk and the cau≈øe; yet di≈ømi≈ø≈øing the E≈øq he kept on his way, till arriving at the Court, he was known to be the Soldian of Babylon's ≈øon; whereupon he was pre≈øented to the Emperor, who with his Nobles was fitting in a great Hall; when having done his reverance, he declared, that his coming was to that
end, that he might prove his valour again≈øt the Knights of the Court, upon the≈øe conditions, viz. That every Knight, who entered the Iu≈øt, ≈øhould bring his Ladys picture on his Shield, and that her name ≈øhould be written under it; and if they was vanqui≈øhed, that Shield to be hanged up, under the portraicture of his fair Mi≈øtri≈øs Targiana; and that they ≈øhould run with the Launce only; and tho≈øe that had no Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes, ≈øhould (upon being foiled) deliver the names of tho≈øe, in writing, to whom they were well wi≈øhers, and might in time be ≈øuch. The≈øe conditions agreed on, and the Iudges of the field appointed, every one prepared, and the day following the Iu≈øts began, which day Albayzer kept the field, foiling all that entered, or ran again≈øt him, to the great grief of the Ladys, who were a≈øhamed theie ≈øervants ≈øhould be ≈øo handled.

The fir≈øt days Iu≈øt over, and the night ≈øpent in Fea≈øting, Mu≈øick and Dancing, as ≈øoon as morning aro≈øe, the Trumpets ≈øounded to the field, where the Iu≈øt was again renewed, which day Albayzer likewi≈øe won; whereat Prince Primalion being in the Court, and de≈øirous to recover the honour of his Fathers Knights, armed him≈øelf, but the Emperor would not ≈øuffer him to enter, re≈øerving the Conque≈øt for ≈øome other hand.

The Emperors Knights thus foiled by a ≈øtranger, cau≈øed a great heavine≈øs in the Court, and exceeding joy and pride in Albayzer, who proudly vaunted that he had taken away the ≈øhield from Dramu≈øiand; therefore he would carry that & all the other Shields he had won, and lay them at his Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes feet: In which haughty exaltation, for a while I ≈øhall leave him, and return to the Turki≈øh Court, to vi≈øit Prince Florian.

div.head: CHAP. XXXX.

argument.p: What happened to Prince Florian in the Turki≈øh Court; And of other adventures that befell him.

div.p:
THe Prince daily increa≈øing in the favour of fair Targiara, re≈øolved to ≈øhew his utmo≈øt prowe≈øs, that ≈øo he might be the deeplyer grafted into her affections; but finding no adventures there worthy his Sword, he re≈øolved to make her acquainted with his ≈øincere affections, and then depart in ≈øearch of Adventures, for her ≈øake: Wherefore
one day being in private with the Prince≈øs; he declared what he had determined, which cau≈øed tears to ≈øtand in her fair eyes, who by this time loved him as life, which he perceiving, ≈øaid:

p.hi: Fair Lady, and Mi≈øtri≈øs of my Thoughts, grieve not that I de≈øire to depart hence, for I ≈øhall ever bear you a true and ≈øincere Affection; and for your Glory and Renown is it that I make this Reque≈øt; What ≈øhame is it for me to ≈øpend my time in Ea≈øe and Idlene≈øs, whil≈øt your former Servant Albayzer is labouring to Wing him≈øelf with Fame? It is not his force, faire≈øt of Creatures, that gives him Victory, but the Banner he fig is under, which is the hopes to obtain and in joy you? O that you would give me but ≈øo ‚Ä¢ a ‚Ä¢ ge ‚Ä¢ Commi≈ø≈øion! ≈øoon ≈øhould you find me as great and glorious; nay, with this hand would I take from him all the Trophies he has won.

div.p:
This ≈øpeech of the Prince, dryed his Mi≈øtri≈øs eyes, when cheering up, ≈øhe ≈øaid, Indeed Albayzer had done wonders for her ≈øake, yet ≈øhe could in no wi≈øe affect his per≈øon; wherefore if he might be conquered, all the obligations then would vani≈øh, and that (if he thought fit) ≈øhe would in di≈øgui≈øe accompany him to Con≈øtantinople, ≈øending Albayzer word before-hand, that he ≈øhould not ≈øtir thence till further order. This re≈øolve was highly approved by the Prince, and urged to be put in ≈øpeedy practice; whereupon the Prince≈øs feigning a Letter, from her Aunt the Queen of A≈ø≈øyria, that ≈øhe was ≈øick, at the point of Death, in≈øtantly de≈øiring to ≈øee her, ≈øhe ≈øhewed it to her Father, and by many intreaties ≈øo prevailed, that he con≈øented to her going; when to accompany her, ≈øhe cho≈øe no other train than Florian, called in that Court the Chri≈øtian Knight, four E≈øquires, and ≈øix Damo≈øels, all which mounting early in the morning, left the City, and rode without meeting any interruption, till they came into the confines of Con≈øtantinople, where meeting four Knights, and they beholding the beauty of the Prince≈øs, would have taken her from Prince Florian, which ≈øo inraged him, that running one of them through with his Launce, he ≈ølew the other two with his ≈øword, whereat the fourth fled: When riding a little further, and entering a plea≈øant Valley, he cau≈øed the Tent to be pitched for the Prince≈øs, and there, by rea≈øon it was late, he continued with her all night; when in the morning they ≈øet forward and rode till they came to a plea≈øant fountain, at which they alighted to drink the water; when as two Kts. riding by, who had been conquered by Albayzer, knew the Prince≈øs by the re≈øemblance of her Picture, when alighting,
they layed hold on her, ≈øwearing, that ≈øince for her ≈øake they had received the di≈øgrace, they would carry her as a Pri≈øoner to their Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes, thereby to make an attoanment for them, which rudene≈øs ≈øo offended the Prince, that drawing his ≈øword, at one blow he cut off the hand of him that gra≈øped the Prince≈øs, and afterward ≈ølew the other, which he that was wounded ≈øeeing, intreated the Prince≈øs to beg for his life, which at her reque≈øt was granted; and his E≈øq having bound up his wound, he departed in a heavy condition.

The≈øe mi≈øchances ≈øo afflicted the fair Targiana, that ≈øhe willed the Prince to ha≈øten thence; but long they had not travelled e'r they beheld a Knight lying under a fair ≈øpreading Tree, greatly bemoaning his misfortune, for falling under the di≈øplea≈øure of his Mi≈øtri≈øs; to who≈øe amorous complaints they li≈øtened ≈øo long, that the Kt. turning about, e≈øpyed them, when ri≈øing in great anger, he bid the Prince prepare for the combat, ≈øince he had heard his fond di≈øcour≈øe, he ≈øhould no where report it to his di≈øgrace, but at that time he ≈øhould remember his Valour; whereupon he left the Lady to be ≈øpectator of the dreadful combat; for although they received wounds on either ≈øide, yet neither gained a foot of ground, which made each of them wonder; but ≈øo it happened, while≈øt they ≈øo earne≈øtly like Lyons or Tygars fought, a Knight came riding up, when beholding the fair Prince≈øs, and knowing her by her portraicture, he cau≈øed his E≈øq by force to ca≈øt her behind him, and rode as fa≈øt as he might, undi≈øcerned of the combatants, who through eagerne≈øs to ≈øtrike and guard, neither heard nor ≈øaw her; yet her train that was ≈øome di≈øtance, followed hard after their Lady: But ≈øo it happened, that a while after Dramu≈øiand riding in ≈øearch of the Shield, and ≈øeeing two Kts. hotly ingaged, ≈øuddenly came up, when by the Dragon one of them bare in his Shield, he knew him to be Prince Palmerin, who the better to be unknown, had altered his Device, when crying aloud, Prince Palmerin, what means this mortal combat? And what occa≈øioned it? Now Florian no ≈øooner heard that name, but he recoiled, and threw down his Sword, di≈øcovering who he was, whereupon the two Brethren (no longer Foes) embraced each other, & begged pardon, that ≈øo ignorantly they had ≈øhed each others Blood: But
when one of the Prince≈øs E≈øquirs, who returned from following his Lady, reported what had happened to the Prince≈øs, Florian (overcome with rage & grief) fell to the earth in a ≈øwound; when recovering, he poured out divers lamentations, blaming hard fate, vowing revenge on him that had conveyed her thence; when as his Brother and Dramu≈øiand comforted him in the be≈øt wi≈øe, declaring that they would make it their bu≈øine≈øs to ≈øearch for her; whereupon they all departed to an adjacent Mona≈øtery, where the Prince's wounds were by an aged man, well skilled in Chyrurgery, cured.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXI.

argument.p: Who the Knight was that carryed away the Prince≈øs Targiana; And how he was vanqui≈øhed, and the Prince≈øs taken from him by a Knight, who carryed her to Con≈øtantinople, and in her pre≈øence vanqui≈øhed Albayzer.

div.p:
THe Prince≈øs Targiana being carried away, as afore≈øaid, it was ≈øoon known to be Albanis of Freeze, Son to the King of Denmark, that had offered the violence: For riding with her through a Forre≈øt, he met with a Kt. in black Armour, having a flaming Heart portrayed on his Shield, when Albanis, willing to ≈øhew his Valour, ≈øo affronted the Kt. that he obliged him to the combat, but it turned to his di≈øadvantage; for upon the fir≈øt Encounter he was tumbled from his Saddle, and in the fall, his Arm being under him, it broke; whereupon the Kt. in black Armour finding him uncapable of the ≈øword combat, left him to his E≈øq and was about to depart, at what time the Prince≈øs de≈øired him out of all kindne≈øs, that he would not leave her in that de≈øolate place, in the hands of a man who had before violated the order of Knighthood; whereupon inquiring into the matter, he took compa≈ø≈øion on her tender beauty, and undertook to conduct her & her Train to Con≈øtantinople, which accordingly he did, where upon his arrival he found Albayzer about to depart with all the trophies he had won from divers Knights of Fame, to the great grief of the Court Ladies, but glad he was not gone before his arrival, he (after having di≈øpo≈øed of the Prince≈øs in the be≈øt manner, who had by this time put her ≈øelf into Princely habit, after the Turki≈øh Fa≈øhion) de≈øired the combate with him, who proud of his many Victories, with a disdainful look threw down his
Gage, vowing to lead him in triumph to his Mi≈øtri≈øs, if he conquered him; Nay, ≈øaid the Knight, let it be al≈øo agreed, that if I conquer you, I ≈øhall bear the Shield you ≈øtole from the Ca≈øtle of Dramu≈øiand, in the night, when the Kt. that guarded it was not aware of you This affront made Albayzer fume extreamly, and vow revenge, when ca≈øting round his fiery eyes, he e≈øpyed (contrary to his expectation) the fair Targiana, yet ≈øuppo≈øed it impo≈ø≈øible ≈øhe ≈øhould be there, till being further ≈øatisfied, he relinqui≈øhed the doubt, and falling at her feet, gave her a thou≈øand thanks for vouch≈øafing in per≈øon to view tho≈øe actions of his, which he doubted not but Fame would have let her known, without giving her ≈øelf the curio≈øity & trouble; for which Oration having obtained the favour of her fair hand, he e≈øpyed the black Knight prepared to receive him, wherefore not to delay, he mounted, and ≈øo in full careir they ran at each other, with ≈øuch force, that Albayzer, to his great amazement and di≈øgrace, was tumbled from his Hor≈øe, and the black Kt. by the force he met with ≈øhaken in his Saddle; whereupon the former urged the later to the combat of the Sword, which he as willingly accepted, ≈øo that a bloody Encounter began, till ≈øuch time as Albayzer, fainting through lo≈øs of blood, fell to the ground, whereupon the black Kt. uncla≈øped his Helmet, to have taken off his head, but that the Prince≈øs (not forgetting her old ≈øervant, who for her ≈øake had ≈øo often hazarded his life) running in, upon her knees begged his life, which was accordingly granted, and he forced to forgo the many Trophies he had gained; whereupon the black Kt. (who upon his di≈øcovering him≈øelf, proved to be Florendos, Son to Primalion) required that the Shield of Miragarda might be placed in the middle, as Chief; which accordingly was done, & then both of them were conveyed to appointed Lodgings, to be cured of their wounds.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXII.

argument.p: Of the adventure of the CUP, and what the meaning was.

div.p:
GReat was the Ioy of the Court-Ladies, who≈øe beauty Albayzer had eclip≈øed, that he carried not the Palm to his own Country, and as great was the Emperors, when he knew the fair Targiana was pre≈øent, whom he recommended to the Empre≈øs and Prince≈ø≈øes, to be u≈øed
according to her E≈øtate: When during the≈øe pa≈ø≈øages, a Lady richly attired, arrived at Court, attended by a Knight who carryed a Rich Casket; when coming into the pre≈øence of the Emperor, Empre≈øs, and divers great Lords and Ladys, after ≈øalutation made, ≈øhe thus began:

Mo≈øt Mighty and Pui≈ø≈øant Emperor; Having for the ≈øake of a fair Lady travelled through many Countries, in order to the fini≈øhing of an Adventure, and hitherto failed therein, I have at length attained this happy place, hoping to find a Kt. that may accompli≈øh it: Then know, that thus it is, viz. There lately lived a King of Thrace, named Sardamant, who was exceedingly skilled in Magick, and having a Daughter of excellent Beauty, ≈øhe was courted of many Knights, which made him (lea≈øt contrary to his knowledg ≈øhe ≈øhould Marry) to ≈øhut her up in a Ca≈øtle, into which, notwith≈øtanding, one of her Servants, whom ≈øhe intirely loved, u≈øually got by a Rope Ladder, which ≈øhe drew up by a Silken Thread; but at length being di≈øcovered by his corival, he was ca≈øt into Pri≈øon; when ≈øoon after the Lady, who≈øe name was Brandi≈øia, conceived with Child, which ≈øo inraged the K. that as ≈øoon as ≈øhe was brought to Bed, he cut off her Lovers Head, and ≈øent his heart to her in this Cup, which ≈øhe took ≈øo hainou≈øly, that having filled the Cup with her Tears, and ≈øent it to her Father, ≈øhe bound the Heart to her own, and crying, I come my dear Love, to meet thee in Eliziums happy ≈øhades, ≈øhe threw her ≈øelf from the Battlements, and ≈øo expired; upon notice of which, the King repenting of ≈øuch his hard u≈øage, cau≈øed the Off-≈øpring of his Daughter, the young Prince≈øs Leonarda, to be brought up after her E≈øtate, having none be≈øide to Heir his great Wealth: Yet lea≈øt in her Infancy ≈øhe ≈øhould be conveyed thence, or in riper years betrayed into the ≈ønares of unlawful Love, he by inchantment ≈øo ≈øurrounded the Ca≈øtle wherein ≈øhe re≈øideth with Mi≈øts and deluding Phantomes, that when any one approaches; it ≈øeems to vani≈øh; after which congealing his Daughters tears (which you behold in this Cup) into a Stone, he, before his Death, left the≈øe directions: That the fair Leonarda can be marryed to none but him, or by his appointment, in who≈øe hand the Cup being, the congealed matter di≈ø≈øolveth to its proper
liquidne≈øs; and ≈øuch a one it mu≈øt be who≈øe Valour and Virtue ≈øurpa≈ø≈øes mo≈øt Knights upon earth; therefore if ≈øuch a one there be, let him e≈ø≈øay to deliver the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Prince≈øs out of her confinement.

This Adventure made all that were pre≈øent greatly wonder, yet re≈øolved they to e≈ø≈øay it; whereupon it went from hand to hand, but the effects were not wrought, in≈øomuch that the Lady began to di≈øpair, till at length Palmerin being healed of his wounds, came to try the Adventure, when immediately the tears di≈ø≈øolving, a new wonder in≈øued, which put the ≈øpectators into a great fright which was, that a flame of Fire ≈øeized the Prince invironing him on every ≈øide, which they vainly endeavoured to extingui≈øh, till the Lady ≈øprinkling a few of the Tears on him, it was extingui≈øhed and he found intirely well, whom they ≈øuppo≈øed to be con≈øumed to A≈øhes; and at the ≈øame time, the pa≈ø≈øion he had ≈øo long conceived for fair Polinarda increa≈øed; and the Lady pronounced him the man that was worthy of the fair young Prince≈øs, and that mu≈øt deliver her; and ≈øo the admiration of all vani≈øhed.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXIII.

argument.p: Of another ≈øtrange Adventure, and what in≈øued; And of the Fight again≈øt the Gyants.

div.p:
THe fir≈øt Adventure being over, there ≈øoon after happened another as ≈øtrange, which was as followeth: The Emperor & his Nobles ≈øitting in the Hall of his Palace, unexpectedly entered a Lady, attended by 3 fearful Gyants, and addre≈ø≈øing her to the Emperor, ≈øpoke in this manner: Emperor of Greece, I am ≈øent to you, from the Soldian of Per≈øia, the Soldian of Babylon, and the Emperor of the Turks, to demand your con≈øent to divers things which I have in charge; and if it ≈øo happen that you refu≈øe to comply, the≈øe my attendants have commi≈ø≈øion to denounce War again≈øt you. This ≈øtrange & unu≈øual di≈øcour≈øe did not a little amaze and con≈øternate the Emperor, yet he bid her make her propo≈øals. Then know, Sir, (replied the Lady) that in the fir≈øt place it is required, that you ≈øend
your Grand-Daughter, the fair Polinarda, to my Lord the Soldian of Per≈øia; Secondly, that Florendos her Brother ≈øhall ≈øwear to marry Armenia, Si≈øter to Albayzer, now Crowned Soldian of Babylon; and as for my Lord, the Emperor of the Turks, he requires you, as you tender the welfare of your Empire, that you would ≈øend him the Kt. Florian, ≈øometimes re≈øident in his Court, who has conveyed thence the fair Targiana. The≈øe are the demands; and now ≈øir I expect your an≈øwer.

The Emperor, who was never wont to be braved at this rate, by any Potentate, was not a little angry, yet concealing his di≈øplea≈øure, he made reply: That tho≈øe proud Lords ≈øhe mentioned, did ill to ≈øend him conditions of Peace or War, for that he nothing expected any thing in that nature; yet ≈øeeing it was their nature, they might give him at their plea≈øure, for never in a better time could they do it, adding, that what they ≈øo peremptorily demanded, or rather commanded, they ≈øhould have humbly ≈øued for, yet had they done it, he could not, nor would not have gratified their de≈øires.

The Emperor having made this an≈øwer, the Gyants with dreadful and deformed countenances advanced, when as Berocant, the Soldian of Per≈øia's Champion, in the name of the re≈øt pronounced War, with all its attendant mi≈øeries, and then defied the Kts. pre≈øent, de≈øiring that the place might be a≈ø≈øigned, where he and his two Companions might fight ten or twelve of the be≈øt Kts. which proud ≈øpeech ≈øo fired young Palmerin, that preventing others that attempted to reply, he in this wi≈øe began: Mon≈øters of Men, know that words nor fearful faces can never di≈ømay the Valiant, who have and dare meet Death in all his gri≈øly forms; you know not again≈øt whom you vent your pride; no numbers ≈øhall oppre≈øs you, only three Kts. ≈øhall teach your tongues from henceforth better order. He ≈øcarce had ended, when Florian and Dramu≈øiand begged that they might be his partners in the combat; but the Gyants ≈øeeing the inequality in the ≈øtature, ≈øaid, They would not fight where ≈øo little glory was to be gained by conquering; Nay, ≈øaid Horian, 'tis rather cowardly fear that deters you, than ought be≈øide, therefore, to ≈øpur you on, know, I am the Kt. you demand, to deliver to the Turk; 'twas I that lead away the fair Targiana, though
not again≈øt her will. This being heard, the Gyants raged like a Tempe≈øt, each of them vowing the bloodie≈øt revenge he might, re≈øolving to ≈øacrifice tho≈øe Knights to the plea≈øure of their Lords, but failed in what they aimed at; for the three Kts. entering the combat again≈øt them, after a dreadful ≈øight, the three Mon≈øters of Men, Berocant, Albarocco, and Arbu≈øar, each ten cubits high, were made ≈øhorter by the Heads, which cau≈øed the Emperor & all the Chri≈øtian Knights greatly to rejoyce.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXIV.

argument.p: What hapned in the Court of the Emperor after the combat: How Palmerin ended the Adventure of the Inchanted Ca≈øtle.

div.p: PRince Florian having renounced his love to the Prince≈øs Targiana, upon her fre≈øhly entertaining the amours of Albayzer, who had been vanqui≈øhed by Florendos, care was taken to ≈øend her to her Father's Court, which was done, with a great train, ≈øuitable to her Birth & Fortune; of which Albayzer having notice, came thither, & with the con≈øent of her Father married her. As for Florendos, he having obtained leave, departed to the Ca≈øtle of Almorol, with the Shield he had recovered, hoping thereby thereby to be re≈øtored into the favour of his fair Mi≈øtri≈øs Miragarda.

The≈øe things pa≈ø≈øing, Palmerin's mind was wholly taken up for fini≈øhing the Adventure of Thrace; wherefore arming him≈øelf, he rode in ≈øearch of the Ca≈øtle, having had directions of the Lady where to find it: When coming to a ≈øpacious Plain, he beheld divers dark Clouds over≈øpreading the mid≈øt thereof, when advancing nearer, he met divers wild Bea≈øts, which can at him with great fury, again≈øt whom he prepared him≈øelf, but in his blows wounded nothing but Ayr, for they were only Phantoms of terrour, formed by Magick; wherefore pa≈ø≈øing through the skirts of the thick darkne≈øs, he found it like a ≈ømall ≈øhowre of Rain, till at length he ≈øaw a glimmering of Light, as if it proceeded from flaming Torches, twards which he approached, ≈øtill encountering with airy Spectrums, which in their careir (much like bla≈øts of wind) gave him ≈øuch buffets, that he could fearcely fit his Hor≈øe; yet at length, having pretty well
pa≈ø≈øed the darkne≈øs, he beheld the Ca≈øtle (being a mo≈øt ≈øtately building) Walled and Moated round, before which ≈øtood two Knights, to his ≈øeeming, well appointed, but as they came fiercely on, they vani≈øhed; whereupon e≈øpying the Bridge about to be drawn up, he rode furiou≈øly and pa≈ø≈øed it, when as a doleful cry ari≈øing within, two Gyants came with fearful gazing eyes, and ≈øtrong Maces in their hands, and gave him many heavy ≈øtrokes, but ≈øtill as he ≈øtruck at them, they avoided him, and in the end vani≈øhed; then entred he the Ca≈øtle, which he had no ≈øooner done, but a mighty Earthquake ≈øhook it, that it ≈øeemed to be falling about his ears, yet (nothing daunted) the couragious Prince pa≈ø≈øed on, till he came to an Iron Gate, before which lay a Serpent of mon≈øtrous bigne≈øs, ≈øpitting fire, and with his forked ≈øting threatning de≈øtruction to any that approached; and be≈øide him lay a great parcel of Keys, which the Prince ≈øuppo≈øing to be tho≈øe that unlocked the Ca≈øtle doores, a≈ø≈øaulted him with ≈øuch violence, that bur≈øting through a window he took wing and flew over the City adjacent, by which the Citizens knew that the Inchantment was di≈ø≈øolved; then flew open all the doores of their own accord; whereupon entring a Garden, he found the fair Prince≈øs, attended with divers grave Matrons, who approached with great joy to congratulate his happy ≈øucce≈øs, in performing ≈øo great an adventure; the Prince≈øs yielding her ≈øelf to be wholly governed by him in all affairs. But long they had not di≈øcour≈øed, e'r a great number of the Nobles of that Country came to pay Homage to the Prince≈øs, and to ≈øeat her upon her Fathers Throne; and having ≈øufficiently expre≈ø≈øed their thanks to Prince Palmerin, they conveyed her to her Father's Palace, which was till that time held by Queen Carmelia her Aunt, and there made fea≈øting, & all manner of di≈øports, where the Prince (at their reque≈øt) was pre≈øent; then the Queen brought the fair young Prince≈øs to him, de≈øiring that their hands might be joyned in ≈øacred Marriage-bands, but he excu≈øed it‚ñ™ ≈øaying, his heart was firmly linked another way, and that none but Polinarda mu≈øt po≈ø≈øe≈øs his love, which the Lady that brought the Cup to the Emperors Court affirming, he was then required to appoint her a Noble Knight to e≈øpou≈øe her, which he promi≈øed to do, and ≈øuch a one as ≈øhould be worthy the Diadem of Thrace.

div.head: THE FAMOUS HISTORY Of the Renowned Prince. PALMERIN of ENGLAND. PART, the Second.
CHAP. XXXXV.

argument.p: What happened to Prince Florendos, in his travel towards the fair Miragarda; And to the Knights that were ≈øent to accompany Targiana to the Great Turk's Court.

div.p:
PRince Florendos had not far pa≈ø≈øed, e'r he met with a Damo≈øel, who in a piteous manner demanded his a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to deliver a Lady, who was doomed to dye by A≈øtribor a Gyant, Brother to Dramorant the cruel, ≈ølain by Palmerin, Pompides, and Florian, to which the Prince con≈øenting, ≈øhe lead him to the Ca≈øtle, before which he found two Knights ≈øtanding ready with their Launces, who (as he attempted to pa≈øs the Bridge) came again≈øt him, but were received with ≈øuch courage and bravery, that the Prince's Launce lighting upon the brea≈øt of one of them, pierced his Armour, & bore him dead to the Earth, which the other ≈øeeing, drew his Sword, and charged upon the Prince with great fury, but long ≈øurvived not; for by a ≈øtroke he received upon his Helm, it bur≈øt, and the Sword entering his Brain, down he fell; which evil hap the Gyant from his ≈øtation perceiving, was greatly inraged, and with a ≈øtrong Battail-Ax came forth, menacing the Prince with Death and Ruin; but he nothing affrighted, prepared to receive him in the be≈øt wi≈øe; when as a dreadful combat hapned between them, till at length, through ≈øwear and lo≈øs of blood, the Gyant fainting, the Victory fell to the Prince, yet not without many wounds on his ≈øide; but having loped off the Head of the Mon≈øter, he entered the Ca≈øtle, and in a deep Dungeon (directed thither by the laments of a womans voice) he found a fair
Lady, whom he ≈øet at liberty, and demanded the cau≈øe of her cruel u≈øage, to whom ≈øhe faintly replyed, that (the Gyant, in revenge of his Brothers death, ≈ølain by the valiant Knight Albayzer, in order to the delivery of her ≈øelf and two Si≈øters) ≈øhe had been taken captive by A≈øtribor, who vowed, ≈øo ≈øoon as he could take that Kt. they ≈øhould be both ≈øacrificed to his brothers Gho≈øt. This lamentable ≈øtory greatly moved the Prince, that having had his wounds dre≈ø≈øed by the ≈øaid Lady, he departed with her to her Fathers Ca≈øtle, where leaving her, he pa≈ø≈øed on towards the Ca≈øtle of Almorol.

The Prince riding three days without any adventure, in the end beheld a fair Ca≈øtle, when approaching it, a Damo≈øel came forth, and informed him it was the Ca≈øtle of Arnalte, Prince≈øs of Navar, and that her Lady demanded, that he ≈øhould fulfill what ≈øhe ≈øhould de≈øire, or ≈øwear never more to bear Armour, or el≈øe abide the danger that was likely to befall him, of which hard conditions he cho≈øe the la≈øt; whereupon ≈øix Knights well armed i≈ø≈øued out, running at him with great fury, mo≈øt of who≈øe Launces he cut in ≈øunder with his Sword, and then charged them ≈øo furiou≈øly, that four of them fell a ≈øacrifice to his revenge, when as the other two being ≈øore wounded, and in danger of death, the Prince≈øs came forth, and upon her knees begged their lives, which the Prince, upon condition ≈øhe would reveal the cau≈øe of the evil cu≈øtom, granted; when being lead into the Ca≈øtle, ≈øhe cau≈øed him to ≈øit down by her upon a Couch of Velvet, and with a ≈øigh ≈øhe thus began: Alas ‚Ä¢ ir! ≈øaid ≈øhe, it was once my hap to find a noble Knight ≈øleeping in a Valley not far di≈øtant from this place, who≈øe youthful Beauty and comely ≈øhape ≈øo fired my heart, that I was all a Fevour; when being no longer able to re≈øi≈øt the Power of Love, to ea≈øe my torment, I conveyed him ≈øleeping (as he was) into this Ca≈øtle, with the help of my Si≈øters; but cruel he di≈ødaining my tears and intreaties, on the account of one Polinarda, to whom he ≈øaid he had vowed his affections, my love, ≈øo ≈ølighted, turned to anger, yet gently mild, ≈øo that hoping by keeping him under re≈øtraint, I might oblige him to take compa≈ø≈øion on me; but ≈øoon after came one Florian of the De≈øart, and another Knight, who overcoming my Guards, ≈øet him free, and burnt part of
my Ca≈øtle, which I ≈øince repaired, and ordained this Adventure to bring him hither again, obligeing by promi≈øe, or by for many Knights to combat him, wear no Armour, or become „Äà‚óä„Äâ Pri≈øoners, of which I have many in confinement, who d ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t prefer their Mi≈øtri≈øs Beauty before mine, & refu≈øe my demands.

At this narration the Prince greatly wondered, declaring to her who the Prince was, and informing her it was not in the power of any Knight to conquer him, much more contrary to his mind, to make him yield to her de≈øires, though he confe≈ø≈øed ≈øhe was fair, to a Miracle, yet his heart was already fixed beyond recall; and thereupon de≈øired to ≈øee the Knights ≈øhe held Pri≈øoners, to which ≈øhe con≈øenting, they proved to be Blandidon, Te ‚Ä¢ ebrant, & Recamon, Kts. of the Emperors Court, all which, at the reque≈øt of Prince Florian, ≈øhe ≈øet at liberty, who together with the Prince, taking leave of their fair Goaler, departed, on their way towards the Ca≈øtle of Almorol; on which Iourney for a while we will leave them, and pa≈øs to the Court of the Great Turk.

The Prince≈øs Targiana having been honourably di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, and in her Train divers Princes of the Emperor's Court, and Kts. of great worth, who encountering many difficulties by the way, at la≈øt arrived at Adrinople, where the Emperor of the Turks re≈øided, who under≈øtanding what happened to his Gyants and that Prince Horian was not ≈øent, as he expected, cau≈øed all the Knights, Chri≈øtians, as al≈øo King Polendos, and many others, to be conducted into a large Hall, whither in great ≈øtate he came, attended by his Guards, putting it to their choice in many haughty & raunting words, Whether they would chu≈øe to be Pri≈øoners or in≈øtantly dye? This unexpected welcome amazed the hardy Knights; yet ≈øcorning to be afraid, after ≈øome pau≈øe, the King ≈øtepped forth, and demanded the rea≈øon of ≈øuch their u≈øage, ≈øeeing they had not offended him; But (replyed the haughty Turk) Florian of the De≈øart has, and unle≈øs he ≈øpeedily be ≈øent to me in Chains, I will revenge the injury on you. That will not be, (replyed K. Polendos) for the Emperor e≈øteems him at the price of half his Empire; and know, That we being Chri≈øtian Kts. ≈øcorn ba≈øe Servitude, and will rather dye, than ≈øuffer ignominious Bondage; which words ≈øo incouraged
Prince Belcar, and the re≈øt, that drawing their ≈øwords, & ≈øtanding together, they re≈øolved to ≈øell their lives at a price too high for the Turk's puny Guards to purcha≈øe; but ju≈øt as their dreadful hands began to move, in came the beautious Prince≈øs Targiana, with di≈ølevel'd Hair, and falling at her Fathers feet, begged he would ≈øpare them, that had done her ≈øo much honour and pre≈øerved her life, but the angry Mahometan would con≈øent upon no other conditions, than that they would ≈øurrender them≈øelves his Pri≈øoners; whereupon the Prince≈øs be≈øought them, that they would at that time ≈øubmit to fatal nece≈ø≈øity, promi≈øing ≈øo to deal with her Father, when his pa≈ø≈øion was over, that they ≈øhould be ≈øoon ≈øet at liberty, or if he refu≈øed, ≈øhe would work other means for their Relea≈øe; at what time they (con≈øidering their ca≈øe to be de≈øperate, after ≈øome conference among≈øt them≈øelves) con≈øented to lay down their weapons; whereupon they were conveyed to divers ≈øtrong Ca≈øtles, where they continued in pri≈øon many days.

This news coming to the ear of Palmerin the Emperor, and of the Princes, they were greatly grieved at the barbarous ingratitude of the Infidel, vowing revenge as ≈øoon as po≈ø≈øible, to con≈øult of which I ≈øhall for a while leave them, and return to Prince Florian, whom I left on his way towards the Ca≈øtle of the fair Miragarda.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXVI.

argument.p: What happened to Prince Florian, after he left the Ca≈øtle of Arnalte; And how the Prince≈øs of Thrace her Damzel arrived at the Court of Con≈øtantinople.

div.p:
PRince Florendos departing from the Ca≈øtle in the company of tho≈øe Knights he had delivered, at length came into a plea≈øant Grove of Trees, where he e≈øpied a Knight at all points armed, ≈øtanding between two Oakes, who upon his approach ≈øent his E≈øquire to him & his company, to command them not to pa≈øs that way, unle≈øs they would confe≈øs and maintain, not only there, but in all places, that the Prince≈øs Arnalte of Navar, was the mo≈øt beautiful of all Ladys living; to which Floriman (preventing Prince Florendos) replyed, That he could not, neither would he ≈øo much wrong his
Con≈øcience, as to give the Lye to him≈øelf, for that although ≈øhe was fair, ≈øhe was cruel and uncourteous, and that there were many fairer by far, which he was ready to maintain, if the Kt. con≈øented; whereupon couching their Spears, they ran at each other with ≈øuch fury, that they both fell to the ground; but recovering their feet, they drew their Swords and charged each other with great fury, the Victory for a long time being doubtfull; but in the end ≈øuch was the force of Floriman, that he brought the Kt. under, and would have ≈ølain him, had not the Prince interpo≈øed, at what time uncla≈øping his Helm, they found it to be Albanis of Freeze, Son to the King of Denmark, whereat Floriman was greatly grieved that he had ≈øo ignorantly wounded his friend; yet no ≈øigns of death appearing, they went to the hou≈øe of an old Kt. hard by, where his wounds were cured, and there (at the reque≈øt of Florendos) he declared how he became amorous of the Prince≈øs, and had taken an oath to maintain, ≈øhe was the faire≈øt Creature living, having under the favour and protection of her Beauty conquered many a good Knight: When having refre≈øhed them≈øelves, they pa≈ø≈øed on towards the Ca≈øtle of Almorol, in which expedition I ≈øhall again leave them, and return to Palmerin of England.

The Nobles of Thra ‚Ä¢ e, de≈øirous to have their young Prince≈øs given in marriage, ≈øent the Lady who had been intru≈øted in the management of the Adventure of the Cup, to the Court of the Emperor, who undertaking it, arrived there at ≈øuch time as Prince Palmerin had retired to recreate him≈øelf, when entering, and ≈øeeing him not among≈øt the other, ≈øhe began to be heavy, as fearing ≈øome mi≈øhap had befaln him, but being ≈øatisfied to the contrary, ≈øhe de≈øired Audience, which being granted, ≈øhe thus began:

p.hi:
Mo≈øt pui≈ø≈øant Emperor, Ladys, and worthy Knights, My Charge is from Queen Carmelia, and the Nobles of Thrace, to let you know the Worthy Exploits of the Renowned Prince Palmerin, lea≈øt his Mode≈øty hiding his great Exploits, Fame ≈øhould therein be ≈øilent: Know then, that the Prince has worthily fini≈øhed an Adventure, that may amaze the World, conquering Mon≈øters, Gyants, and all difficulties, thereby delivering the beautiful Leonarda, whom he yet refu≈øed, and with her the Diadem of Thrace, offered him by the Prince≈øs, and all the Nobles of the Kingdom, ≈øo firm and con≈øtant was he in his Love to the fair Polinarda, your Grand-Daughter, and Daughter to the Worthy prince Primalion; yet has he promi≈øed (according to the Will of her decea≈øed father) to provide her ≈øuch a prince, as may be
worthy of her Love; Wherefore in the Name of the Queen, Prince≈øs, and all our Nobility, with Letters-Credentials, I come to require, That the fair prince≈øs (my Lady) may be brought to your Court, and there Received according to her E≈øtate.

div.p: This motion highly plea≈øed the Emperor, as it did all the Ladys, who were de≈øirous of nothing more, than to ≈øee her, for who≈øe deliverance the Noble Prince had adventured ≈øuch hazards; wherefore with many Rich Pre≈øents the Damo≈øel was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, and earne≈øtly de≈øired to ha≈øten her Lady thither; in which undertaking I ≈øhall leave her, and return to Prince Palmerin.

The Prince delighting him≈øelf in a plea≈øant Forre≈øt, to ≈øhun popular applau≈øe, after his late expedition, ≈øo it happened That he beheld divers Kts. galloping cro≈øs through a by-way, when being de≈øirous to know the occa≈øion of their ha≈øte, as imagining they were po≈øting to ≈øome Adventure, he followed ≈øo long till he overtook one of them, who laged behind, by rea≈øon his Hor≈øe was faln lame, of whom he demanded the cau≈øe of ≈øuch ha≈øte, but he for a long time gave him doubtful an≈øwers, yet in the end, hoping he might lend him his E≈øq Hor≈øe, thus began:

Know Sir, (≈øince it is not in your power to hinder th ‚Ä¢ Ente ‚Ä¢ pr ‚Ä¢ ze) That Feli≈øtor, a Noble Man of this Country, falling in love with a beautious Damo≈øel, living not far di≈øtant from his Ca≈øtle, who≈øe eyes all along promi≈øed him love and good liking; but ≈øo it happened, that through the per≈øwa≈øions of her Mother, ≈øhe marryed one Ridamur, who is now repairing with her to his own Ca≈øtle, when to prevent it, and take her by force, and kill her Lord, this company is provided, as al≈øo another layed in Ambu≈øh by the way they mu≈øt pa≈øs; But ≈øuch is my misfortune, that my Hor≈øe falling Lame, I fear will di≈øappoint me of being there to a≈ø≈øi≈øt my friend; therefore (≈øince I have freely told you all) I hope you will ≈øuffer me to change Hor≈øes with your E≈øquire. Nay, (≈øaid he) you rather de≈øerve to be cha≈øtized, for daring to undertake ≈øo Villanous an attempt, in going about to force free minds, and di≈øhonour an Innocent Lady, which all good Kts. ought to protect: But no longer to ≈øpend my breath upon you, I'll follow the Adventurers, and (perhaps) make them repent the undertaking of ≈øo ra≈øh an Adventure. This being ≈øaid, he rode forward with great eagerne≈øs, whereat he who had informed him laughed.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXVII.

argument.p: What happened to the Prince in the Adventure of the re≈øcue: As al≈øo to Prince Florian in another Adventure.

div.p:
PRince Palmerin, fired with a de≈øire to give a≈ø≈øi≈øtance to the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed, ha≈øted to overtake the Troop, but was not
≈øo ≈øpeedy, as to come before Ridamur was ≈ølain, and the Lady, together with her Mother, taken pri≈øoners, who made many grievous laments, in≈øomuch, that the Prince riding up, commanded tho≈øe that held them, upon pain of forfeiting their heads to let them go; but they being ≈øix in number be≈øides Feli≈øtor, began to flout him, ≈øaying, What means this mad fellow, to intermeddle in our affairs? I'le warrant (replyed another) he being ≈øome fool-hardy Knight, and de≈øirous to get him a name, now means to purcha≈øe it at the hazard of his life; but above all, Feli≈øtor began to rave exceedingly, threatning him with death, for pre≈øuming to intermeddle with his affairs; to which the Prince replyed, That as for his threats, he feared them not but was come with a re≈øolution to correct his in≈øolence, and ≈øet free the Lady he had ≈øo cowardly taken, and about to deprive of her honour; wherefore with his Launce running again≈øt him, he overthrew him, and the Launce piercing quite through his body, he fell dead; then drawing his Sword, he ≈øo layed about him, that killing two of his Knights, the other four fled to the Ca≈øtle of the Lady, and took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of it, till ≈øuch time as it was regained by the Prince and two of them ≈ølain.

The old Lady and her Daughter perceiving them≈øelves intirely at liberty, greatly rejoyced, and coming before the Prince, would have humbled them≈øelves on their knees, but he would not ≈øuffer them, but gently rai≈øed them, and ≈øaluted their fair hands; then came they to the place where the body of Ridamur lay, which he cau≈øed divers Country Pea≈øants to convey to the Ca≈øtle adjacent, but when he and the Ladies arrived there they found the Bridge drawn up, and the Ca≈øtle po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, which made them g ‚Ä¢ eatly wonder, whereupon they de≈øired the Prince to lye in ambu≈øh a while, to ≈øee if any that were within would come forth, but he not finding it, pa≈ø≈øed the Moat upon a Float of Timber he found therein, when entering a fair Hall, he found four armed Kts. whom he knew to be tho≈øe he had vanqui≈øhed and put to flight; yet they ≈øeeing him an foot, and ≈øuppo≈øing him through long travel and lo≈øs of blood to be faint, ≈øet upon him, but ≈øoon found their mi≈øtake; for after a ≈øharp di≈øpute, two of them fell dead, and the other two upon their knees begged mercy, which they received at his hands, who≈øe clemency
won his applau≈øe greater than his Sword; whereupon he commanded them to let down the Bridge, and ask pardon of the Ladies, which done he ≈øuffered them to depart. The Ladys being entered, with great joy again ≈øaluted him, and intreated him to ≈øtay ≈øo long, till they had interred the body of Ridamur, to which he con≈øented, and then departed towards Con≈øtantinople, on who≈øe way thither for a while I ≈øhall leave him, and return to Prince Florian.

Prince Florian having again taken his Device of the ≈øavage Man, departed in ≈øearch of Adventures, ≈øo far, that at length arriving in France, he was de≈øirous to pa≈øs over into England to vi≈øit his Father and Mother; but as it had once before befaln him, ≈øo it hapned to him now: For he having no ≈øooner imbarqued, but a wind ari≈øing, which long troubled the Ocean, he was driven upon the Coa≈øt of Ireland, where going on ≈øhore and repo≈øing upon a green Bank, he was ≈øuddenly awaked by the ≈øhreiks of a Damo≈øel, whereupon ≈øtarting up with his ≈øword in his hand, he ≈øaw her flying before a mon≈øtrous Gyant, at which interpo≈øing his Shield, he bid her be of good comfort; but ≈øoon the Gyant (who≈øe name was Br ‚Ä¢ calon) came up with a ≈øtern countenance, and commanded him to deliver her, or he was a dead man; to which the Prince reply'd, He had ever born Armour to ≈øuccour di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Ladys, and at the hazard of his Life would venture to pre≈øerve her; whereupon the Gyant in a great Rage ≈øtruck at him with his Batttail-Ax, but mi≈ø≈øing his blow, the Prince ≈øaluted him with his ≈øword, ≈øo that a hot Encounter happened between them, which made the Damo≈øel ≈øtand trembling and almo≈øt ready to give up the Gho≈øt, for fear the Prince ≈øhould be ≈ølain; but ≈øuch was his good fortune, that (after much blood ≈øhed on either ≈øide) the Gyant fainted, and retiring in ≈øight, ≈øtruck his heel upon a ≈øtump and fell, when the Prince not thinking it prudence to let any advantage ≈ølip in a combat with ≈øuch an Enemy, ≈øtood upon him & cut off his head. Then rejoyced the Damo≈øel greatly, and conducted the Prince to a Hermit's Cave not far di≈øtant, to cure his wounds, & there attend him, informing him that ≈øhe appertained to the Empre≈øs of Germany, and had been ca≈øt on ≈øhore by Shipwrack in her pa≈ø≈øage to Denmark.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXVII.

argument.p: What happened to Prince Florendos upon his Arrival at the Ca≈øtle of Almorol.

div.p: THe Prince Florendos having fini≈øhed many Adventures, arrived at la≈øt at the Ca≈øtle of Almorol, with the Shields of Miragarda and Targiana, where again≈øt him came the Gyant Almorol, but knowing him to be the Prince, he threw down his Spear, and embraced him in his arms with joy, demanding how he had ≈øped ≈øince his departure? when as the Prince informed him of all that had happened, but above all, of the Adventure again≈øt Albayzar, producing the two Shields, the ≈øight of which greatly rejoyced him; whereupon he ha≈øtily ran into the Ca≈øtle, to inform the Prince≈øs, That her Servant was returned, and had brought the Shield; as al≈øo the Shield of her who had dared to ≈øtand her Rival in Beauty: This news highly plea≈øed her, yet being of a haughty mind, ≈øhe ≈øhewed it but a little outward, though the Gyant urged, That ≈øhe ought to be kind to the man, that had ≈øuffered ≈øo much, and indured ≈øuch hard≈øhip for her ≈øake; but all ≈øhe would grant, was, the favour of ki≈ø≈øing her hand, and re-admitted to guard the Shield; which made him very pen≈øive, and greatly to bewaile her hard hap, often repeating his amorous pa≈ø≈øion to his Ladys Picture, at the feet of which he had placed the Shield of Targiana.

When having ≈øtayed there ≈øome time without meeting with any adventure, at length he e≈øpyed coming towards him three Knights; the fir≈øt in ≈øilver and green Armour, having on his Shield in Greek Letters of gold, the word Normandy: The ≈øecond had Armour white and Azure mingled artificially with ≈øtreams of green interchangeable, bearing in a Field of Sinople the god Apollo: The third had his Armour of a Carnation colour, be≈øet with Cro≈ølets of Gold, and for his device, Orpheus
tortured in the flames of Hell: And as they approached the Ca≈øtle they ≈øung this following Song.

lg.l: FAir Madam, if you can vouch≈øafe to ≈øee
The lively Picture of a careful mind
Forlorn with grief, then do but look on me,
And judge if Fortune be not mo≈øt unkind,
That he who ≈øues and ≈øerveth faithfully
Should be repay'd with extream cruelty.
What greater Torment to a gentle mind
Than to be ≈øcorned where he liketh mo≈øt?
What ≈øtate of Refuge can he hope to find
where each thing doth at his misfortune boa≈øt?
Condemn'd, confounded with rebuke & blame,
Yet ignorant from whence the Cau≈øes came.
So heavy is the waighty yoke of Love
When quainte≈øt looks afford di≈øcourte≈øie,
Then wi≈øe is he that doth the pa≈ø≈øion prove,
And yet can keep him≈øelf at liberty:
But he who≈øe wits are ravi≈øhed by ≈øtealth,
Had need of Phy≈øick in his greate≈øt health.
Some men in love commend their happine≈øs,
Their quiet ≈øweet, and delicate delight;
And I can boa≈øt of Fortunes frowardne≈øs,
Her extream rigor, and ≈øevere de≈øpite;
But for the ≈øweetne≈øs other men have felt
I came too late, my part was el≈øewhere dealt.
Yet can I ≈øay, no man has been more ju≈øt,
Nor ≈øerv'd his Lady with more due regard;
But ≈øhe being govern'd by her own mi≈øtru≈øt,
Denies her Servant his de≈øerv'd reward:
Thus my Misfortune waxeth more and more,
Yet I will ≈øuffer, though I dye therefore.

div.p: This Song greatly plea≈øed the Prince, and becau≈øe it nearly related to his condition, he engraved it upon the bark of a Cypres Tree; by what time the Knights were advanced to the Tree where the Shields hung; when the fir≈øt Knight beholding the beautifull Picture of the fair Miragarda, he began to contemplate thereon, ≈øaying, That ≈øhe who≈øe Portraicture it was, might well command all Hearts, and was indeed the ≈øoveraign Empre≈øs of Beauty, and that it was no wonder, that for her ≈øake ≈øo many Adventures had been undertaken, and that tho≈øe that defended her Cau≈øe were ≈øo pro≈øperous.

Having ≈øaid thus much, he de≈øired Prince Florendos to break a couple of Launces with him in Honour of the Lady, who≈øe Picture he pretended to guard; to which the Prince readily con≈øenting, they prepared for the Iu≈øt, and run ≈øo furiou≈øly again≈øt each other, that the Knight in the green Armour was overthrown; whereupon the Prince alighting, they drew their ≈øwords, and began a furious Combat, wounding each other in a de≈øperate manner, in≈øomuch, that the blood i≈ø≈øued out, and the green Knight at la≈øt fainting, the Combat was given over. Then would the two other Knights prove the Turnament with their Spears, again≈øt whom ran Prince Floriman, who was a little before arrived to bear Florendos company, who overthrew them both, at what time it ≈øo happened, that they were known to be Prince Platier the ≈øage Aliart, and Beroldo Prince of Spain, upon which they embraced each other, and ≈øtayed divers days at the Ca≈øtle of Almorol, in hopes to ≈øee the far-famed beautys of Miragarda; but ≈øhe being of a haughty temper, would not vouch≈øafe to give them that ≈øatisfaction; whereupon having taken leave of each other, they departed.

The Princes gone, ≈øoon after another ≈øtrange Adventure happened, which was, that down the River, on the ≈øide of
which the Ca≈øtle ≈øtood, there came two Boates, one covered with a Canopy of Silk embroidered with Gold, in which ≈øate a Lady of incomparable beauty, and at her feet, between two Matrons, a Knight in green Armour, intermixed with Gold, who had for his device, in a Field of Sinople, god Cupid bound in Chains, with his Bow and Arrows broken: When in the other Boat were divers Damzels, with three E≈øquires playing upon Lutes, and tuneing their voices to the melodious ≈øound: At which the two Princes ≈øtood wondring ≈øo long, that rowing to the ≈øide of the Ca≈øtle, a Damzel and an E≈øquire came on ≈øhore, and advancing to the Tree where the Shield of Miragarda hung, they gazed upon it a con≈øiderable time, and ≈øeeming ≈øomewhat di≈øplea≈øed that the Portraicture was ≈øo exceeding fair, they left it, and having obtained leave of the Prince≈øs and the Gyant Almorol, the Damzel entered the Ca≈øtle, and had acce≈øs to the pre≈øence of the Prince≈øs Miragarda, when (having payed her re≈øpects) ≈øhe in humble wi≈øe made it known; That her Lady Arnalte Prince≈øs of Navar, being in her Boat under the Ca≈øtle Wall, de≈øired that ≈øhe might enter the Ca≈øtle and confer with her, that ≈øo face to face, compari≈øons of beauty might be made: But the Prince≈øs Miragarda would by no means con≈øent, excu≈øing it upon the Gyant Almorol and the Prince Florendos, whom (as ≈øhe ≈øaid) had it in their power to refu≈øe, if ≈øhe con≈øented; therefore in hearty commendations to her for her kindne≈øs, and the trouble ≈øhe had given her ≈øelf, ≈øhe de≈øired to be excu≈øed, as to what was de≈øired: With which unplea≈øant an≈øwer the Damzel returned to her Lady, who upon the report thereof, was out of patience, in≈øomuch, that in a great rage ≈øhe commanded her Knight to fetch the Shield, which accordingly he enterprized, but upon his arrival at the place where it hung, he found it was not to be obtained by fair words, but by Combat; wherefore not daring to return without it, he (after many words had pa≈ø≈øed) defied the Prince to the Combat; whereupon a dreadful Fight began, which for a long time held bloody and doubtful, but in the end the Prince (by a ≈øtroke he gave him on the Helm) brought him to his mercy; which the Prince≈øs Arnalte perceiving, in a great
rage cau≈øed her Marriners to Row up the River, leaving her Knight to quit him≈øelf as well as he could; but the Prince pittying him as a Lover, ≈øpared his Life, and referred him to the Sentence of Miragarda, who injoyned him upon the Oath of Knighthood, never to ≈øerve any Prince≈øs but Arnalte; and that he ≈øhould alter the device in his Shield, that in≈øtead of Cupid's being bound, he ≈øhould paint him as victor, leading a Knight fa≈øt menacled in Chains of Silver: to the performance of which being ≈øworn, he was di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, being grieved at nothing more than that his Lady had left him in di≈øplea≈øure.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXVIII.

argument.p: Who the Knight was that came with the Prince≈øs Arnalte: And of the ≈øplendid Entertainment made in the Court of Con≈øtantinople, upon the Arrival of Leonarda Prince≈øs of Thrace.

div.p:
TO let you under≈øtand who the Knight was that came with the Prince≈øs Arnalte, know that his name was Dragolant Son to the Duke of Normandy, who arming him≈øelf, and ≈øetting forward in ≈øearch of Almorol's Ca≈øtle, to win the affections of fair Miragarda; when happening on the Ca≈øtle of Arnalte, and overcoming her Knights, ≈øhe became ≈øo amorous of him, that ≈øhe entertained him as her Knight; and he on the other hand contemplating her beauty, which was not much inferiour to Miragarda's, and on the other hand con≈øidering ≈øhe was Heire≈øs to the Kingdom of Navar, became her ≈øworn ≈øervant; but as ≈øhe was a Lady that was ≈øoon angry, and as ≈øoon plea≈øed, ≈øhe left him vanqui≈øhed, as you have heard: But upon his being di≈ømi≈ø≈øed, overtaking her, and in her pre≈øence trying his Valour upon divers Knights that would have offered her violence, he recovered
her favour to ≈øuch a degree, that within a ≈øhort time they were married together, and he inve≈øted with the Title of a King: In which happy e≈øtate I will leave him, and return to the Prince≈øs Leonarda.

Leonarda Prince≈øs of Thrace being on her way towards Con≈øtantinople, the Emperor with a great Train of his Knights went to meet her, which they having done, highly welcomed her, who ≈øate in her Sun-bright Charriot, attired in Gold and Iewels beyond value: When as the Complements having pa≈ø≈øed on either ≈øide, and a happy Repa≈øt taken in a Royal Pavillion, they all ha≈øted towards the City, where they were that evening earne≈øtly expected; but had not travelled far e're they beheld a Knight ≈øtanding in the way, with his Launce in his hand, well mounted, and attended with two E≈øquires, one of which he ≈øent to the Emperor, to require the Iu≈øt with his Knights; which the Emperor (though loth to lo≈øe ≈øo much time, yet for the credit of his Knights, and honour of the Prince≈øs) granted: whereupon the ≈øtrange Knight (who bore for his device a Cyprus Tree in a Field of Azure) advanced, and was met in full Carreir by Prince Beroldo, but he (too feeble for his force) was di≈ømounted; as likewi≈øe were Prince Platire, Pompids, and all the Knights which attended the Emperor; which greatly grieved him, that ≈øo great a di≈øgrace was befallen his Knights in the ≈øight of the Prince≈øs, and were in a manner alltogether out of conceit with them≈øelves, who before had hopes to gain the e≈øteem of ≈øo beautifull a Virgin: But whil≈øt they were mu≈øing, the ≈øtrange Knight ≈øeeing no more to deal with, came before the Emperor, and uncla≈øping his Helm, appeared to the great joy of them all, to be Prince Florian of the De≈øart, who had left the Engli≈øh Court, and pa≈ø≈øed through Germany, and divers other Countries, ≈øeeking Adventures, till arriving near Con≈øtantinople, he under≈øtood the Prince≈øs was on her way, and having had knowledge of her excellent beauty from his Brother Palmerin, he was re≈øolved to divertize her with the prooff of his Prowe≈øs.

Vpon this di≈øcovery the Prince (after having ≈øubmitted him≈øelf to the Emperor, and his Vncle Prince Primalion, who at that in≈øtant arrived,) came to the fair Prince≈øs, and obtained the favour of ki≈ø≈øing her delicate hand; and from that time, though before uncon≈øtant and wavering in Love, he became ≈øo amorous of her, that for her ≈øake he enterprized many dangers and difficult hazards.

The Noble Train arriving about Sun-≈øet at the City of Con≈øtantinople, all the Ladies attended the Empre≈øs, who came forth of her Pallace to welcome her Gue≈øt, ≈øo that what with the perfections of Nature and adornments of Art, a glorious and ravi≈øhing ≈øpectacle was there to be beheld; and all night long the Streets and Pallaces were illum ‚Ä¢ ned with Tapers, and Fires made of fragrant Wood, as Cedar, Cyprus, and what el≈øe might con≈øi≈øt with the Magnificence; when in the morning early all manner of Mu≈øick ≈øounded, and every thing el≈øe that could procure delight was to be ≈øeen.

When as the Prince≈øs Leonarda being in the company of fair Polinarda, began to expre≈øs her high e≈øteem of Prince Palmerin, but above all his con≈øtant love, from which the Diadem of Thrace could no ways charm him; which rai≈øed a conceit in the Prince≈øs Polinarda, not only of his worth, but a fear of lo≈øing him, if ≈øhe hid her pa≈ø≈øion from him, as ≈øhe for ≈øome time had done, and ≈øeemed outwardly to be di≈øplea≈øed with him ≈øhe inwardly loved and admired; wherefore ≈øhe determined with her ≈øelf to give him better incouragement for the future: But whil≈øt this thought la≈øted, in came Prince Florian, and having made his reverence, ≈øate down by the Ladies; when fixing his eyes on the fair Prince≈øs Leonarda, and ≈øhe the like on him, they found ≈øuch a mutual ≈øimpathy of love and liking, that from that time their Hearts were firmly vnited; yet blu≈øhes re≈øtrained their ≈øpeech, till at length Florian taking courage, addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf in this manner:

p.hi:
Bright Mirror of Beauty, who≈øe Charms have power to make the harde≈øt Marble relent: Behold the Victim that mu≈øt bow before the Alter of the Almighty, and pay his Vows at your fair ≈øhrine: Grant, mo≈øt Excellent of Woman-kind, to
own the Conque≈øt you have made, and pitty the conquered: Yet all that I dare pre≈øume to ask, is, That you would daign to allow me the Honour of being your Knight, that under the Banner of your rare perfections, I may amaze the world with deeds worthy to be attributed to ≈øo much Excellency as ≈øhines in you.

div.p: This unexpected Complement made the Ro≈øie blu≈øhes ari≈øe in the Prince≈ø≈øes Cheeks, ≈øo that the Lillys that before were ≈øtriving for ma≈øtery, were quite vanqui≈øhed; when re-collecting her ≈øelf, ≈øhe thus replyed:

p.hi: Sir, your Prai≈øes of my Beauty might have been ≈øpared, by rea≈øon that I can allow your Comments thereon to be no other than a Complement: Yet the reque≈øt you have made, being ≈øo ≈ømall, for this fair Prince≈øs ≈øake, who≈øe Cou≈øin you are, I cannot in point of Honour nor Civility deny your reque≈øt; yet ≈øhould blame my ≈øelf for ≈øo doing, if (adventuring for my ≈øake) any misfortune ≈øhould befall you.

div.p: The Prince (overjoyed at this conce≈ø≈øion) took the boldne≈øs to approach his Mi≈øtri≈øs and ≈øalute her fair hand; at what in≈øtant a Me≈ø≈øenger came in ≈øearch of him, to inform him, that the Emperor expected him in his Chamber: whereupon humbly taking his leave of the Ladies, though with ≈øome regret, he departed, leaving them to their freedom of di≈øcour≈øe.

div.head: CHAP. XXXXIX.

argument.p: What happened to Prince Florian upon his being ≈øent by the Emperor in a ≈øtrange Adventure.

div.p:
PRince Florian (as afore≈øaid) having left the company of the Ladies to attend the Emperor, found there an Aged Man of large ≈øtature bedewing his reverend Beard with tears, and greatly complaining again≈øt the adver≈øne≈øs of Fortune: When being by the Emperor ordered to declare the ≈øum of his Grief, he replyed, As to the particulars, he had ≈øworn to hide from any but the Knight
who would be ≈øo hardy in getting him≈øelf Fame and Renown in undertaking it, and by atchieving it, ea≈øe him of infinite mi≈øery.

The Prince hearing this, and ≈øuppo≈øing for that purpo≈øe the Emperor had ≈øent for him, began greatly to rejoyce, that he had ≈øuch an opportunity to oblige his new Mi≈øtri≈øs the Prince≈øs Leonarda; whereupon he joyfully offered his ≈øervice, though the Emperor was alltogether unwilling he ≈øhould hazard him≈øelf, unle≈øs the Adventure was known; but upon the often A≈ø≈øeverations of the Old Man, and the earne≈øt of the Prince, he at length gave his con≈øent; in≈øomuch, that the Prince (accompanied only with his E≈øquire, and the Aged Man) departed the Court in great ha≈øte: So that although the Emperor afterward repenting, and ≈øending after him Beroldo, Platire, Blandidon, and many other good Knights, to ≈øuccour him, if occa≈øion required, they could not overtake him; for coming to a River over-≈øhaded with Trees, and pa≈ø≈øing it in a little Boat, e're the Boat could return to fetch his E≈øquire, and the Hor≈øes as the Aged Man promi≈øed it ≈øhould, ≈øuch a Tempe≈øt, (together a di≈ømal and gloomy Fogg) happened, that the Boat was over-≈øet as ≈øoon as ever the Prince landed. But being ≈øafe on ≈øhore, and ≈øeeing the Ca≈øtle before him, where he had notice from the per≈øon who had required his help, that the Adventure was, he came before it; but finding it ≈øeated upon an high Rock, and but one way, very narrow to a≈øcend, he drew his Sword and mounted, (by rea≈øon of the height, he was obliged to re≈øt divers times;) when looking for the Old Man, whom he ≈øuppo≈øed to have followed him, he found him mi≈ø≈øing, whereupon he began to ≈øu≈øpect ≈øome treachery; yet nothing daunted, he re≈øolved to try the utmo≈øt: So that arriving at the top of the Rock, he came to the Gate, which he found open, when in≈øtead of Armed Men, whom he expected, he met with three beautifull Damzels Richly attired, who came forth to welcome him, which increa≈øed his wonder; yet ≈øcorning to fear ≈øuch fair Enemies, he followed them into a ≈øtately Hall, at the upper end of which, in a Chair of State, ≈øate a beautifull
Lady of great ≈øtature, who upon his approach aro≈øe to meet him, giving him leave to ≈øalute her, then ≈øhe welcomed him in a kind manner, feigning much joy to have ≈øo much Honour as a vi≈øit from a Knight ≈øo high in the favour of Fortune, telling him he mu≈øt repo≈øe there that night, and that on the morrow ≈øhe would inform him of the Adventure to be undertaken, with which he ≈øeemed well content; whereupon he was lead into a ≈øtately Parlour, where the Tables were ≈øpread with all manner of provi≈øion, and after ≈øome Complements made, ≈øate down, frequently ca≈øting his eyes upon one of the Damzels that ≈øerved at the Table, who≈øe beauty he fancied to be carer than what he ever had ≈øeen before; nor was ≈øhe wanting to entertain him with amorous glances: Supper ended, he was by that Damzel conducted to his Lodging, who laying ba≈øhfulne≈øs a≈øide, promi≈øed to yield her Honour to be at his di≈øpo≈øal, ≈øo ≈øoon as conveniency would permit; and ≈øo giving him a flattering ki≈øs, ≈øhe ≈ølipped a King upon his finger (as ≈øhe ≈øaid) in pledge of her future good will: But ≈øo it happened, That it had a Stone in it, the Virtue of which ≈øuddenly ca≈øt the Prince into a dead ≈øleep, when the large-≈øized Lady, who≈øe Name was Arleucia, entring the Chamber, and beholding the Prince o'rewhelmed with drow≈øiene≈øs, ≈øhe thus began to rejoyce:

Happy am I this day, that Fortune had delivered into my hands the Man I ≈øo long wi≈øhed for; now is the time that my Revenge for my Brethrens Blood mu≈øt be wrought: O Brocalon! Baleato! Calfurnine! and Camboldam! Three of you fell by this Prince's hand, whom I am about to ≈øacrifice to your Gho≈øt.

And thereupon taking a ≈øtrong Sword in her hand, ≈øhe was about to ≈øtrike the fatal blow, in order to take off the Prince's Head, when beholding his exqui≈øite beauty and manly grace, her heart began to fail her, ≈øo that letting fall her hand, ≈øhe pau≈øed a while; but Revenge overcoming her pa≈ø≈øion, ≈øhe a ≈øecond time re≈øolved his Death, and had put her bloody intent in practi≈øe, when (as Fate, or rather Fortune, would have it) the Aged Man that had decoyed him from the Court entered,
and intreated her to hold her hand, ≈øaying, There could be nothing more plea≈øing to her ≈øorrowful Mother, than to have it in her power to take the Prince's life, whom ≈øhe might not otherwi≈øe perhaps believe to be dead: Yet hardly could he per≈øwade this Virago to hearken to his intreaty, ≈øhe was ≈øo fired with Revenge.

This Prince by this means obtaining a Reprieve, it was agreed, that her Mother ≈øhould be ≈øought for, and made acquainted with the prey that Fortune had ≈øent her, and that ≈øhe ≈øhould ha≈øte to pa≈øs Iudgment upon the de≈øtroyer of her Sons: In ≈øearch of whom we will leave them, and return to Prince Palmerin.

div.head: CHAP. L.

argument.p: Of the Grief conceived for the lo≈øs of Prince Florian; And how his Brother Palmerin went in ≈øearch of him; and what befell him.

div.p: PRince Florian's E≈øquire ≈øtaying with the Hor≈øes on the other ≈øide of the River two days, and not perceiving his Ma≈øter return, was for want of provi≈øion con≈øtrained to return; when far he had not rode, e're he met with two Knights, who by their Armour to be ≈øage Aliart, and Prince Palmerin, to whom he related what had befallen his Lord, which did not a little perplex them; yet the Sage betaking him to his Art, a≈ø≈øured the Prince, that he was detained by Necromancy in the profound I≈øland, and that it would co≈øt ≈øome time to recover him out of the hands of his Adver≈øaries: whereupon the Prince ≈øending the E≈øquire to the Emperors Court, to certifie the Emperor of what had happened, re≈øolved to go in ≈øearch of him.

The news known at Con≈øtantinople, cau≈øed a general grief, but e≈øpecially the Emperor was greatly afflicted, becau≈øe he had
≈øo ra≈øhly con≈øented to his undertaking an Adventure he knew not, what, nor where. The Ladies could not refrain from weeping, but e≈øpecially the fair Leonarda, who had ≈øo ≈øoon lo≈øt her new ≈øervant, on whom ≈øhe had impre≈ø≈øed ≈øuch deep affections; but in con≈øideration that his brother had undertaken his deliverance, they were ≈øomewhat comforted, yet knew not what to think, ≈øeeing Sage Aliart had given out, that he was in danger of his life.

Prince Palmerin having attained the River, where the E≈øquire had informed him his Lord pa≈ø≈øed, found there neither Boat nor Bridge; yet riding along the hither bank, he at la≈øt found a place where it was fordable; when coming to the Ca≈øtle, which by the de≈øcription the Sage gave of it, he well knew to be the ≈øame, whereupon with his drawn Sword he mounted the Stairs, meeting by the way with many airey Fantomes, but no humane oppo≈øition, which made him boldly enter, when all he found, was a Damzel, who ≈øeeing him approach with his drawn Sword, ≈øhrieked aloud, and was about to fly; but the Prince taking her by the arm, charged her upon her Life to inform him what was become of the Knight, that not many days before came to the Ca≈øtle? Whereupon ≈øhe trembling, and faultering in her ≈øpeech, replied: That that morning he was conveyed by her Lady Arlutea, and Alfernao, who (in a Trance) having put him on Skip-board, had carryed him (at the Reque≈øt of Collumbra her Ladys Mother) to the Profound I≈øland, where they intended to put him to death, in revenge of the Death of the four Gyants ≈ølain by him and his Brother; the ≈øaid Gyants being Sons to Collumbra, and Brothers to Arleucea; who had left her Country to be nearer the Emperors Court, that ≈øhe might the better effect her purpo≈øed Revenge. This news greatly di≈øturbed the Prince, but con≈øidering there was no time to be lo≈øt, he made the Damzel ≈øwear to the truth of what ≈øhe had ≈øaid, and to de≈øcribe the Ca≈øtle of the Gyante≈øs Collumbra; as al≈øo the Ship wherein they were imbarqued: Which done he ha≈øted to the Sea-≈øide, and made all the ha≈øte imaginable to imbarque, di≈ømi≈ø≈øing his
E≈øquire, to expect him at Con≈øtantinople, and bear his re≈øpects to the fair Polinarda, de≈øiring her good wi≈øhes for effecting the Enterprize he had undertaken.

Now ≈øo it happened, that Aliart knowing what had pa≈ø≈øed, and that they were upon the Sea, as ≈øoon as they came within ≈øight of the I≈øland where the Gyante≈øs lived, rai≈øed ≈øuch a ≈øtorm, that by contrary Winds they were driven upon a ≈øtrange Coa≈øt, yet could not (by rea≈øon of the mighty Rocks) Land, but were forced to ride it out at Sea, when they were carried up to Heaven and down to Hell, ≈øo tempe≈øtuous were the Winds, and ≈øo dreadful the ≈øurface of the Deep, that every moment they expected to peri≈øh; whereupon Arleucea began to repent of what ≈øhe had undertaken, wi≈øhing ≈øhe was again in her Ca≈øtle, and that Prince Florian had not come thither: Yet often was ≈øhe determined to kill him on Ship-board, but feared to be letted, by rea≈øon the Marriners were ignorant of the Con≈øpiracy again≈øt his Life; but in the end imagining that Heaven was offended at her unju≈øt determination, and that all were at the brink of Ruin; after divers cogitations, ruminating in her mind how her Brethren fell in ≈øingle Combat, and the Princes only defended them≈øelves, ≈øhe (after having con≈øulted Alfernao) re≈øolved to take off the Charm, and keep the Prince in ignorance of what had been de≈øigned again≈øt his Life: Wherefore going to the Cabin where he lay, and having taken off the Ring, ≈øhe ≈øprinkled a certain Iuice upon his face, which ≈øoon re≈øtored him to his ≈øen≈øes; and as ≈øoon the ≈øtorm began to cea≈øe.

The Prince finding him≈øelf on Ship-board, began to marvel how he came there; when gazing about him, beheld Arleucea, knowing her to be the ≈øame Lady that had Fea≈øted him in her Ca≈øtle; whereupon he took her by the hand, and cau≈øing her to ≈øit down by him, after many gentle ≈øpeeches towards her, demanded how he came thither, and what the Adventure was he ≈øhould fini≈øh? But ≈øhe di≈ø≈øembling the matter a while, in the end (≈øeeing his Princely Carriage, great Beauty, and wonderful Civility) gave ≈øuch ≈øcope to her pa≈ø≈øion, that earne≈øtly
repenting of what ≈øhe before intended, falling on her knees, ≈øhe fir≈øt with tears begged his pardon for the Body-Treachery de≈øigned again≈øt his life, and then related from point to point what had happened, and what was further intended; whereat he Marvelling fell likewi≈øe on his knees, and gave thanks to Heaven; then ri≈øing, he pardoned Arleucea, but ≈øhe laying all the contrivance of the matter to Alfernao, he could be hardly intreated to ≈øpare his life; but in the end, con≈øidering Age, and that by taking his life he ≈øhould render him≈øelf inglorious, he was content, he ≈øhould be confined a perpetual Pri≈øoner in a Ca≈øtle on the Coa≈øt of Spain, belonging to King Recinde, whither by this time the Tempe≈øt had driven them; and there landing, he with the young Gyante≈øs, and four Damzels he found on board with her, travelled ≈øo long, that coming into a plea≈øant Valley, they e≈øpied two fair Tents, and by them walking four Ladies, who ≈øeeing them approach, one of them merrily ≈øaid, Sir Knight, you are well ≈øtocked with Ladies, a ‚Ä¢ d may well ≈øpare ≈øome of them to our Knights, who have more occa≈øion for them. Nay, ≈øaid the Prince, I ≈øhall in no wi≈øe forgo my Charge; but if your Knights dare contend with me, and take them, or any of them by force, I ≈øhall gladly ≈øubmit to the chance of Fortune. Nay, ≈øaid the Lady, 'tis the cu≈øtom of this place, that you mu≈øt try the Ju≈øt e're you depart, or leave your Lady; and if you become Conqueror, then we are all at your divotion, to be di≈øpo≈øed of as you ≈øhall think fit. If this be the cu≈øtome, ≈øaid the Prince, I am contented; but where are tho≈øe I am to contend with? It will not be long (replied ≈øhe) e're they will be with you. When as at her command, a Dwarf that remained in one of the Tents ≈øounding a Silver Trumpet, the Knights came riding out of the Forre≈øt, when to receive them the Prince prepared; and meeting the fir≈øt, (who pretended to the Lady that made the challenge) he threw him from his Hor≈øe with ≈øuch force, that he lay breathle≈øs: Then he prepared to meet the re≈øt, and ≈øerved them in the like manner; which ≈øo inraged them, that contrary to their cu≈øtom, they (re≈øolving to be revenged) drew
their Swords, and came upon him very furiou≈øly, to the great grief of his late acquired Mi≈øtri≈øs; but ≈øo ≈øtoutly the Prince behaved him≈øelf, that in a ≈øhort time he ≈øo di≈øabled them, that they were not capable of u≈øing their Swords: Wherefore (according to contract and cu≈øtom) he cau≈øed the four Ladies to mount the Knights Hor≈øes, and (leaving their former Guardians in the Tents ≈øorely to bewail their misfortunes) rode with him, whom he carried away as it were in Triumph.

div.head: CHAP. LI.

argument.p: Of the Adventure that befell Prince Florian, in conducting the Ladies to the Court of Spain: And what happened to Prince Palmerin of England in the Profound I≈øland.

div.p:
THe Prince being proud of his beautiful Troop, re≈øolved to convey them to the Court of Recinde King of Spain; whereupon riding merrily through divers plea≈øant places, di≈øcour≈øing of ≈øundry affairs, his new acquired Companions greatly delighted in their Guide, but above all Arleucea became ≈øo pa≈ø≈øionate of him, that ≈øhe could not keep her eyes from off him; but he having a de≈øign to be≈øtow her upon his friend Dramu≈øiand, would not ≈øhew her ≈øuch countenance as ≈øhe expected. Long they had not rode towards the Court of Spain, but the Prince began to inquire of the Ladies that he had won at the Iu≈øts, what, and who they were, and the cau≈øe of their coming to that place? when as one of them named Arte≈øia made this Reply: Sir, ≈øince you u≈øe us ≈øo courteou≈øly, it is but rea≈øon I ≈øhould ≈øatisfie you in ≈øo ≈ømall a reque≈øt: Know then, that we are ≈øi≈øters, who, by the Licen≈øe of our Mother, came with the≈øe Knights (who were de≈øirous of us in Marriage) to the place where you found us, who (to plea≈øe us, and create in us a better e≈øteem of them) would often oblige ≈øuch Knights as pa≈ø≈øed to forgo their Ladies, if any accompanied them, or confe≈øs we were
fairer than any they adored; in which (before this time) they never was un≈øucce≈øsfull.

This Story plea≈øed the Prince, ≈øo that continuing their former mirth, they merrily rode on: On which way I will leave them a while, and ≈øee what became of Prince Palmerin in ≈øearching after his Brother.

The Prince (as is ≈øaid) having taken Shipping, after a while being to≈ø≈øed on the Seas, came to a Port of the Profound I≈øland, near to which he found a ≈ømall Cottage, where entring he e≈øpied a grave per≈øon, who aro≈øe up and welcomed him; when as the Prince ≈øitting down, began to inquire into the ≈øtate of the Country, and received an≈øwer, That it was an I≈øland plentifully ≈øtored with all things; and that over it not long before ruled a Gigantick Tyrant named Bravorant, who committed all manner of Murthers, Rapin, and Violence, but kind Heaven in the end cut him off: Yet left he by his Wife Collumbra four Sons, viz.
