Calfernine, Camboldam, Brocalon, Baleato; the two former of which glorying in their ≈øtrength and tyranny, leaving the I≈øland, went in ≈øearch of Adventures, making great ≈øpoyl in all places, till at la≈øt they were ≈ølain in ≈øingle Combat by the Sons of Prince Don Edoard; of which the other two Brethren hearing, contrary to the will of their Mother, went to ≈øeek the Princes, and revenge their brothers death; but (as fate would have it) meeting with one of the Princes, known by the Title of The Knight of the ≈øavage Man, they fell by his ≈øword, as the former had done: Which news ≈øo inraged their Mother, that (out of all patience) ≈øhe leagued with one Alfernao, skilled in Magick, who promi≈øed to deliver that Knight into her hands, that ≈øhe might glut her ≈øelf with torturing him to death, ≈øo that he is by her daily expected; as al≈øo by her brother E≈øpouvantable, a mon≈øtrous Gyant, who (as her Sub≈øtitute) greatly Tyranizes.

The Prince upon notice that his brother was not yet arrived, greatly rejoyced, de≈øiring to know the Ca≈øtle of the Gyant and Gyante≈øs, and the neare≈øt way to it: When having received direction, and re≈øted that night, the next morning
early (having largely rewarded his Ho≈øt) he took his leave: When pa≈ø≈øing a Forre≈øt, he came to a Haven of the Sea, where he e≈øpyed a great Combat of ten Knights again≈øt three, yet the later maintained their ground to a wonder; when making up to them, he ≈øoon knew the three Knights to be Berold Prince of Spain, Platire Son to Primalion, and the Sage Aliart; and tho≈øe that fought again≈øt them were the Knights of the Gyante≈øs, who, upon their landing, came to take them Pri≈øoners: But as the Prince was about to come to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, he e≈øpied the mon≈øtrous Gyant E≈øpouventable clo≈øe lurking behind a Tree to expect the event of the Combat, who ≈øeeing his men ≈øo hard be≈øet, came forth with a dreadful noi≈øe, much like the roar of inraged Seas, crying, Kill, kill the Varlets: which the Prince perceiving, advanced again≈øt him with great courage and bravery, ≈øaying, Stay Mon≈øter, and combat me, permitting tho≈øe that are over-matched by number, though not by Valour, to fini≈øh their Combat. The Gyant beholding the Prince with disdain, reylyed, That he would cha≈øti≈øe him with death, and fea≈øt with his fle≈øh the Fowles of the Air: which nothing amazing the Prince, he drew his Sword, ≈øo that a dreadfull Combat en≈øued, and ≈øo long la≈øted that after great effu≈øion of blood, and many wounds, the Prince his unconquerable Fortune prevailed, and the Gyant was brought on his knees to beg his life; but the Prince having knowledge of the many Cruelties he had committed, contrary to his wonted clemency, ≈ømote off his Head, and hanged it by the Hair upon a Bough in the Forre≈øt; when turning about, he perceived his Companions had killed five of the ten, and brought the other five into ≈øubjection, who upon their declaring they were forced to do what they did by the Gyants compul≈øion, they had their lives.

Whereupon having re≈øted them≈øelves, and bound up their wounds, the Prince with his three Companions rode towards the Ca≈øtle of Collumbra, re≈øolving to rid the I≈øland of ≈øuch a curb: When as the I≈ølanders having notice of what had happened, came to meet them with branches of Palms and Garlands
in their hands, ≈øtileing them their deliverers, and animating them to de≈øtroy all the Lineage of the Tyrant; but e're the Prince arrived, they in great numbers a≈ø≈øaulted the Ca≈øtle, ≈øwearing to revenge the many injuries they had received on Collumbra, and the cur≈øed Kindred that yet remained; whereupon ≈øhe being in great di≈øtre≈øs, and expecting the Rabble every moment would force the Gates open, and ≈øhew her no mercy, ≈øhe ≈øent a Damzel of hers out through a private Vault, to fall at the Prince's feet, and implore him to take her into his protection, not ≈øuffering her to fall into the hands of the multitude; when as the Prince con≈øidering ≈øhe was a woman, and that ≈øhe would be greatly outraged, interpo≈øed with the people, promi≈øing them that ≈øhe ≈øhould for the future be ≈øo well ≈øecured, as never after to injure them; whereupon in a ≈øhort time they were ≈øo well pacified, that they drew off; when as the Prince and his Companions entring, found in a great Hall the di≈øcon≈øolate Collumbra, overwhelmed in tears, greatly bewailing her many misfortunes, and wi≈øhing to dye, which moved the Prince to ≈øuch compa≈ø≈øion, that he began rather to comfort than rebuke her, for her many Tyrannies, and cruel Intentions again≈øt her Brother. Yet to keep his word with the people, and to pre≈øerve her from their fury after his departure, he cau≈øed her, and her Damzels, who were not unwilling to be conveyed on Ship-board: And then having ≈øetled the I≈øland, though refu≈øing the Soveraignty thereof, which was earne≈øtly pre≈ø≈øed upon him, he imbarqued for Con≈øtantinople; having fir≈øt promi≈øed to ≈øend the people ≈øuch a Governour, as ≈øhould greatly advance their felicity.

div.head: CHAP. LII.

argument.p: What happened to Prince Palmerin, after his departure from the Profound-I≈øland.

div.p: THe Prince having ≈øetled the Affairs to the content of the I≈ølanders, di≈ømi≈ø≈øed ≈øage Aliart in one Ve≈ø≈øel, and with another that he found in the Port, accompanied with Berolde, and Platire, he Coa≈øted ≈øo long, that in the end he fell in with another I≈øland, called, The Perillous I≈øland; where going on ≈øhore, he found it well peopled, and very opulent: For after the Inchantre≈øs Eutrope was dead, by the Adventurous Prince's means, divers of the I≈ølanders belonging to the adjacent I≈ølands, flocked thither, by rea≈øon of the fertilety of the place, and mightily improved it.

Here the Prince going on ≈øhore, knew by the many Monuments, that was the place in which he had undergone ≈øuch danger; and carrying his Companions from place to place, he (to their great admiration) ≈øhewed and related the many ≈øtrange Encounters, but e≈øpecially that of the Fountain, where they found lying the bones of the Bea≈øts he had ≈ølain; and at the Ca≈øtle the Shield which (as a Trophie) he cau≈øed the ≈øubdued Knight to hang up, as a Memorial of that Adventure: The which done, they pa≈ø≈øed in a fair Garden, repleni≈øh'd with all the Pride of Flora, and adorned with Fruits, ≈øo lovely to the Eye, that a rarer ≈øight could not be found; when in the mid≈øt thereof there ≈øtood a Cry≈øtal Fountain, imbo≈ø≈øed with Silver Sculptures of many Stories, and rare Device. But whil≈øt they were mu≈øing and admiring it, (to ≈øhew that all the Enchantment was not fini≈øhed) like an Exaltation up there ≈øprang a ≈øtately Fabrick, ≈øeeming to the Eye of Lucent Stones, and Ma≈ø≈øy Gold, the Gates wide open, yet guarded by two mon≈øtrous forms, between them ≈øtanding an Image of
Gold; when to ≈øee this Rarity all flocked, but were with≈øtood entrance with many terrible bla≈øts, which overthrew ≈øuch as approached; till the Prince (ordained to fini≈øh great Adventures) advancing, went to the Image, and took a Golden Key out of its hand; whereupon the Gyants vani≈øhed: So that entering the Man≈øion, and opening (as they ≈øuppo≈øed) divers Doors, at length they came to a fair Clo≈øet, hung round with Pictures of the rare≈øt Beautys in the World, ≈øo lively, that at fir≈øt they ≈øtarted, each ≈øuppo≈øing to have ≈øeen his Mi≈øtri≈øs there. But long they contemplated not thereon, before a dreadfull murmuring was heard, and in≈øtantly a Clap of Thunder breaking o're this Airy Man≈øion, it vani≈øhed in a Fla≈øh of Lightening, leaving the Spectators in con≈øternation and amazement; when well con≈øidering it was the device of ≈øome Magician, they immediately imputed it to ≈øage Aliart, or Urgandia, who had erected it to plea≈øe them; and ≈øo con≈øidering about other affairs, they returned to the Ca≈øtle; when as a number of the Inhabitants knowing the Prince to be him that had fini≈øhed the Enchantment of Eutrope, came to congratulate his ≈øecond Arrival, and offer him the Homage of the Country, which he would not accept in Per≈øon, but allotted it to the ≈øage Aliart, who ≈øoon after took po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, in the Name of the Emperor of Con≈øtantinople.

Then the Prince, de≈øirous to leave that place, took his farewel of his companions, and embarqued with his E≈øquire, who by this time having notice of his Adventure in the Profound-I≈øland, was come to him. When in ≈øearch of new Adventures I ≈øhall for a while leave him and the re≈øt, and return to Con≈øtantinople.

div.head: CHAP. LIII.

argument.p: How the News of what had hapened arrived at Con≈øtantinople: And what befell the Gyante≈øs Collumbra and Alfernao.

div.p: WHile≈øt the Court of Con≈øtantinople was in great ≈øu≈øpence for the ab≈øence of the Princes, nothing but Clouds of ≈øorrow appeared on every Face; but long that ob≈øcurity of Mirth and Iollitry la≈øted not, before News was brought, how the Treachery of Alfernao was defeated; and that Prince Florian, who had in his company Arleucea, was ≈øafe in Spain, intending in his way to that Court, to vi≈øit the Ca≈øtle of Almorol; ≈øo that upon certain notice thereof, the Clouds vani≈øhed, and re≈øtored the face of things as formerly. Yet Leonarda could not tell what to think, that her entertained Servant had ≈øoon betaken him≈øelf to a fre≈øh Beauty; but above all, ≈øhe feared lea≈øt he ≈øhould be Captivated by the eyes of Miragarda, of whom Fame had every where ≈øo well ≈øpoken, celebrating her for the mo≈øt accompli≈øh'd Beauty upon Earth: But being comforted by her dear Companion and Confidant, the beautious Prince≈øs Polinarda, ≈øhe lo≈øt her fears, and re≈øted a≈ø≈øured of his worth and vertue; in requital extolling the Deeds of Prince Palmerin above the Skies.

Whil≈øt matters were at this pa≈øs, news was brought that the Gyante≈øs Collumbra was arrived as a Pri≈øoner, to be di≈øpo≈øed of at the plea≈øure of the Emperor; upon which Orders were given to introduce her: But ≈øuch was her large and mon≈øtrous ≈øize, that the Ladies at her fir≈øt approach looked pale, and ≈øtood agha≈øt; but ≈øeeing her in tears, and that ≈øhe had deformed her ≈øelf with her Nailes and violent blows, wi≈øhing rather to dye than live, after the lo≈øs of her Progeny; they commi≈øerated her, and began to intercede on her behalf, till ≈øuch time as they were acquainted with the cruelties ≈øhe had
u≈øed, and what devices ≈øhe had laid for the Lives of the Princes: Whereupon after ≈øhe had been long examined, and confe≈ø≈øed each particular, ju≈øtifying what ≈øhe did as legal, and that ≈øhe ≈øtill would do it, was it in her power, cur≈øing Fortune, and the ≈øeni≈øter Stars that ruled her Birth, for rendring her ≈øo wretched and unfortunate: So ≈øhe was conducted to a Chamber, and a Guard ≈øet on her, lea≈øt ≈øhe ≈øhould offer violence to her ≈øelf. But whil≈øt they were di≈øcour≈øing with each other, armed with fury and a deep de≈øpair, ≈øhe tore the Bar out of the Window, and by that means having made room for her va≈øt body, ≈øhe ca≈øt her ≈øelf out, when falling on the Pavement, ≈øhe with the fall extingui≈øhed life, to the grief of the Emperor, and all the Ladys of the Court.

Alfernao in his Confinement hearing of what had hapened, and finding him≈øelf (through his Trea≈øon) faln into di≈øgrace and contempt, at the ≈øame time fearing he ≈øhould be brought before the Emperor, and there be ≈øharply puni≈øhed for his treacherous di≈ø≈øimulation, he took a Do≈øe of Poy≈øon, which he u≈øually carried about him to mi≈øchief others, and ≈øo in Death followed his Friend and old Companion Collumbra.

div.head: CHAP. LIV.

argument.p: How King Polendos, and the Knights that were made Pri≈øoners being ≈øet at Liberty, arrived at Con≈øtantinople: And how Prince Florian, with his Ladys, arrived at the Court of Spain; and what in≈øued.

div.p:
NOW whil≈øt the Court was filled with compa≈ø≈øion for the unfortunate end of the≈øe Per≈øons, the Emperor was informed, That four Turki≈øh Galleys were arrived in the Port; which made him conjecture (as indeed it was true) that the Turk, at the In≈øtance of his Daughter, had ≈øent home King Belcar, and the re≈øt of the
Captive Knights; upon notice of which he was ≈øo overjoyed, that mounting on Hor≈øeback, he with ≈øuch of his Nobles as were at hand, pa≈ø≈øed to the Port, where he found them about to land, which gladed him beyond mea≈øure; but their countenances were ≈øo changed by the growing of their Beards and ill u≈øage, that but by their Voices, he could not have known them; yet taking them in his Arms, he imbraced them with tears, not ≈øuffering them to kneel before him, as they were about to do; but having a Charriot at hand, cau≈øed them to enter thereinto, by rea≈øon of their weak e≈øtate, and ≈øo conveyed them to the Court, where they were highly welcomed with loud acclamations, and the ≈øound of Drums, Trumpets, and Clarions, and fea≈øted in a mo≈øt plentifull manner, the better to recover their faded ≈øtrength. But in the mid≈øt of this Iollitry the Emperor had notice, that Almancer the Turki≈øh Emba≈ø≈øador, was on board the Admirals Gally with a Charge from his Lord: Wherefore the Emperor ≈øent a great Train to de≈øire his Landing, and to conduct him in the be≈øt manner to the Court; but he refu≈øed it, ≈øaying, He would not come on ≈øhore till the en≈øuing Day; with which an≈øwer they returned to the Emperor, who ordered great preparations for his reception again≈øt the morrow, inquiring in the mean time of King Polendos, and the re≈øt, how they had fared, and by what means they were delivered? When in the name of all, the King made this Reply: That they had been hardly dealt with by the Infidel; and that many times their Lives were in danger, by rea≈øon Prince Florian was not ≈øent, but through the ince≈ø≈øant Prayers, Teares, and Intreaty of fair Targiana, they had at la≈øt obtained their liberty.

Time ≈øliding apace, the weary Courtiers de≈øired repo≈øe, whereupon every one retired to his chamber, till light (awakened by circling houres) began to dawn, when as (not unmindful of the entertainment due to the Emba≈ø≈øador) they clothed them≈øelves in rich attire, cau≈øing many co≈øtly Pageants and goodly ≈øights to be erected: When as Polendos, Belcar, and the re≈øt of the returned Knights, with many others, arriving at
the Port, entered a Barge, and rowed to his Gally ≈øide, and there received him with many Complements, and from thence rowed him to the ≈øhore, all the Ayr being filled with ≈øounds of Harmony; when coming to the Court, he was conducted by King Polendos, and Prince Primaleon, before the Chair of State, where the Emperor was ≈øeated in his Emperial Robes; when after complements on either ≈øide pa≈ø≈øed, and the Emba≈ø≈øador had taken his place, he fir≈øt delivered his Letters, Credentials, under the Ottoman Seal; after which he thus began:

Know, Mo≈øt Pui≈ø≈øant Emperor, that from the Mighty Ottoman Emperor (my Lord and Ma≈øter) I am ≈øent to ≈øalute you in his Name, and to give you knowledge, that his Emperial Diadem has been ≈øtained, and its bright dazling Lu≈øtre much impaired, by the Indignity offered him, in the Per≈øon of his Daughter, conveyed from his Court by Florian, a Knight of your Court: Wherefore, if you expect Peace at his hands, it can be pre≈øerved at no other rate, than by delivering him up to be de≈øervedly puni≈øhed, who has offered ≈øuch in≈øolence to his Turki≈øh Maje≈øty, as to give the World occa≈øion of di≈øcour≈øe, and blot the Name of that fair Lady, who is the ≈øolace of his Life.
This having ≈øaid, he ended; and the Emperor made this reply:

Know, Sir, I am de≈øirous of your Lords friend≈øhip, and ≈øeek not War in my declining years, but rather wi≈øh to ≈øpend the ≈ømall remainder of my life in Peace, therefore expected no ≈øuch Command to be layed on me, which (if I judge aright) is to no other end de≈øign'd, then to create a new ground for War: If ≈øo, I might more ju≈øtly ≈øeek Revenge for the injury and ingratitude my Knights have ≈øu≈øtained in recompence of my Commands and their good will. As for the Prince≈øs, I own my ≈øelf obl ‚Ä¢ ged to her for their deliverance; but for the injury offer'd her by Florian, I ≈øee none, ≈øince with her Fathers leave (without compul≈øion) ≈øhe left the Court, and cho≈øe the Prince to be her Guard, and was as honourably received
at my Court, as ≈øhe could be regarded in her Fathers. As for the Prince you ≈øpeak of, though he is my Grand≈øon, yet he is not my Subject; nor can I compel free minds, if that I would; but ≈øurely rather than I would deliver him up to your Ma≈øters Rage, (were it in my power, and he would con≈øent) I'de freely hazard my Empire in Fortunes chance: And now you have my An≈øwer, you may ≈øtay and have the Freedom of my Court, or depart at Plea≈øure.

The Emperor thus ending, with a Maje≈øtick frown greatly di≈ømayed the Amba≈ø≈øador, who without replying was about to retire to his Gallys, but that the Princes ≈øtayed him to make merry, and received the Emperors Letter, to which he con≈øented; and ≈øo after three days tarryance, he returned to him that ≈øent him; where I ≈øhall leave him, and return to Prince Florian.

The Prince, with his Troop of Ladies, having reached the Court of Spain; ≈øent his E≈øquire to the King and Queen, to implore them that they would permit the Knights of their Court to Iu≈øt again≈øt a ≈øtrange Knight, in the behalf of their Ladies, for that he would maintain the Beauty of tho≈øe that accompanied him again≈øt any of the Court-Ladies, if ≈øo be it any Knights dur≈øt maintain the contrary. The King, who had delighted from his Youth in Feats of Arms, appeared no way aver≈øe, but rather de≈øired that the Valour of his Knights ≈øhould be tryed, whereupon he di≈ømi≈ø≈øed the E≈øquire with a promi≈øe that his Ma≈øters reque≈øt ≈øhould on the morrow be granted, and that for that night Lodgings ≈øhould be provided for him and his Lady. The Prince having now an opportunity to try his force again≈øt the feeble Knights of Spain, made no doubt but by his Prowe≈øs to Eclip≈øe the Glory of that Court, in Honour of the Emperor, and therefore returned King Recinde great thanks.

The night being ≈øpent in Mirth and Iollitry, the next morning they prepared for the Li≈øt, the Trumpets loudly ≈øounding thereto, which awakened the Knights; when mounting their Steeds, they advanced, and found the Prince
in the Li≈øt; whereupon a Spani≈øh Knight, in white Armour, with a wounded Heart in his Shield, confronted him, at what time the Prince ≈øent to acquaint him, That if him≈øelf was conquored, the Knight ≈øhould chu≈øe from among≈øt his Train the mo≈øt beautifull Damzel; but if he vanqui≈øhed the Knight, he would have his Mi≈øtri≈øs, and therefore required him to a≈ø≈øign her; to which the Knight who≈øe Name was Gonzales, ≈øent this Reply; That he doubted not but the ≈øtrange Knight was weary of his Female Company, and therefore came to put them off at any rate; but as for his Mi≈øtri≈øs, his power was ≈øo little over her, that ≈øhe was alltogether at her own di≈øpo≈øal. This an≈øwer ≈øo di≈øplea≈øed the Prince, that he gave ≈øignal for the Iu≈øt, without any conditions: When running furiou≈øly at each other, the Spani≈øh Knight was thrown from his Hor≈øe, with his Heels upwards, which ≈øo grieved him, that he required the Combat of the Sword, which the Prince as readily granted, but the King forbad it: Yet a ≈øecond Knight running again≈øt the Prince, fared no better, and ≈øo a third, till all his Launces were broken, ≈øo that he was obliged to intreat of the King a new ≈øupply, and with them had the Iu≈øt ≈øix houres, none being able to unhor≈øe him, which ≈øore aba≈øhed the King, to ≈øee his Knights di≈øgraced, and the Fame of his Court Eclip≈øed by one Knight, in≈øomuch that he repented he had granted the di≈øport, and thereupon for that day cau≈øed it to cea≈øe, intending it ≈øhould be no more; but upon the intreaty of ≈øome Knights, that upon the fame of the Exerci≈øe newly arrived there, it was renewed the next day; when as the Spani≈øh Knights fared no better than the day before, which cooled their courage.

Matters going thus, the Prince re≈øolved to depart to the Ca≈øtle of Almorol the next morning, of which Arleucea having notice, watching her opportunity, when her companions were a≈øleep, ≈øhe ≈øtole into the Prince's Lodging-Chamber, where a Taper was burning, and ≈øitting down upon his Bed-≈øide, began to ≈øigh out her pa≈ø≈øion in this order:

O unfortunate that I am! How am I captivated in the ≈ønares of Love, and forced to do at upon the Man that ≈ølights my pa≈ø≈øion? O that I had never ≈øeen his face, unle≈øs he would have more regarded me, and pittied the Feavour that con≈øumes me. This ≈øaid, ≈øhe began to weep tenderly; whereupon the Prince awaking, wondered to ≈øee a woman in his Chamber, but by the light di≈øcovering who it was; and ≈øhe ≈øtill continuing her lamentations, he comforted her in the be≈øt wi≈øe, promi≈øing that allthough him≈øelf intended not to marry her, yet he would be≈øtow her upon ≈øuch a Husband, as ≈øhould plea≈øe her: This ab≈øolute denyal di≈øturbed her more than before, ≈øo that ca≈øting her Arms about the Prince, ≈øhe lay as one intranced for a pretty ≈øpace; but recovering hee ≈øen≈øes, and mode≈øt ba≈øhfulne≈øs, ≈øhe left him, and retired to her Chamber; where awaking one of her Damzels named Polephemia, ≈øhe imparted to her the Secrets of her Heart, de≈øiring her to go to the Prince, and per≈øwade him that night to receive her into his Arms, and ≈øatisfie the de≈øires of a longing Virgin. But this Damzel, who was the ≈øame that put the inchanted King upon the Prince's finger, having the opportunity of being alone with him ≈øolicited her own (in≈øtead of her Ladies) cau≈øe ≈øo long, that he having born her good-will ever ≈øince he fir≈øt beheld her, laying niceties a≈øide, ≈øo dealt with her, that to both their contents he po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed her Virgin Trea≈øure, and ≈øent her blithe and gay with Loves refre≈øhments, when the morning dawn, to carry Cordial words to her di≈øcon≈øolate Lady, who little ≈øu≈øpected what had pa≈ø≈øed, yet de≈øired no greater happine≈øs.

In the morning early the Prince and his beautiful Female Troop taking leave of the King, Queen, and Court-Ladies, departed towards the Ca≈øtle of Almorol; but coming into a plea≈øant Valley before them, they beheld a Knight of a mon≈øtrous ≈ølye come riding on a Hor≈øe greater than Beaucephalus, with two E≈øquires of his attendance: When coming near the Prince, and beholding the Ladies, he rudely layed hold of Arleucea, ≈øwearing ≈øhe ≈øhould hear him company, and that two
others ≈øhould be allotted to his E≈øquires: This rough and un≈øeemly action ≈øo moved the Prince, that drawing his Sword, he came at him to revenge the Injury, which the Knight (or rather Gyant) perceiving, let go his hold, and drawing his Ma≈ø≈øy Blade, a dreadfull Combat began; but ≈øo eager was the Prince to revenge the affront, that the Gyant received many wounds, till in the end fainting, through the lo≈øs of blood, he fell; when taking off his Helmet, the Prince being about to ≈ømite off his Head, his E≈øquires fell on their Knees, and with tears begged him to ≈øpare their Lords Life, which the Ladyes perceiving, interceded ≈øo much on his behalf, that the Prince was contented to ≈øpare his Life, conditionally, that he would tell his Name, and go to the Court of Spain, and there relate what had befallen him; both which he ≈øwore to do, ≈øaying, He was called Trofolant the Fearfull; And as for the other part of his Oath, though it would redound much to his di≈øgrace, yet would he faithfully perform it: Whereupon he was ≈øuffered to depart.

The Prince having cha≈øti≈øed the in≈øolency of the Gyant, pa≈ø≈øed on till he met three Knights, compleatly armed, pa≈ø≈øing a little River, who e≈øpying one Knight conducting ≈øo many Ladyes, agreed among≈øt them≈øelves to take each of them one; whereupon coming up, one cho≈øe Arleucea, another Poliphemia, and the third Arte≈øia; Nay, Gentlemen, ≈øaid the Prince, you mu≈øt fir≈øt ask my leave, which (a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelves) you will not obtain, e're any of the≈øe Ladys fall to your ≈øhare. That needs not, ≈øaid one of the Knights, for we will be our own Carvers; yet (tru≈øt me) we will ≈øo kindly u≈øe the Ladys, that they ≈øhall have no cau≈øe to repent the change. I ≈øee (≈øaid the Prince) you are re≈øolutely bent to le≈ø≈øen my Train, if po≈ø≈øible, therefore prepare to win them, and they are freely yours, for unle≈øs you purcha≈øe them at the price of my overthrow, you mu≈øt not expect to have them.

The words of the Prince greatly plea≈øing the Knights,
they began to contemn his force, and vaunt of their own Valour beyond mea≈øure; but ≈øo it happened, that in the Iu≈øt they were all overthrown, and remitted for a puni≈øhment of their pre≈øumption to the Ladies they had claimed, who injoyned them to tell their Names, and go to the Court of Spain, as had the Gyant, and there (in the pre≈øence of the King and his Knights) declare what had befallen them, and by who≈øe hand; to which with a mournful voice one of them replyed: That allthough the Sentence was ≈øevere, yet ≈øeeing it was their misfortune to be conquored, they would not decline it; As for our Names, ≈øaid he, I am called Grovanel, this other Knight is my Brother Brabazan, and the third Claribard; all of us Knights of the Spani≈øh Court, which makes us the lother to make our di≈øgrace publique there; yet upon the Oaths of our Knighthood, ≈øeeing the Ladys have injoyned it, it ≈øhall be performed: And thereupon the Prince di≈ømi≈ø≈øed them, and kept on his way towards the Ca≈øtle of the Gyant Almorol.

div.head: CHAP. LV.

argument.p: Of the Gyant and three Knights arrival at the Court of Spain: And of the arrival of Prince Florian at the Ca≈øtle of the Gyant Almorol; and what en≈øued thereon.

div.p: THe Gyant Trofolant (according to his Oath) arriving at the Court of Spain, after admittance had to the Kings pre≈øence, began to declare the occa≈øion of his coming, and tell the whole matter, which did not a little perplex the King to know who the Knight with the Damzels was; but whil≈øt the doubt la≈øted, the other Knights came in, and became Relaters of their own misfortunes, which ≈øtill increa≈øed the wonder, and ≈øomewhat le≈ø≈øened the di≈øgrace of tho≈øe Knights that had been overthrown in the pre≈øence of their Ladies, but in the end they concluded it mu≈øt be one of the invincible Sons of Prince Don Edoard, and thereupon re≈øted them≈øelves ≈øatisfied as well as they could.

The Prince riding on in the company of his Ladies, travelled ≈øo long, that he came within ≈øight of Almorol's Ca≈øtle, when to his beautifull Companions he thus began: Ladies know that we approach the Ca≈øtle where dwells the fair Miragarda, who≈øe Beauty is famed for excellent throughout the World, therefore agree among≈øt your ≈øelves who≈øe Banner I ≈øhall fight under: when as a murmure aro≈øe among≈øt them, every one thinking her ≈øelf the faire≈øt, till Poliphemia, who had a wonderfull conceit of her beauty, thus broke ≈øilence: Sir Knight, if you fight under Beauty's Banner, it behoves you to be loyal and con≈øtant in your Love, for I per≈øwade my ≈øelf, if the Knight that protects the Shield of Miragarda was not ≈øo, Fortune would not favour him as ≈øhe does, for we cannot believe but ≈øome of us are as beautifull as ≈øhe; therefore if you are unfortunate in the Enterprize, attribute it to your
uncon≈øtancy, and not to the Defect of our Beauty. The Prince hearing her ≈øay thus much, could not refrain ≈ømiling to think of the e≈øteem ≈øhe had of her ≈øelf, and what had pa≈ø≈øed between them; yet giving her and the re≈øt many Complements, they at la≈øt came to the River The≈øin, that encompa≈ø≈øed the Ca≈øtle, on which they beheld Miragarda and her Damzels in a Boat, who≈øe beauty was ≈øo excellent, that it had well nigh conquored the Prince, but he who was alltogether uncon≈øtant in Love, ≈øoon ≈øhook off her Chaines.

The Prince had not long ≈øtayed before the Ca≈øtle, but Florendos ≈øent his E≈øquire to him, to acquaint him with the cu≈øtom of the Ca≈øtle; Nay, (≈øaid Prince Florian) tell thy Lord I am very well acquainted with the cu≈øtom, and came hither on purpo≈øe to break a Launce with the Guardian of Miragarda's Beauty: Vpon notice whereof Florendos advanced, and prepared for the Iu≈øt; but the Prince (not de≈øirous to injure his Kin≈øman) declared that he would not undertake the Combat of the Sword, but came to ≈øhew his Ladys Pa≈øtime, not being Emulus to bereave him of his tru≈øt; whereupon Florendos ≈øaluted him, and was de≈øirous to know his Name, but he refu≈øed, ≈øo that the Iu≈øt began with great vehemency; yet ≈øuch was the regard that Florian had for his Nephew, that he would not di≈øgrace him in the fight of his Lady, who ≈øtood in the Window to behold the Iu≈øts, whereupon they broke three Launces without any advantage, which ≈øo inraged Florendos, (who was alltogether ignorant of his Adver≈øaries ≈øtrength) that he would have tryed the Combat of the Sword, but Prince Florian with gentle words per≈øwaded him to the contrary, de≈øiring that that might be referred to Almorol the Gyant, again≈øt whom he was de≈øirous to try his ≈øtrength; which made the Ladies that bore him company to ≈ømile, mi≈ø-doubting the Courage of their mo≈øt valiant Knight.

Almorol having notice that the combat was required again≈øt him, went to his fair Mi≈øtri≈øs, and required her con≈øent, who (becau≈øe the Iu≈øts were not decided) accorded to his
Reque≈øt; whereupon the Gyant came forth, and defied Prince Florian to the combat of the Sword, who (now at liberty to u≈øe his full ≈øtrength) greatly rejoyced; in≈øomuch that the combatants being in a readine≈øs, charged each other ≈øo furiou≈øly, that wounds were received on both ≈øides, but the Prince (whom Fortune ever favoured) brought the Gyant to his mercy, yet would not injure his Life, allthough in his power, but ≈øuffered him to be carryed off, and his wounds to be healed, having ingaged, that if him≈øelf had been overcome, to have be≈øtowed Arleucea in Marriage upon the Gyant.

During the time that Florendos and the attendants of the Ca≈øtle were carrying off the Gyant, and looking to his wounds, two Knights came riding up to the Shield of Miragarda, and laying hold on it, would have conveyed it thence, but Prince Florian, ob≈øerving his Rin≈øman to be ab≈øent, forbad them on their peril, yet they regarded not his Menaces, but dared him to the combat to defend it; whereupon he prepared him≈øelf for the Iu≈øt, and ran one of them with a ≈øtrong Staff through the Body, and layed the other on the Earth; by which time Florendos was arrived, greatly di≈øplea≈øed that the Iu≈øt ≈øhould be performed in his ab≈øence; but when he knew that his Kin≈øman Florian had done him that ≈øervice, he greatly rejoyced, and would have conducted him into the Ca≈øtle, but could not per≈øwade him to ≈øtay, for that he had promi≈øed to return to the Court of Spain, to give tho≈øe Knights a further ≈øatisfaction of his Prowe≈øs; whereupon taking leave, he departed with his Female Train, every one of which ≈øtriving to be highe≈øt in his favour.

But far he had not rode e're he heard the piteous ≈øhreiks of a Lady on the other ≈øide of a River, and becau≈øe he could not conveniently come nearer, by rea≈øon of the depth of the water, he unarmed him≈øelf and ca≈øt it over, when-leaving the Ladies he had in guard, he ≈øwam cro≈øs the Flood, and entering the Thicket, beheld a Knight forcing a Damzel, whil≈øt another Knight was binding her E≈øquire to a Tree; which unmanly
abu≈øe, ≈øo inraged the Prince, that he commanded them upon pain of Death to de≈øi≈øt, but they being two to one ≈øeemed little to regard his threats, though afterwards they repented it: For the Prince being inraged at ≈øo great a wickedne≈øs as they were about to commit, having given them leave to put them≈øelves in a po≈øture of defence, charged them with ≈øuch fury, that he layed one of them breathle≈øs, and brought the other to his mercy, obligeing him to ask the Lady forgivene≈øs, and taking an Oath of him, to go to the Court of Spain, and make report of his Villany, and what had befallen him; and ≈øo unbinding the Damzels E≈øquire, he pa≈ø≈øed along the Bank of the River till he found a place fordable, over which he pa≈ø≈øed with the Lady and her E≈øquire, demanding the cau≈øe why they u≈øed ≈øuch violence, and how ≈øhe came to meet with them? to which ≈øhe an≈øwered, That being a Damzel, Attendant upon the Prince≈øs Miragarda, ≈øhe obtained leave to go to the Court of Spain, to vi≈øit her friends, when as the≈øe Knights having been foiled at the Ca≈øtle of Almorol, to revenge that di≈øgrace, re≈øolved (upon their knowing who I was) to deprive me of my Honour, having ca≈øt Lots who ≈øhould have the fir≈øt E≈ø≈øay, and had ≈øucceeded in their Wickedne≈øs, had not kind Heaven happily ≈øent you to my re≈øcue.

The Damzel had ≈øcarce ended, when an Out-cry and Female Shreiks was heard, when the Prince looking up, beheld a Knight with Arleucea behind him, riding as fa≈øt as po≈ø≈øible away with her; whereupon he ha≈øtened to recover his Hor≈øe, which done, he rode after him, crying, Stay Uncourteous, and be cha≈øtized for the In≈øolence you have offered to a Lady under my protection: Whereat the Knight turning about in great fury, ≈øet down the Lady, ≈øaying, He would be revenged for ≈øuch his bold interruption; whereupon drawing his Sword, he advanced, but received ≈øuch a welcome, that after ≈øix or ≈øeven exchanged blows, the Prince brought him under, and would have taken off his Head, but that he begging for life, Arleucea pittyed him and interceded on his behalf,
yet made him ≈øwear to go to the Court of Spain, as the other had done, and there make his Confe≈ø≈øion, and own what had befallen him, and not for the future to bear Arms, unle≈øs the Ladies of that Court would permit him ≈øo to do; which done, he departed in great heavine≈øs; and ≈øoon after both he and all the re≈øt performed their vows, to the glory of the Prince, and their own ≈øhame.

div.head: CHAP. LVI.

argument.p: How Prince Florian returned to the Court of Spain, and thence departed to the Ca≈øtle of Arnalte, and what befell him.

div.p:
PRince Florian having hitherto ≈øecured his Ladies from all injury, brought them once more to the Court of Spain, where upon their arrival they were received by the King and Queen with many expre≈ø≈øions of Ioy, but he greatly envied by divers other Knights, whom he had foiled, wherefore they ≈øtirred up ≈øuch Knights as were newly come, to try with him the Iu≈øt, and combat for his Ladies; of which number, Lu≈øtramar, Grandian, and Arpiam undertook it, but were mi≈øerably foiled; wherefore the King would not ≈øuffer any more of his Knights to enter the Iu≈øt, but cau≈øed a ≈øumptuous Fea≈øt to be made, obligeing the Prince and his Ladies to ≈øit with him at the Table: When he being unarmed, (which was the Kings policy to know him) appeared to be Florian of the De≈øart, Son to Prince Edoard; whereupon the King embraced him, as afterwards did the Queen, and all the Chief
Nobility, in ≈øuch a manner, that great was the Court; the King declaring, that it was no di≈øgrace to be foiled by ≈øuch a Knight.

But having ≈øtayed there divers days, he re≈øolved to depart towards the Ca≈øtle of Arnalte Prince≈øs of Navar, to try the Adventure of the Ca≈øtle: Whereas his new acquired Ladies finding him uncon≈øtant in Love, were re≈øolved to leave him which he perceiving, was not at all di≈øcontented, for that they were continually wrangling among≈øt them≈øelves who was highe≈øt in his favour, in≈øomuch that they greatly di≈øturbed his quiet; ≈øo that departing with Arleucea and her Damzels, he left the re≈øt in the Spani≈øh Court, and rode towards Navar; when without meeting with any adventure, he came to the Ca≈øtle of the Prince≈øs Arnalte, where a Shield with her Picture hung upon a Tree, and was guarded by Dragolant Son to Duke Drapos of Normandy, as that of Miragarda was by Prince Florendos.

The Prince arriving at the Ca≈øtle, and being known by the Device of his Shield to the Prince≈øs, who bore him mortal hate for re≈øcuing his Brother, urged her Champion to de≈øtroy him, and that no le≈øs than him≈øelf ≈øhould be the Reward; which ≈øo exalted his mind, that he promi≈øed to bring the Prince bound, and lay him at her feet; in order to which he prepared him≈øelf, and came to the Iu≈øt; but before he began, commanded him to render him≈øelf and the Ladies in his Train to the plea≈øure of his Lady, at which the Prince ≈ømiling, made reply, That he exacted ≈øo largely, that he could not aquie≈øs with his demands, but if he could win them, they were then his own: Whereupon he retired to fetch the greater compa≈øs, when meeting with extraordinary force, their Launces were ≈øhivered, and both of them ≈øhook; but at the ≈øecond Cour≈øe Dragolant was tumbled from his Hor≈øe with his Heels upwards, which ≈øo inraged him, that he drew his Sword, and came towards the Prince, who (to be upon equal terms with him) alighted, and after a fierce combat of the Sword, brought him into ≈øuch a feeble condition, that he
fainting through wearine≈øs, wounds, and lo≈øs of blood, fell to the ground, which Arnalte (that had all the while beheld the combat) perceiving, came running in great ha≈øte, and begged his life of the Prince, who (upon condition ≈øhe would promi≈øe to marry the vanqui≈øhed Knight) promi≈øed to conde≈øcend to her reque≈øt; which ≈øhe perceiving, and con≈øidering the many Services of Dragolant, and that although Fortune at that time proved aver≈øe, yet he was a valiant Knight, con≈øented it ≈øhould be ≈øo; whereupon the Prince helped her and her Damzels to carry the Knight into the Ca≈øtle, where his wounds being dre≈ø≈øed, and he refre≈øhed with Cordials, he ≈øoon recovered, but was greatly grieved, as fearing he had greatly di≈øobliged the Saint he adored; but under≈øtanding what Conditions had been made on his behalf, (after having humbled him≈øelf before Arnalte, for her Gracious conde≈øcention) he with much endear affection embraced the Prince, giving a Thou≈øand thanks for the tender Regard he had of him: Whereupon the day for the Nuptials was appointed, and all things in order put, in≈øomuch, that great was the Solemnity in its Celebration; where in the height of Mirth and Iollitry I will leave Prince Florian, and proceed to relate the further Adventures of his Brother Palmerin.

div.head: CHAP. LVII.

argument.p: The Adventures of Prince Palmerin, after he left the Perilous-I≈øland.

div.p:
PRince Palmerin imbarquing, with onely Sylvian in his company, ≈øailed ≈øo long, that in the end he arrived upon the Coa≈øt of Scotland, where he went on ≈øhore, but had not travelled far e're he came to a Bridge that was guarded by a Knight in green Armour, with a Bulls Head in his Shield, which made the Prince gue≈øs him to be Pompides, whereupon he ≈øtayed to pau≈øe a while, when as he under≈øtood by the di≈øcour≈øe he had with a Damzel, that that Knight kept the Bridge for the love he beareth to Armi≈øia, Daughter to Meliadus King of Scots: But whil≈øt he was con≈øidering whether he ≈øhould enter the combat again≈øt his Friend or forbear, a ≈øtrange Knight came proudly riding up, and offered to force the Bridge, but was ≈øtayed by Pompides, when ≈øoon the Encounter of the Launce began, in which the ≈øtrange Knight was di≈ømounted, and much brui≈øed in his fall, yet he drew his Sword, and came towards Pompides, which made him alight, ≈øo that between them a dreadfull Combat in≈øued, till at length the ≈øtrange Knight (through lo≈øs of blood) fainted, which Pompides perceiving, bid him yield and ≈øurrender him≈øelf to fair Armi≈øia, but with many proud words he refu≈øed, and began to charge on Pompides again with all his force, but in the end was totally vanqui≈øhed, having received many de≈øperate wounds; whereupon Pompides taking off his Helmet, told him, That ≈øince he would not fairly yield to his reque≈øt, he ≈øhould now be compelled to beg the Prince≈øs pardon, and reveal his Name; but he again refu≈øed to do either, ≈øaying, He would ≈øooner dye in the place, than ca≈øt him≈øelf upon the mercile≈øs Cruelty of Armi≈øia: The≈øe words
made Pompides ≈øu≈øpect the Knight to be Adra≈øpe, Son to Duke Sizani, who ≈ølew the Prince Doriell, Brother to the Prince≈øs; whereupon he ≈øent to the Prince≈øs, to come thither, and pa≈øs her Sentence upon a Knight, that would not obey the cu≈øtom of the Bridge; who upon her arrival, with abundance of tears declared it was Adra≈øpe the Murtherer, to be revenged on whom the Bridge was ordained, earne≈øtly commanding Pompides to ≈øtrike off his Head: But whil≈øt he delayed, and was per≈øwading the Prince≈øs to more mildne≈øs, Prince Palmerin (who had beheld what had pa≈ø≈øed) came and joyned with Pompides in per≈øwading her, ≈øaying, It became a Noble nature to be kind and mercifull to the vanqui≈øhed, ≈øparing tho≈øe Lives that fortune or fate throws into their hands; but the Prince≈øs ≈øtill Iu≈øted (with a Rivolet of tears flowing from her eyes) that his Head might be taken off; but whil≈øt it was delayed, Adra≈øpe (through grief, ≈øhame, and lo≈øs of blood) dyed; yet ≈øo angry was the Prince≈øs, that ≈øhe was not obeyed, that ≈øhe flung away in a great rage, yet her pa≈ø≈øion being alayed, ≈øhe again came forth; and under≈øtanding Prince Palmerin was pre≈øent, ≈øhe invited him into her Hou≈øe, and related to him, How that Adra≈øpe once pretending Court≈øhip to her, upon her refu≈øing for his ill nature, became ≈øo trouble≈øome to her, that ≈øhe was obliged to acquaint her Brother Doriell with it, who ≈øharply rebuked him for his in≈øolence, which created in him ≈øuch a hatred again≈øt her Brother, that watching his opportunity, and taking him at a di≈øadvantage, he ≈ølew him, and retired to his Fathers Strengths in the High-lands, whereupon the King her Father, her ≈øelf, and the Peerage of the Kingdom, were brought into great heavine≈øs, and ordained that Bridge for Revenge, as well hoping that the haughty Adra≈øpe would out of a conceit of his Valour attempt; when to incourage my Knights again≈øt him, I pledged my ≈øelf as the price of his death; nor did our expectations fail: For often he came to upbraid me with my Brothers death, vanqui≈øhing and ≈ølaying divers of my Knights, till ≈øuch time as this good Knight came, who has
revenged my Brothers Murther: Therefore in requital I render my ≈øelf to be at his di≈øpo≈øal, and de≈øire you (Sir) to accompany us to my Fathers Court at Edenburg, where great will be the Ioy, upon notice of what has happened.

Vpon this Relation of Armi≈øia's the Prince highly approved of her undertaking, promi≈øing that ≈øhe ≈øhould be obeyed in all things: But Pompides, who had doated upon her Beauty, was ≈øo tran≈øported at what he heard, that he could not forbear expre≈ø≈øing him≈øelf in Rap≈øodies; yet attended with a Noble Train, they pa≈ø≈øed to the Scotch Court, where ≈øo great was the Ioy, that the like before had never happened. When the King being acquainted with the Conditions his Daughter had made, gladly accorded, in≈øomuch, that the Nuptials were celebrated with extraordinary Pomp and Royalty. After which the Prince taking leave of the Court, left Scotland, to go in ≈øearch of new Adventures, being de≈øirous of nothing more, than to be at Con≈øtantinople, there to have a ≈øight of her, for whom he underwent ≈øo many hazards.

div.head: CHAP. LVIII.

argument.p: How Prince Palmerin departing Scotland, after ≈øome conte≈øt by the way, arrived at Con≈øtantinople; and of the Adventure he had propo≈øed to him.

div.p: THE Prince having a≈ø≈øi≈øted at the Ceremony of his Friend Pompides, left him to ≈øport in the dear embraces of his lovely Bride; and taking leave of the Court, re≈øolved for Con≈øtantinople, to ≈øee what entertainment his beautious Mi≈øtri≈øs would give him; but by the way pa≈ø≈øing through many Countries, he met with divers Adventures, but none of them worthy of note, till he came into Hungary; where repo≈øing at a Fountain that ≈øtood by a Forre≈øt-≈øide, he beheld a Damzel in a di≈øtracted manner crying, and making piteous mean, when coming towards him, ≈øhe fell at his feet, and be≈øought him, To ≈øave her from an ill-natured and mon≈øtrous Gyant, that ≈øought to ≈ølay her; but ≈øhe had ≈øcarce time to utter the≈øe words before the Mon≈øter came puffing like a Cyclops, having almo≈øt ≈øpent him≈øelf with running, when with a dreadfull countenance he thus began:

Wretched Woman! You have betaken your ≈øelf to a feeble Protector, who≈øe Life you have likewi≈øe ca≈øt away, for had I not been directed to him in pur≈øuing you, I might have mi≈ø≈øed him; wherefore he has rea≈øon to cur≈øe you for his untimely fate. Nay, replyed the Prince, b ‚Ä¢ a≈øt not before you know who you have to deal with, for if my ≈øword fail me not, which failed me never, I ≈øhall ≈øoon let you ≈øee your error, a ‚Ä¢ d cha≈øtize your In≈øolence, in revenging the affront offered this Damzel. Whereupon a fierce combat in≈øued, which continued bloody and doubtfull for the ≈øpace of an hour, all which time the Damzel ≈øtood trembling in doubt whether to fly or attend the end of the combat; but in the end, Fortune favoured
the Prince ≈øo far, that ≈øtriking the Gyant between the Ioynts of his Harne≈øs, his Arm was parted by the Shoulder, yet fought he with the other Arm, till through lo≈øs of blood he fell down; whereupon the Prince parted his Head from his Body, and then under≈øtood by the Damzel, that it was Va≈øcalion, who ≈øought fir≈øt to ravi≈øh, and afterwards to put her to Death, becau≈øe ≈øhe belonged to the Prince≈øs Gridona, who≈øe Husband Primalion had ≈ølain Lucran his Father at Con≈øtantinople, when he entered the fight again≈øt him, in hopes to take from him his Prince≈øs.

The Prince having ridded the Damzel of her fears, accompanyed her to Con≈øtantinople, and then di≈ømi≈ø≈øed her, becau≈øe he would not pre≈øently be known, ≈øending his E≈øquire to take him a private Lodging for that night, that he might the better under≈øtand how affairs went in the Emperors Court; when as he had notice from a Knight that lodged in the ≈øame Hou≈øe, That one Arnolf a Gyant, and Lord of the A≈øtronomical-I≈øland, was come to defie the Knights of the Emperors Court, in hopes to find among≈øt them Florian of the Forre≈øt, that conveyed away Arleucea, whom he ≈øaid Bravorant her Father had betrothed to him before his death. This News was not a little joyful to the Prince, who by this means hoped to be re≈øtored to the favour of his fair Polinarda, to whom he re≈øolved to addre≈øs him≈øelf, not doubting but to recover her favour: So that the next morning mounting in di≈øgui≈øed Armour, and bearing in his Shield a Golden Tygar, he attended the Trumpets ≈øound, when as he beheld Arnolf highly mounted to enter the Li≈øt, yet he ≈øtayed to permit other Knights to Iu≈øt before him, that his Conque≈øt might be the more approved: And ≈øuch was the Gyants force, that although divers encountered him, they were thrown to the ground, and ≈øorely brui≈øed, and at the Combat of the Sword fared no better; whereupon the Gyant proudly prancing about the King, demanded If any dur≈øt find him yet more work? or, if none dur≈øt, he would report them Cowards through the world: This Braveado highly incen≈øed the Prince, ≈øo that
≈øetting Spurs to his Hor≈øe, he entered and confronted Arnolf, letting him know, That he came to cha≈øti≈øe his in≈øolence; and to inrage him the more, declared, That he was near Kin≈øman to Prince Florian, and would now undertake his Quarrel, but if Fortune declared again≈øt it, he would undertake Arleucea ≈øhould be put into his po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion.

The Gyant having heard the words of the Prince, between Ioy and Anger was greatly tran≈øported, in≈øomuch, that without reply he ≈øet Spurs to his Hor≈øe, which the Prince perceiving, did the like, and ran ≈øo forcibly again≈øt him, that he threw him to the ground, and was him≈øelf much ≈øhaken in his Saddle: This di≈øgrace greatly inraged Arnolf, in≈øomuch, that drawing his Sword, he came towards the Prince, when to be upon equal terms he di≈ømounted, ≈øo that between them a fierce Combat in≈øued, with great effu≈øion of Blood; for by the forcible blows their Armour was broken in divers places; whereupon the Emperor offered to part them, but they refu≈øed, ≈øaying, Nothing but Death or Conque≈øt ≈øhould decide; which greatly grieved the fair Polinarda, who from a Window beheld the fearfull Encounter, and more than ≈øu≈øpected her much-loved Lord was fighting in di≈øgui≈øe: Nor was it long e're he e≈øpyed her, and conjectured the cau≈øe of her fears, which put fre≈øh vigor into him, at ≈øuch a rate, as redoubling his force, he with a ≈øtroke full on his Cre≈øt, felled Arnolf to the ground, where (refu≈øing to beg his Life at the Prince's hands, and none interceeding for him) he was ≈ølain.

div.head: CHAP. LIX.

argument.p: How Palmerin di≈øcovered him≈øelf; and of his amorous Addre≈ø≈øes to the fair Polinarda.

div.p: THE Prince having (to the Ioy of the Court) ≈øubdued his Adver≈øary, was by the Emperors Command, conveyed into the Pallace, and unarmed, when to the high ≈øatisfaction, he appeared to be what he was, and the Emperor and all the Nobles embraced him, but nothing gave him ≈øo much content as the kind looks of his fair Polinarda, who was pre≈øent; yet ba≈øhfulne≈øs at that time made her di≈ø≈øemble her affection as well as ≈øhe could.

But the Prince having received divers wounds in the Combat, it was the opinion of his Chyrurgions, that he ought to retire to his Chamber, which he did, ≈øtudious in thought, how he might have an opportunity to conver≈øe with his beloved Polinarda: But whil≈øt his thoughts formed a Thou≈øand devices to accompli≈øh his de≈øire, Dramaciana a Virgin, attendant on the Prince≈øs, and her chief Confidant, came to vi≈øit him, being privately ≈øent by her Lady ≈øo to do, which did not a little revive him, in≈øomuch, that (having complemented her) he entered into di≈øcour≈øe with her, opening the ≈øecrets of his Heart, and de≈øiring her, That ≈øhe would without flattery inform him how ≈øhe found her Lady affected towards him; to which ≈øhe replyed: That he need not (if he had the Courage to pro≈øecute his Love in his proper Per≈øon) fear, but his de≈øires would be accompli≈øhed, for that ≈øhe had not failed in his ab≈øence to ≈øolicite his Sute, and did not find the Prince≈øs aver≈øe any further than Mode≈øty and a tender regard of her Honour re≈øtrained her. This News (like an Angels Voice) in a manner tran≈øported the Prince, but e≈øpecially when Dramaciana promi≈øed ≈øo to order the matter, that he ≈øhould be privately
conveyed into the Prince≈øs her Lodging, and lay open his mind before her, and that the time ≈øhould be at ≈øix of the Clock in the following Evening: And ≈øo taking her leave, ≈øhe went to obtain leave to perform her promi≈øe.

The Prince being in an exta≈øie of Ioy to think the Reward of all his Toiles were at hand, forgot his wounds, not regarding their ≈ømart, but attiring him≈øelf in the be≈øt manner, went at the time appointed, where he found a private door open, when pa≈ø≈øing through the Ante-chambers, he found the Prince≈øs (to his wi≈øh) reading alone, who at his approach aro≈øe blu≈øhing, and ≈øeemed ≈øomewhat di≈øcompo≈øed, as if ≈øhe had been ≈øurprized, (≈øuch Art has Woman, to ≈øeemingly neglect what they mo≈øt covet) which the Prince perceiving, bending with one Knee to the ground, with low ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion begged her pardon, if in thought he had offended, ≈øaying, That on her ≈ømiles or frowns his Life or Death depended; and that but her beautious ≈øelf, among≈øt all the Beauties that the Sun beheld, had power to make him happy or mi≈øerable: At which pau≈øing, and ≈øeeing the Prince≈øs ≈øtand aba≈øhed, he aro≈øe, and taking her by the fair hand, cau≈øed her to ≈øit, and fate him≈øelf down by her, ≈øtill holding her by the hand, when recollecting him≈øelf, he thus proceeded:

Beautious Lady, who≈øe fame has ≈øpread all Lands, behold the Man with pittyings who for your ≈øake has ≈øhunned no danger, but expo≈øed him≈øelf in every hazard that might advance your Renown; and now with low ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion implores that he may lay him≈øelf and his Trophies at your feet, ≈øince in≈øpired by you, his great Atchievements were performed; the force of your Tran≈øcendant Beauty more than any force in him acquired; His ≈ømall Renown a price too low to purcha≈øe ≈øuch a peerle≈øs Beauty; But con≈øidering (Madam) your great Goodne≈øs, and Compa≈ø≈øion, with boldne≈øs I pre≈øume to ask your Love, that ble≈ø≈øed Elizium of Tran≈øporting Rapture.
Thus having ≈øaid, again he pau≈øed, expecting his fair Mi≈øtri≈øs ≈øhould reply, who after ≈øtrugling long between ba≈øhfulne≈øs and true affection, thus broke ≈øilence:

Sir, that your Atchievements have been brave and great I own, and mu≈øt grieve to think, that for my ≈øake you ≈øhould have been expo≈øed to ≈øo many dangers, but know the fault is your own, for (certain 'tis) I would have had you ≈øtayed in my Father's Court, but (≈øeeing pa≈ø≈øed things cannot be recalled) I would not for the future have you hazard your ≈øelf for my ≈øake. And here ≈øhe ended; whereupon the Prince replyed.

p.hi: Madam, not for your ≈øake, ≈øay you, that I mu≈øt not hazard my ≈øelf? Know, thou onely center of my Love, no danger is too great to enterprize, if by acquiring it the lea≈øt Honour may redound to you, who (like a Godde≈øs) ought to have the fates of Nations in your hand, and be the Vniver≈øal Empre≈øs of Mankind: Con≈øider then, that ≈øuch a Love as mine (which burnes as bright as Phoebus gaudy fires) can think no Task too difficult, to plea≈øure her on whom it center: Therefore let me with ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion beg you let that re≈øt, and give your allmo≈øt di≈øpairing Servant ≈øome hopes to feed upon, that ≈øo his Life may for the future be di≈øcumbered of a Thou≈øand wracking Feares, and all the Tortures that can ≈øeize a doubtfull Lover's mind.

div.p: My Lord, replyed the Prince≈øs, you are not ignorant of the affection which with blu≈øhes I am con≈øtrained to own, yet mu≈øt con≈øider Princes Fames are tender, and the lea≈øt ≈øtroke ≈øoon wounds them, yet be a≈ø≈øured, I am your own, if the Emperor and my Father Primalion conde≈øcend; but if not; allthough I may have cau≈øe to grieve at their aver≈øne≈øs, yet mu≈øt I be ≈øo con≈øcious of my Honour, as not to pa≈øs the limmit of Obedience: Therefore take it for my full determination, if they Bar not the Gate to bli≈øs, I have no further argument again≈øt a Prince of ≈øo much merit.

This unexpected an≈øwer ≈øo exta≈øied the Prince, that (by rea≈øon of the tran≈øport of his ≈øen≈øes) he ≈øtood long time like one amazed, not being capable to utter his abundant joy, but gazing with eager eyes upon his lovely Love, till in the end Leonarda Prince≈øs of Thrace entering, cau≈øed the Prince (though much unwilling) to retire, having fir≈øt promi≈øed ≈øhe ≈øhould be obeyed.

div.head: CHAP. LX.

argument.p: How Man≈øia, Tor≈øia, Telan≈øia, and Latrania, four beautifull Ladyes of the French Court, ordained the Adventure of their re≈øpective Ca≈øtles, and what happened therein.

div.p:
ALL the Ladyes afore≈øaid being emulus of each others Beauty, and thinking it a di≈øgrace to have their Fame eclip≈øed, obtained leave of King Arneedes to erect four Ca≈øtles, and there cau≈øe Iu≈øts to be held by ≈øuch Knights as would undertake to defend their Beautys again≈øt all ≈øtrange Knights: Which being done, many Knights came thither, and tryed their fortunes, being greatly enamoured of the Ladyes, who would have their Knights try for each ≈øingly, not approving any vnited Force; when in the end Prince Floriman coming thither, and having a view of the fair Man≈øia, he became greatly enamoured of her, and undertook to defend her beauty again≈øt all that ≈øhould oppo≈øe him, performing ≈øo well, that he became Victor in all Encounters, till in the end Dramu≈øiand the Gyant arrived there, and undertook to defend the beauty of Tor≈øia, overthrowing Prince Floriman, but long injoyed not the Honour; For Prince Florian travelling towards Con≈øtantinople with Arleucea, and hearing of the Adventures of tho≈øe Ladyes, came thither and had a ≈øight of them, re≈øolving to enter the Combat for each of them, and ≈øo prevailed, that Dramu≈øiand and all the other Knights were wor≈øted; yet being much uncon≈øtant in love, he greatly regarded not the Prizes he had won, yet re≈øolved to ≈øtay there a while, that ≈øo he might increa≈øe his Renown, as indeed he did: For Iu≈øting again≈øt all that attempted the Adventure, he ≈øtill remained Victor; but being de≈øirous to be at Con≈øtantinople, as well to be pre≈øent with the fair Leonarda, as to coun≈øel and comfort the Emperor in what related to the ≈øtate of War,
threatned by the haughty Turk; whereupon taking leave of the four Ladyes, who were greatly enamoured of him, and loath to lo≈øe the company of ≈øo Renowned a Knight, he departed with Arleucea and her Damzels, and Dramu≈øiand (for the great love he bare him, but more to Arleucea) would needs accompany him; and ≈øo they rode on till they came near to Con≈øtantinople, where they had ≈øight of a gallant Troop of Knights and Ladyes, being not long ignorant that the Emperor was in, whereupon they rode up, and alighting, made their obedience, and were received with great Ioy; but ≈øcarcely had the Complements pa≈ø≈øed on either ≈øide, before a Knight attended by divers E≈øquires and Damzels approached, and de≈øired the Iu≈øt, which was granted, and fir≈øt undertaken by Bilizant, who in the fir≈øt Encounter was tumbled from his Hor≈øe, as likewi≈øe were two more, which Florian perceiving, prepared again≈øt the ≈øtrange Knight, but he knowing him by the device of his Shield, refu≈øed him, and ≈øent to acquaint the Emperor, that he was Dragolant, Son to Fri≈øol, who was come to his Court with Arnalte his e≈øpou≈øed Wife, and Queen of Navar; whereupon the Iu≈øts were cea≈øed, and they received with all expre≈ø≈øion of kindne≈øs, the fair Arnalte being conducted to the Pallace, upon her entring the City, by the Prince≈øs Polinarda, and Leonarda, ≈øo that ≈øumptuous Fea≈øts and Di≈øports were held for many dayes; but that which eclip≈øed the Ioy, was the News of King Fredrick of England's death, in who≈øe ≈øtead his Son Prince Don Edoard was Crowned.

div.head: CHAP. LXI.

argument.p: How Arnedes King of France, and Recinde King of Spain, came accompanyed with the Prince≈øs Miragarda and Almorol, to the Court of the Emperor; and of the celebration of divers Marriages.

div.p: THE Emperor Palmerin being ≈øtriken in Years, and de≈øirous before he dyed to ≈øee his Friends, and con≈øult them in relation to the Turki≈øh War, and other matters, he ≈øent for the Emperor of Almain, Don Edoard King of England, Recinde King of Spain, Arnedes King of France, and divers other Potentates, together with their Wives and Daughters, who obeyed his Summons, and were upon their arrivals highly entertained, with Fea≈øting, Mu≈øick, and all manner of Iollitry; upon notice of which, mo≈øt of the Knights that were abroad ≈øeeking Adventures, came thither, in≈øomuch, that the Court was full of the chief Chivalry of Europe. When after divers dayes pa≈ø≈øed in merriment, the Emperor (to Crown the general joy) called an A≈ø≈øembly of the Kings and Potentates, to know whether they would be≈øtow their beautifull Daughters in Marriage, upon ≈øuch Princes and Knights as long had loved and faithfully ≈øerved them? when finding none aver≈øe, and knowing the Knights and Ladyes were in the Court, (and opportunity, no time better to be taken) he took his Son-in-Law [King Edoard] a≈øide, and gave him command to divulge his plea≈øure, which he did in this manner.

KNights, and Ladyes, Renowned in Arms and Beauty throughout the World, be it known unto you; That the Pui≈ø≈øant and mo≈øt Renowned Emperor Palmerin, Emperor of all Grecia, has (in Con≈øideration of the many Glorious Atchievements) made it His Reque≈øt, That this Court may be Honoured with the Nuptials He de≈øires to be celebrated; He for His part, undertaking for the Princes, and His Empre≈øs, and her Ladyes, for the Prince≈ø≈øes and Ladyes.
Fir≈øt. 'Tis his Will, that Prince Florendos be made happy in the Embraces of fair Miragarda.
Secondly. That Prince Palmerin ≈øhould enjoy his beloved Polinarda
Thirdly. That Prince Gracian ≈øhould be ble≈ø≈øed with Claritia, Daughter to King Polendos.
Fourthly. That Prince Berolde ≈øhould Wedd fair Oni≈øtalda.
Fifthly. That Francian ≈øhould Match with Bernada.
Sixthly. That Prince Platire ≈øhould enjoy his fair Sidelia, Daughter to King Tarnaes of Lacedemon.
Seventhly. That to the Renowned Florian of the Forre≈øt, the beautifull Leonarda ≈øhould be E≈øpou≈øed.
Eighthly. That Don Rou≈øel, Son to Duke Belcar, ≈øhould have his beloved Dramaciana.
Ninthly. That Bilizant ≈øhould be made happy with fair Deni≈øa.
Tenthly. That Dramian ≈øhould be ble≈ø≈øed with fair Clariana.
Eleventhly. That Fri≈øol ≈øhould be Marryed to Leonara, Daughter to the Duke of Pera.
Twelfthly. That Dramu≈øiand ≈øhould have Arleucea, whom he mo≈øt coveted.

And that ≈øince Pandritia had been mi≈øtaken by the Soldian Bellagris, who had begat on her (in the di≈øgui≈øe of Don Edoard) a Son called Blandidon, ≈øhe ≈øhould in recompence of her long ≈øorrow, be rewarded with the ≈øaid Soldian, who was Lord of great Countries, and had for that purpo≈øe received the Chri≈øtian Faith.

The≈øe and divers other Marriages being propo≈øed, they were left to the con≈øideration of the Ladyes, the Emperor being before well ≈øatisfied, that the Princes and Knights were de≈øirous of no greater happine≈øs on this ≈øide Heaven. When after ≈øome pau≈øe, Mode≈øty and Blu≈øhes ≈øtriving with Pa≈ø≈øion, and a thorough Inquiry made by the Empre≈øs, Prince≈øs, Gridona, and Flerida, the Emperor was certified, that his plea≈øure in all he had propo≈øed, ≈øhould be joyfully obeyed: Whereupon (being impatient of delay) he cau≈øed the Fea≈øt to be renewed, and all manner of plea≈øant Recreations to be invented, in≈øomuch, that the like had not been ≈øeen: So each Prince (attended on in a ≈øplendid manner) were in the Great Cathedrall of Con≈øtantinople e≈øpou≈øed to his fair Prince≈øs, to all their hearts content, ≈øo reaping (with increa≈øe of Ioy) the ble≈ø≈øed Reward of their renown & undertakings; when the remaining part of the day was ≈øpent in Triumphs & Delight, till wi≈øhed-for darkne≈øs came, when as the blu≈øhing Ladyes, beautifull as the Morning-Star, were lead to their re≈øpective Chambers, to pay Love-Tribute, and encounter with their Warriours in the field of Venus, amid≈øt a Thou≈øand ≈øoft Love-≈øighs and pantings of Ioy, whil≈øt (≈øtrugling there 'twixt willing and unwilling) they re≈øigned their Virgin Trea≈øures to tho≈øe, who (ble≈ø≈øed now in the height of Elizium) lay raptured in a thou≈øand tran≈øports 'twixt their Ladyes Armes.

div.head: CHAP. LXII.

argument.p: How the Prince≈øs of Thrace was taken away by a ≈øtrange Adventure, and how recovered by the means of Prince Florian her Husband, and ≈øage Aliart.

div.p:
THE Court being filled with Ioy, as afore≈øaid, early with the Morning dawn, the blu≈øhing Brides di≈øcovered their Ro≈øie cheeks with a lovely fear, well knowing what an alteration ≈øome few houres had wrought, and longer could have been content to have been ≈øhrowded in the Mantle of black night; but after many kind Carre≈ø≈øes from their amorous Bridegrooms, who could not ≈øufficiently gaze upon tho≈øe Beauties they ≈øo long de≈øired, up they aro≈øe, for change of Recreation; when as the Hunters (who by the Emperors command were ≈øent to ≈øeek for Game) brought the glad news, that they had found the huge≈øt Boar their eyes e're ≈øaw to cha≈øe; at which the Emperor and all his glittering Train of either ≈øex mounted their fiery Steeds, and ≈øoon arrived at the Thicket, where he lay with glowing eyes that ≈øeemed like two living Coales of Fire, when being rou≈øed, the Dogs pur≈øued, and Iavelings thick, were thrown; when in the mid≈øt of the cha≈øe the Heavens grew, and Clouds of darkne≈øs ≈øeemed to de≈øcend frought with Thunder and bla≈øting Lightening, which ≈øo amazed the pur≈øuers, that they knew not where they was; when on a ≈øudden a Chariot de≈øcending like a flame of Brim≈øtone, caught the beautious Prince≈øs of Thrace from her Palfrey, (crying in vain for help) and wrapped her through the Skies, that both ≈øhe and the Chariot were quickly out of ≈øight, and with her all the darkne≈øs vani≈øhed: But when Prince Florian under≈øtood who it was that was ≈øo taken thence, he grieved beyond mea≈øure, and would not be comforted, till ≈øage Aliart told him, that it was done by the effects of Inchantment, and that
Targiana had procured it, in revenge of his ≈ølighting her love, and that ≈øhe might be yet recovered; whereupon he vowed never to leave the ≈øearch, till he again po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed her, in who≈øe dire hands ≈øoe're ≈øhe were; and then taking leave, he ≈øuddenly imbarqued, leaving the Court in ≈øome heavine≈øs for his departure. And having ≈øearched many Lands, and oft indured the wrath of Skyes, at length he came to a high Rock, cut into a Ca≈øtle, ≈øtanding in the deepe≈øt Ocean, when to try who dwelt therein he landed, and mounting the narrow pa≈ø≈øage, found it curiou≈øly framed, and all the Gates wide open, and in Letters of Gold over the Porch was wrought, This is the Ca≈øtle of Queen Melai; but finding none to oppo≈øe him, that had corporal ≈øhapes, (though oft he met with di≈ømal gu≈øts of wind, and heard ≈øad groans,) he pa≈ø≈øed through many ≈øtately Rooms, till in the end he came where he beheld an Altar flaming, and near it a Serpent of Bra≈øs, of wondrous ≈øize, on which (whil≈øt he gazed) he e≈øpyed a Key of Gold hang round its neck, and (as it were) a light i≈ø≈øue through divers crevi≈øes that repre≈øented a door, which made him think, that the mon≈øtrous Effigies was hollow, and in it ≈øome rare wonder included; when taking hold of the Key, he ≈ønapped the Chain a≈øunder, at which murmures, like Thunder almo≈øt ≈øpent, were heard, and helli≈øh ≈øhreiks; yet into the Key-hole (which at la≈øt he found) he thru≈øt the Key, when open ≈ølew a door with dreadfull ≈øound, and there to his amazement he beheld the beautious Prince≈øs, charmed in a dead ≈øleep, with four Wax Tapers burning, two at her head, and a like number at her feet, but not being able to come at her, he called aloud, My Love, my Joy, my life, awake, and here behold thy Guardian (Angel) come to re≈øcue thee: In vain he called, for an≈øwer none was had, nor could he perceive a motion of her breath, which ≈øo inraged him, that drawing his Sword, he layed upon the Brazen Mon≈øter, thinking ≈øo to ≈øunder it, but ≈øtill his Sword, without making any impre≈ø≈øion, rebounded from it as from a Rock of Adamant, which made him rage extreamly; yet whil≈øt his fury la≈øted looking round, he ≈øaw behind him the
≈øage Aliart, which did not a little rejoyce him, as well knowing Art and Pollicy oft availes where force is deficient, when embracing him, he de≈øired his coun≈øel in the matter; whereupon the ≈øage thus an≈øwered:

The≈øe Tapers that you ≈øee, contain the Prince≈ø≈øes life, and when they expire, or are extingui≈øhed, ≈øhe dies; but ≈øince Heaven has brought us timely hither to pre≈øerve ≈øo bright a Beauty, fear not, but her deliverance ≈øhall ≈øoon be wrought: Whereupon lighting a Magick Taper at one of tho≈øe bright flames, he held it to the No≈øtrils of the Serpent, when as a dreadfull noi≈øe was heard, of loud laments and cryes, and ≈øoon the Serpent bur≈øt in ≈øunder, upon which (as from a Dream) the Prince≈øs did awake, and at her awaking the Tapers vani≈øhed, when gazing round, ≈øhe e≈øpyed her Lord, and with much Ioy ran to his Arms, inquiring how ≈øhe came in that di≈ømal place, when having been informed in every circum≈øtance, ≈øhe greatly marvelled, and on her knees ble≈ø≈øed Heaven for her deliverance.

So taking leave of the inchanted place, which ≈øoon after their departure vani≈øhed into Ayr, they imbarqued, and ≈øailing before a pro≈øperous wind, arrived at Con≈øtantinople, bani≈øhing with their pre≈øence the ≈øadne≈øs their ab≈øence cau≈øed: Where for a while I will leave them, and proceed to the Third Part of this Famous Hi≈øtory.

div.head: THE Famous Hi≈øtory OF The Renowned PRINCE Palmerin of England. Part, the Third.
CHAP. LXIII.

argument.p: How the Prince≈øs Targiana ≈øent the Emperor notice, how her Father the Great Turk Albayzer, now made Soldian of Babylon, and the Sultan of Per≈øia, were coming again≈øt him with a powerfull Army: Of the arrival of tho≈øe Armies at the Port of Con≈øtantinople, and the conflict between them and the Emperors Forces upon their Landing.

div.p: THE Prince≈øs Targiana ob≈øerving the great preparations that were made to War upon the Emperor of Greece, for refu≈øing to deliver up Prince Florian, and weighing the kind entertainment ≈øhe had received in the Court of Con≈øtantinople, ≈øhe ≈øent a private Me≈ø≈øenger, to acquaint him with all that was intended again≈øt him, not having been able, by her Prayers and Intreaty, to divert her Father and Husband from the War.

This News greatly con≈øternated the Emperor, and many of the Princes, but like valiant men, inured to bear the wor≈øt of Fortune, they re≈øolved to provide again≈øt the Tempe≈øt that was bearing upon them: Wherefore the Emperor cau≈øed Forces to be rai≈øed in all parts of his Empire, and provided Armes in abundance, re≈øolving to give the Enemy ≈øuch a welcome as they ≈øhould but badly reli≈øh.

But e're the preparations were fully fini≈øhed, the Enemy's Fleet came before the City, and from the Chief a Herauld was ≈øent, to bid defiance of War, unle≈øs Florian, and the City of Con≈øtantinople would be ≈øurrendred. But the fir≈øt being accepted, rather than the later, the Chri≈øtian Army drew out in this order:

King Edoard being made General of the Forces, lead Ten Thou≈øand choice Knights, who≈øe Rear was brought up by Dramu≈øiand; next him marched Arnedes King of France, with Five Thou≈øand; on who≈øe Right advanced Recinde King of Spain with Three Thou≈øand, his Rear being brought up by the Gyant Almorol; and to ≈øtrengthen them, Verner the German Emperor advanced with Eight Thou≈øand; and by this time the Soldian Bellagris was arrived with Five Thou≈øand Hor≈øe, having ordained his Son Blandidon his Leivetenant; after him marched King Polendos with Four Thou≈øand The≈ø≈øalian Archers on foot: As for Palmerin, Florian, Platire, Florendos, Berolde, Gracian, Gurein German of Orleance, Pompides, Don Rou≈øel, Oni≈øtaldus, Floriman, Belcar, and divers other Flowers of Chivalry, they would be confined to no ≈øetled place, by rea≈øon that upon all occa≈øions they might a≈ø≈øi≈øt where need require. The Rear of this Army was brought up by Tarnaes King of Lacedemon, and the City committed to the charge of Prince Primalion, who acted there as the Aged Emperor's Leivetenant, who by by rea≈øon of his Yeares and Infirmities, was not capable of managing affairs as he ought, in ≈øuch a nece≈ø≈øity.

The Army being drawn out, ha≈øted in good order to the Port, where they found the Enemy under the leading of Albayzer,
(who was made Captain-General of all the Heathen Forces) about to land; when as between them began a dreadfull Incounter, in≈øomuch that all the ≈øhore was dyed with blood, and the waves di≈øcoloured; For King Edoard, his Son Palmerin, and Dramu≈øiand, fighting again≈øt Albayzer and his Gyants, made a dreadfull de≈øtruction, killing two fearfull Gyants, and about an hundred common Souldiers, but not without receiving many wounds: Nor were the re≈øt of the Knights idle, but imployed their whole force for the Honour of Chri≈øtendome, the Glory of the Empire, and the keeping up their Renown, ≈øo that dreadfull deeds in Arms were done; yet the Pagan Ho≈øt was ≈øo numerous, that the places of the ≈ølain was ≈øtill filled up with fre≈øh ≈øupplyes; which the Emperor and Prince Primalion from an high Tower perceiving, the later (by the appointment of the former) i≈ø≈øued out with Seven Hundred cho≈øen Knights, to recrute his friends, and coming fre≈øhly on, he made great ≈ølaughter: But Night ca≈øting her dark Mantle over the Earth, King Edoard cau≈øed the Retreat to be ≈øounded, retiring and incamping under the Walls of the City, being de≈øirous of nothing more than, that the Enemy might land, that ≈øo they might come to a pitched Battel.

div.head: CHAP. LXIV.

argument.p: How the Turks, &c. Landed and incamped their Forces; And of the ≈øupplys that arrived at Con≈øtantinople, to ≈øuccour the Emperor Palmerin.

div.p:
THE Emperial Army retiring, and ≈øtrongly incamping under the Walls of the City, the Turki≈øh Army con≈øi≈øting of upward of Two Hundred Thou≈øand men, forcibly running their Ships on ground, leaped on ≈øhore, and drove back ≈øuch as were left to hinder their landing, though not without great lo≈øs on their ≈øide, and not lo≈øing time (under the covert of the night) they incamped along the ≈øhore ≈øtrongly, in≈øomuch, that the Emperor did not think fit pre≈øently to hazard a Battel, but to ≈øtay till the ≈øupplys that were on their way, from the Countries of tho≈øe Kings that were in his Camp, arrived; which accordingly did in ≈øeven dayes arrive, to the number of Twenty Thou≈øand, be≈øides Eight Thou≈øand Hor≈øe and Foot under the leading of E≈øterlant King of Hungary; and Four Thou≈øand Foot-men, ≈øent by Roramant King of Bohemia: Who having refre≈øhed them≈øelves, prepared to give Battel; when in the mean time leave was given, to view the Camps on either part. And Prince Florian under≈øtanding, for his ≈øake the War was made, relying upon his ≈øtrength and fortune, re≈øolved to go in di≈øgui≈øe to the Heathen Camp, and require the Iu≈øt and Combat, which he accordingly did, overthrowing and putting to the foile all that he encountered, and then returned to his beloved Leonarda, who was bedewing her beautious eyes with tears for his ab≈øence: And after that divers Encounters happened by agreement, wherein the Turks were alwayes wor≈øted; but mo≈øt dreadfull was that (upon a chalenge) between Dramu≈øiand and Framu≈øtant a Per≈øian Gyant; but after a dreadfull Combat, and great effu≈øion of blood on both
≈øides, at the earne≈øt In≈øtance of Targiana (who fortunately arrived during the Combat) they were ≈øeperated, the one retireing into the City, and the other into the Heathen Camp.

When the Empre≈øs and her Ladies had notice, that the fair Sultane≈øs was arrived there, ≈øhe ≈øent to invite her into the City, who accepting of her invitation, came Nobly attended, but ≈øtayed not there, as being ≈øent for back by her Husband, by rea≈øon the dreadfull day of Battel was at hand, on which the fates of Nations did depend.

div.head: CHAP. LXV.

argument.p: Of the Dreadfull Battel fought between the Turks and the Chri≈øtians, before Con≈øtantinople; and what happened therein.

div.p: NOW the Captains and Souldiers, being impatient of inglorious ea≈øe, urged the Battel, and ≈øo prevailed on both ≈øides, that the day was appointed, which came quickly on; when as King Ed ‚Ä¢ ard General of the Field, divided his Battel, & reduced it under the Leading of the following Commanders.

The fir≈øt Squadron he committed to the Soldian Bellagris, con≈øi≈øting of five Thou≈øand Hor≈øe and foot; the ≈øecond to Recinde King of Spain, con≈øi≈øting of Three Thou≈øand; the third to Arnedes King of France, con≈øi≈øting of five Thou≈øand; the fourth to Polendos King of The≈ø≈øaly, con≈øi≈øting of four Thou≈øand; the fifth to Verner Emperor of Almain, con≈øi≈øting
of Eight Thou≈øand; and the la≈øt con≈øi≈øting of four Thou≈øand, he lead him≈øelf; all the≈øe being Hor≈øemen: The body of Foot that was to fight in the middle, and con≈øi≈øted of Fifty Thou≈øand men, was reduced under the Standard of King Tarnaes, & divers of the Princes, & great Captains, ≈øuch as him≈øelf ≈øhould appoint; when in a glorious Troop, to ≈øuccour all parts as occa≈øion required, rode Palmerin, Florian, Gracian, Platire, Pompides, Majortes, Drapos, Belcar, Blandidon, Berolde, Floriman, ‚Ä¢ lorendos, Don Rou≈øel, Francian, Billizant, Oni≈øtalous, Tenebrant, E≈øterlant, Albanis, Rodomant, Dragolant, Luyman, Germane, Tremoran, Don Ro≈øian, D La Bronde, Dramu≈øiand, Almorol, and divers others, who obtained the Honour of the fir≈øt On≈øet, the better to encourage unexpert, and by their furious Charge di≈ømayed the foe: When as King Edoard in Scarlet Armour, enamelled with white and black, and fa≈øtened with Chaines of Gold, bearing for his Device a flying Griffin in a field of Silver, bravely mounted, after ≈øilence made, cheered his Warriours as followeth:

Sacred Fellows in Arms, who≈øe matchle≈øs deeds have hitherto made your Renown to reach the utmo≈øt Orient, now is the time to make your fame immortal, in pre≈øerving this Empire from the ≈øpoyl and havock you Barbarous Nations threaten it withall, for ≈øure the flower of Chri≈øtendom can never flag in Courage at the light of tho≈øe, whom we and our Fathers have ≈øo oft ≈øubdued; therefore let's on, and thorough the Lanes of Death, and o're the heaps of ≈ølaughtered foes, and force way to Victory, that ≈øo the terrour of our Arms may ≈øpread through all their Coa≈øts, and haughty Babylon, Tauris, and Iconium, the Regal Seats of the≈øe three Tyrants that make War on us, may tremble at our Names: Now in your Ladies ≈øights have you ju≈øt cau≈øe to try your Prowe≈øs, and bravely highten their e≈øteem of you, that ≈øo they may ble≈øs the happy moment wherein Fortune ≈øent ≈øuch a Happine≈øs.

Thus having ≈øaid, he ended with ≈øuch ≈øtern regard and a
Maje≈øtick frown, that his War-like Eyes ≈øeemed to glance De≈øtruction on the Foe, and give his own fre≈øh vigour to a≈ø≈øail them. The Generals Speech ≈øo fired each Brea≈øt, that with a ≈øhout that rent the Sky, each undividual Souldier cryed, Lead on.

While the≈øe things pa≈ø≈øed, Albayzer and his Captains were not idle, but divided the Hor≈øemen into nine Companys: The fir≈øt Squadron he gave to the Souldian of Per≈øia; the ≈øecond to the King of Trebezond; the third to the King of Ca≈øpia; the fourth to the King of Armenia; the fifth to the King of Cambia; the ≈øixth to the King of Sparta; the ≈øeventh to the King Bethinia; the eighth to the Prince Argela of Affrica; and the ninth he lead him≈øelf, having ≈øeven mon≈øtrous Gyants for his guard; when as Albayzer (Armed in green Armour, be≈øet with Golden Spheres, and his Ladies Picture in a field of Sinople portrayed in his Shield, mounted on a Per≈øian Hor≈øe) thus cheered his Souldiers:

You the flower of A≈øia, ever Renowned in Arms, behold the day you wi≈øhed is come, your foes are at hand, and the Battel; certain now is the time to try your Valour, on who≈øe Matchle≈øs courage depends in part my fame & high Renown; As for me, I ≈øhall in all parts perform the Office of a Souldier and a General, re≈øolving rather to dye under the≈øe Walls, than to depart without Victory; for know, with Honour I can never return into my own Country, unle≈øs I perform my promi≈øe, which was to levell the Walls of this proud City, which dares affront me and my great Allyes.
