This having ≈øaid, he pau≈øed, but found not any applau≈øe that an≈øwered his expectation; whereupon lea≈øt the Courage of his men ≈øhould coole, and all their Valour faint, he having Mar≈øhaled every Squadron, lead them on to encounter the Emperors Forces, who came like inraged Lyons to meet them, ≈øo that the dreadfull bla≈øt was ≈øcarcely ≈øounded, e're the fight began on all hands cruel and doubtfull; for there might be ≈øeen the brave Exploits of War, each Souldier being ≈øufficient to lead an Army; but the mo≈øt famed Encounters were
the≈øe: Prince Primalion having left the City in charge of divers Knights, bravely encountered the King of Ca≈øpia with ≈øuch courage, that he bore him to the ground, and would have ≈ølain him, had not fifty of his choice guard came to his re≈øcue; whereupon pa≈ø≈øing forward, he made great ≈ølaughter of the foe, cutting off Arms and Heads, to the amazement of tho≈øe that beheld; when being ≈øeconded by Prince Palmerin, none dur≈øt ≈øtand before them, in≈øomuch, that the King of Aetolia came with a choice band to oppo≈øe their fury, but was overthrown, and hardly e≈øcaped with Life. Florendos breaking into the thicke≈øt, pre≈ø≈øed on that ≈øide where the King of Armenia fought, gave him divers wounds, and threw him to the ground, in≈øomuch, that he was carryed by his Servants as dead to the Camp. Berolde and Floriman leading a valiant Troop, bravely charged the power lead by the King of Bythinia, and breaking their Ranks, ≈øeized the King with ≈øo hard a hand, that he had at that time been taken or ≈ølain, had not ≈øuccours from all parts of the Army come to his re≈øcue, yet was he grievou≈øly wounded, and obliged to retire. Nor was the Fight le≈øs bloody where Dramu≈øiand, and Florian, Recinde, Arnedes, and the other Princes fought, in≈øomuch, that nothing could be heard, but cla≈øhing of Armour and dying groans, nor ≈øeen on the ground, but Blood, dead Bodies, and hewed off Limbs; when as Dramu≈øiand piercing the Squadron of his foes to his wi≈øh, met with Framu≈øtant the Per≈øian Gyant, between whom a dreadfull Combat began with the Sword, the≈øe Gyants being reputed of equal ≈øtrength, and on who≈øe Arms depended much the fortune of the War; when in the mean while the Battel on all ≈øides waxed hot, the great Captains every where incouraging their Men by words and example, ≈øtriving all they might to keep them in good order; whil≈øt Argelao and the King of Bythinia being di≈ømounted, fought again≈øt Prince Floriman and Berolde Prince of Spain, but being infinitely wor≈øted, the Soldian of Per≈øia came to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, which the Soldian Bellagris perceiving, broke through the Ranks, with divers of his couragious followers,
and fought ≈øo valiantly, that the Per≈øian was obliged to retire with the lo≈øs of an hundred of his be≈øt Knights. „Äà‚óä„Äâ nor being free from wounds: But new ≈øupplys „Äà‚óä„Äâ moment pre≈ø≈øing forward, found more work for War, is that the ≈øhou ‚Ä¢ s of the vanqui≈øhers, and the crys of the vanqui≈øhed, reached Heavens highe≈øt Con ‚Ä¢ er making the Hills and Valleys all about „Äà‚óä„Äâ , but in the end the Pagan Battel on that ≈øide gave back, which Albayzer perceiving, where he fought, ordered the King of Trebe≈øond with Eight Thou≈øand Hor≈øe to reinforce them, and (if po≈ø≈øible) re≈øtore the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ght; which Platire, Polinardus, Pompides, Majortes, and other valiant Knights perceiving, drew up the Court-Regiments, wherein were the be≈øt Souldiers, and breaking through the Ranks of the Enemy, made ≈øuch ≈ølaughter, that the field was afre≈øh bedewed with blood, and the Trebe≈øonians routed in all parts, which brought ≈øuch a fear upon the whole
‚Ä¢ agan Army, that they began to ≈øhrink together, and were only re≈øtrained from flight by pure ≈øhame.

During this Battel, King Edoard rode through all parts, ≈øuccouring his men where he ≈øaw mo≈øt need, and making great ≈ølaughter of the Enemy with his own hands, being attended every where he rode with an hundred choice Knights; when as the Emperor Palmerin (who from a Tower beheld the fight, together with the Ladies) greatly marvelled at the Prowe≈øs of the Warriours; de≈øiring nothing more than to have been among≈øt them, had his Age permitted; as not, in his Youth being accu≈øtomed to be an idle ≈øpectator, whil≈øt others fought; yet mindfull of the charge of ≈øo great a Potentate, he hourly ≈øent ≈øuch ≈øuccours as could be ≈øpared to reinforce the fainting Regiments, and charge the Enemy with fre≈øh vigor, and to give ≈øuch orders as he thought convenient.

The Battel being in the highth; the chief of the Princes di≈ømounted, and with their Swords cutting their way, entered the Battalian of the Foot men, where Primalion and the King of Trebe≈øond meeting, a dreadfull Combat began; but ≈øuch was the fiercene≈øs of the Fight between them, that for
want of breath, and through lo≈øs of blood, they were obliged to pau≈øe a while: When as Palmerin with a Thou≈øand Knights charged the Battalian of the Souldian of Babylon, and made exceeding ≈ølaughter, in≈øomuch, that they fled from him as from their certain death, none being able to re≈øi≈øt his force. On the other ≈øide fought Florian, who≈øe death the Great Turk had ≈øtrictly injoyned; when tho≈øe that had it in charge perceiving him far entered among≈øt the Ranks of his Enemies, inclo≈øed him on every ≈øide, and gave him many ≈øtrokes that brui≈øed his Armour, which rou≈øed his Courage to that degree, that with a force exceeding, he ≈øo dealt, that ≈øoon they opened on every ≈øide; yet fought he ≈øo long, till ramparts of dead Bodys hemmed him in. But ≈øo well fared not Prince Majortes, for being inclo≈øed by a Squadron of Per≈øian Hor≈øe, he fought (in hopes of ≈øuccour) till through wounds and lo≈øs of blood falling, he gave up the Gho≈øt, who≈øe death much grieved the Chri≈øtian Princes, e≈øpecially Prince Palmerin, who intirely loved him, in≈øomuch, that to revenge his death, he ≈øo furiou≈øly charged the King of Trebe≈ø ‚Ä¢ nd that breaking his him Armour in many places, and infixing divers wounds upon he (in ≈øpight of his men, who laboured to re≈øcue their Lord) brought him to de≈øtruction. And ≈øo long and dreadfull did the fight continue between Dramu≈øiand and Framu≈øtant, that through lo≈øs of blood, and wearine≈øs, they fainted, and were carryed out of the Battel by their friends on either part.

Great was the ≈øorrow of the Ladies, who from the Battelments beheld the fight, there being few of them but had a Husband, Relation, or Friend ingaged, ≈øo that ≈øome of them ≈øeeing the field be≈øtrewed with ≈ølaughter, ≈øwounded away, and others retire their beautious eyes, not being able longer to behold the Tragick action, not knowing what to think of the Battel, or to whom fortune owed the Victory: During the fight, the City was ≈øtrongly guarded on all parts, to prevent a ≈øurprize.

King Edoard retiring from the foiles of War, to take breath and dre≈øs a wound he had received, within a ≈øhort time
came on afre≈øh with a commanded party of Hor≈øe, and made great ≈ølaughter, in≈øomuch, that the Infidels gave back, and the Chri≈øtians on that ≈øide recovered the ground they had lo≈øt, taking new vigor, and charging couragiou≈øly, in≈øomuch, that Albayzer coming thither to re≈øtore the Battel, was over-≈øet with the furious Charge of the Greecian Hor≈øemen, and him≈øelf thrown to the ground, but ≈øoon recovering his Legs, he drew his Sword, and killed divers Knights, yet was ≈øo ≈øtrongly re≈øi≈øted, that there he had been taken or ≈ølain, had not his Gyants (who alwaies guarded his Per≈øon) be≈øtirred them≈øelves with their mighty Battel-Axes, yet one of them fell by the Sword of Prince Primalion, and another was carryed off ≈øore wounded, of which wounds he ≈øoon after dyed.

By this time the Right Wing of the Turks was broken and di≈øordered, being pierced by Recinde and the Gyant Almorol, to rally which Albayzer ≈øtrove in vain, till ≈øuch time as he had reinforced them with Ten Thou≈øand fre≈øh men, and clapped into the front two of his Gyants, viz. Dromorant and Tramfamore; between whom, and King Recinde, ≈øeconded by his tru≈øty Servant Almorol, began a fierce Combat; but being hemmed round by the Infidels, the King (after two houres fighting again≈øt infinite odds, and no ≈øuccour coming) fell wounded from his Hor≈øe, and was ≈ølain by the Gyant Tramfamore, which ≈øo inraged Almorol, that leaving the ≈øide where he fought, he came to revenge his Ma≈øters death, overthrowing with his Mace all that ≈øtood in his way, when coming upon Tramfamor with a fierce blow, he brui≈øed his Helm and Head ≈øo much, that he fell dead, with a horrible groan breathing out his la≈øt.

Prince Palmerin and Primalion hearing of the death of Recinde, were greatly inraged, and to revenge it, redoubled their ≈øtrength, fighting like Lybian Lyons, ≈øo that all the ground where they fought was covered with blood and ≈ølaughter; but Primalion having lo≈øt much blood in the fight, and finding him≈øelf faint, by the advice of his friends (after having
killed above an hundred Turks with his own hands) retired into the City: Yet the Fight waxed hot on all ≈øides, upon the coming in of fre≈øh ≈øupplies, ≈øo that Victory hovered doubtfull over either Army.

Arnedes King of France having notice that his Couzen Recinde was ≈ølain, came with Oni≈øtaldus to revenge his death, but after a long fight, in which many of the Turks, Per≈øians, and Babylonians were ≈ølain, the King having his Hor≈øe killed under him, and his Helmet bur≈øt, was ≈ølain; as al≈øo was Oni≈øtaldus, in endeavouring his re≈øcue; but long their Deaths were not unrevenged: For King Edoard and Prince Florian coming with a fre≈øh Troop of Hor≈øemen, pierced the Squadron of the Turki≈øh Hor≈øe, where they found many of their friends inclo≈øed, yet valiantly fighting again≈øt Dromorant and divers others, upon which the King and his Son put them≈øelves between, making great ≈ølaughter of the Enemy, though not without ≈øome wounds received; but ≈øo eager was the Prince again≈øt the Gyant, that after a dreadfull Combat with him, he gave him a wound on the right ≈øide of his Head, which brought him to the ground, when ≈øetting his Foot upon him, he divided his Head from his Body. Whil≈øt this was doing, King Polendos and Belcar entered the Squadron of the King of Aetolia, and made great ≈ølaughter, in≈øomuch, that Prince Berolde, de≈øirous to revenge his Fathers death, coming to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtance, the routed Pagans in great di≈øorder fled, not regarding the Per≈øon of their King, who labouring to re≈øtrain their flight, was overborn with the trampling of the Hor≈øes. Then came on Prince Florian with a ≈øtrong party, and charged furiou≈øly upon the reinforced Squadron of Trebe≈øond, making great ≈ølaughter, in≈øomuch, that Albayzer was glad to leave his ≈øtation, and come to that part with his mo≈øt approved Knights, but was not able to re≈øtore the Battel on that part; wherefore he returned to keep firm ≈øuch as on the other hand began to waver; for the main Battel being charged by Floriman, Berolde, Florendos, Belcar, Francian, Don Rou≈øel, and divers others, gave
way apace, as not being qualified to ≈øu≈øtain ≈øuch fury; yet at the ≈øight of their General, the Captains ≈øo be≈øtirred them≈øelves, that they brought their men to make a better re≈øi≈øtance, ≈øo that great was the ≈ølaughter on either part; but ≈øo ≈øtrongly the Princes pre≈ø≈øed on, that through a lane of ≈ølaughtered foes they at length came, where they found the Gyant Almorol fighting again≈øt a number of the Enemies, in defence of the dead body of Recinde, which he re≈øolved not to leave as a prey to the Enemies, but with his Life; nor could the Princes (though he was extreamly wounded, and had his Helmet broken in divers places) per≈øwade him to retire, but in the end falling, he (through the many wounds he received, and extream lo≈øs of blood) dyed upon his Ma≈øters body, covering it with his own, which Prince Berolde perceiving, and greatly lamenting the death of his Father and his mo≈øt faithfull Servant, charged upon the Gyant Gramalo (who had mo≈øt in damaged Almorol) with ≈øuch force, that he ≈øoon brought him to the ground, and ≈ømote off his Head, whil≈øt he in vain cryed out for mercy; and following the advantage, he fought again≈øt the Souldian of Per≈øia, who was come thither, and had ≈ølain him, had not the Per≈øians in great number ran between, and hazarded their lives to ≈øave their Lord; yet ≈øo wounded was he, that he was carryed out of the Battel doubtfull whether to recover or not, which gave the Chri≈øtians opportunity to carry off the body of the King and Gyant Almorol, with many others of note that were ≈ølain ≈øince the fight began. Yet no ≈øooner had they done it, but Albayzer taking breath, came on with his chief ≈øtrength, and charged the Squadron lead by King Edoard, but was bravely re≈øi≈øted by tho≈øe that came from the Right Wing to reinforce him, and again obliged to give ground; when as the Souldian Bellagris and the Emperor Verner came on with a fre≈øh party, and made infinite ≈ølaughter; but whil≈øt the later charged too furiou≈øly, his Hor≈øe received a ≈øhot in the eye with a Per≈øian Arrow, which made him ca≈øt his Rider, who in the fall had one of his legs broken, yet fought he couragiou≈øly, till ≈øuch
time as Polinardus and others carryed him off, yet dyed he ≈øoon after of his fall, who≈øe death was greatly lamented in Camp and City.

Primalion being grieved at the hard fortune of the Emperor, fought with great fury, in≈øomuch, that heaps of the ≈ølain encompa≈ø≈øed him about, and was ≈øeconded by his Son Florendos, with as brave a re≈øolution; ≈øo that the King of Bythinia coming to the aid of ≈øuch as were hard put to it, ended his dayes in that place, being ≈ølain by the hand of Prince Floriman, which his men perceiving it, retired with all convenient ≈øpeed; which made the King of Armenia advance with Four Thou≈øand cho≈øen Souldiers, hoping to advance the War, but found him≈øelf ≈øo hardly charged, that he would have retired but being pre≈ø≈øed by the Chri≈øtian Princes, he fell (together with five hundred of his be≈øt men) by the Sword.

During the≈øe Encounters, King Edoard fighting through the Ranks, came upon Albayzer, who was at that time making havock of the Chri≈øtians, and charged him with great fury, ≈øo that a dreadfull Combat happened between them, in which Albayzer had been ≈ølain, had not the Gyants that ≈øtill attended his per≈øon made great re≈øi≈øtance, even till night came on, which hindered the Chri≈øtians of the Victory, and cau≈øed each General to ≈øound the Retreat, the one retiring to the City, and the other to his Camp.

div.head: CHAP. LXVI.

argument.p: Of the Truce taken for ≈øix dayes; And of the Sorrow in the City and Pagan Camp; And the order taken for a Second Battel.

div.p: THE Great Captains retiring with their Forces into the City, a Mu≈øter was taken to know who was wanting, which being once under≈øtood, great was the laments of the Citizens, ≈øome having lo≈øt a Father, others a Brother, ≈øome a Couzen, and divers women their Husbands, Sons, &c. ≈øo that nothing was heard but ≈øighs, laments, and vowes of revenge; but above all, mo≈øt deplorable was the grief of the Court Ladyes, many of whom had lo≈øt their Lords almo≈øt as ≈øoon as injoyed, ≈øuch is the cruel chance of Fortune, in di≈øappointing true Lovers of their happine≈øs, when they ≈øuppo≈øe them≈øelves mo≈øt ≈øure, and laugh at Worldly felicity: There might you behold one bedewing her beautious face with Tears, yet made by Grief more lovely; here another tearing her Amber Tre≈ø≈øes, and complaining of her hard-Star'd fate; yonder another privately retired, and ≈øobbing out that grief, that could not in words find utterance; in another place a bright Angel fallen in a ≈øwound, and ≈øtrugling for life, yet de≈øirous to dye, that ≈øo ≈øhe might ha≈øt to Elizium, to find her departed Lord; in this Chamber in melancholly darkne≈øs another ≈øate ≈øighing, and in groans expre≈ø≈øed her inward angui≈øh; which ≈øad e≈øtate ≈øo moved the hearts of all to pitty, that they be≈øought the Emperor and Empre≈øs to u≈øe their diligence in comforting the di≈øtre≈ø≈øed Beauties, which they did in the be≈øt manner they could, as not being capable of effecting it to their wi≈øh.

While≈øt the≈øe things pa≈ø≈øed, the Princes and great Captains were putting all things in good order, re≈øolving in the morning
early to take the Field, and revenge the lo≈øs they had ≈øu≈øtained: But while≈øt they were con≈øulting, a Trumpet from Albayzer de≈øired to be admitted to the Emperors pre≈øence, where being come, he (in the Name of his Lord) demanded a ≈øix day Truce to bury the Dead, and di≈øpo≈øe of the wounded men; to which the Princes would in no wi≈øe hearken, ≈øaying, Albayzer did it to gain time to recrute his broken Army; and that (as for them≈øelves) they could not undertake to ≈øtay their forward Souldiers from the field, ≈øo de≈øperately were they beat to fini≈øh the War, or dye under the City walls. But the Emperor con≈øidering that many of his Knights were wounded, and that it would be dangerous ≈øo ≈øoon to hazard them in a new ingagement, as al≈øo that the bodies of divers of his friends lay in the field unburyed, together with the common Souldiers, which would greatly annoy the City, he ≈øo tempered the re≈øolution of the forward Princes, that they in the end ≈øubmitted it wholly to his plea≈øure; whereupon a Truce was concluded, and the Dead on either ≈øide accordingly buryed with great ≈øolemnity, the Chiefs having Monuments of co≈øtly work reared to their la≈øting Memories and eternal Fame.

The Truce being expired, early the ≈øucceeding morning King Edoard and the Princes Primalion, Palmerin, and Florian put the Army in Array, and with many Heroick ≈øpeeches encouraged the Souldiers to revenge the death of their friends, and drive the Enemy from their Camp; when in good order they marched out with loud ≈øhouts, wounding the Ayr with Drums, Trumpets, Clarions, Flutes, and Phyfes, which greatly alarum'd the Pagans, and made them in≈øtantly betake them≈øelves to their Arms; yet ≈øo di≈øcouraged were they, that their General was long e're he could draw them out of his Camp; when ≈øtanding in Array, he mounted upon a little Ri≈øing, and from thence began to encourage them in this manner:

Fellow Souldiers, you ≈øee Fortune hath brought us to this place, to revenge Injuries, and try our Valours, which we
have already done, and the Enemy not gained (as yet) any con≈øiderable advantage over us; Therefore this day let your prowe≈øs witne≈øs you men of daring re≈øolution, and the price of your labour ≈øhall be the ≈øpoyl of you Wealthy City, which I de≈øign to leavel with the Du≈øt, and race out of the memory of ≈øucceeding Ages. This ≈øaid, he ended, and did ≈øound the Charge.

div.head: CHAP. LXVII.

argument.p: Of the ≈øecond Battel between the Chri≈øtians and Infidels, with their overthrow, and the Emperor Palmerin.

div.p:
THE Charge ≈øounded on both ≈øides, the Armys (after a flight of Arrows) joyned with the Sphere and Sword in a dreadfull manner, in≈øomuch, that the field was again ≈øtrewed with new ≈ølaughter, and many worthy Knights ≈øore wounded, the Turks being now de≈øperate to overcome; which Palmerin and Florian perceiving, charged the Squadron lead by Albayzer with great fury, in≈øomuch that it gave back, Albayzer him≈øelf in the Encounter being unhor≈øed, and in much danger of his Life; when as the King of Ca≈øpia coming to his relief ≈øtayed the fury of the Princes, and ≈ølew divers of the meaner ≈øort of Greeks, who adventured too far in the Battel: But King Edoard coming to that part, fought ≈øo couragiou≈øly, that he pierced the Ca≈øpian King's Array; and being ≈øeconded by the afore≈øaid Princes, put the Infidels again into di≈øorder; to reinforce whom advanced Prince Argelao,
with Eight Thou≈øand Africans; but being received at the point of the Launce by Palmerin of England, he was ran quite through the Body, and tumbled dead from his Hor≈øe; in imitation of whom Prince Florian encountering another of Albayzers great Captains ≈ølew him.

The Fight being at this pa≈øs, Dramu≈øiand and Framu≈øtant charging through the Squadrons, at la≈øt met, and encountered each other with great fury; when as another Turki≈øh Gyant named Dramator, came to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Framu≈øtant, who≈øe pui≈ø≈øance was little inferiour to the former; which Florian, from the Squadron where he fought, perceiving, came to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his friend, ≈øo that leaving him again upon equal terms, a dreadfull fight continued, which ended in the Death of Dramator, ≈ølain by Prince Florian, and the di≈øorderly Retreat of Framu≈øtant.

The Soldian of Per≈øia fighting in the Right Wing, and finding his men wor≈øted and greatly ≈ølaughtered by Prince Floriman, came re≈øolutely to ingage him, but was welcomed with ≈øuch noble force, that had not his men again re≈øcued him, he had there been ≈ølain. Yet the fight waxed hot on all ≈øides, and loud were the crys and groans of the dying and wounded men, ≈øo that they were plainly heard into the City; yet both ≈øides animated with hope of Victory, ≈øtood ≈øtoutly to their Arms: But upon the arrival of a fre≈øh Squadron of Hor≈øe, and a ≈øtrong Battailian of foot, under the leading of E≈øterlant King of Hungaria, the Chri≈øtians redoubling their Courage, made great havock of their Enemies; whereupon Albayzer (who had his eye upon every place) came thither, and brought Three Hundred Knights to ≈øuccour his friends, being de≈øirous of nothing more, than to be revenged of Prince Florian, whom he beheld ≈ølaughtering his men; whereupon he addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf to the Combat, and layed many ≈øtrokes upon him, which made the Prince recollect his force, and leave fighting with ≈øuch as ≈øhunned Death, to charge his Capital Adver≈øary, which he did with ≈øuch fury, that he tumbled him from his Hor≈øe, when alighting to uncla≈øp his Helm, the Pagans on all ≈øides
came running in throngs to the re≈øcue of their General, that the Prince was con≈øtrained to relinqui≈øh his purpo≈øe, and remount; during which Albayzer was conveyed thence: Yet ≈øo dealt the noble Florian, that his anger fell not in vain, but with ≈øuch fury he charged all that fell in his way, that they dreaded him wor≈øe than Death, flying from him on every hand; but at length being weary with ≈øubduing, he retired to refre≈øh him≈øelf; when as Albayzer having recovered from the amazement he was in, came and re≈øtored the Battel on that part.

King Edoard perceiving the Battel at a ≈øtand, Victory as yet inclining to neither ≈øide, commanded his re≈øerves to charge the Left Wing of the Enemy, which they did with ≈øuch vigor and bravery of mind, that the battel ≈øoon began to ≈øwerve: When Prince Palmerin, and his Vncle Prince Primalion, coming on the King of Cambia, who commanded that part of the battel, was ≈ølain, and the Wing roured, notwith≈øtanding a reinforcement of Three Thou≈øand Parthian Archers came in, who≈øe Arrows gauled the Chri≈øtian Hor≈øe, and cau≈øed divers of them to ca≈øt their Riders; and now was the body of the Pagan Army (con≈øi≈øting of Forty Thou≈øand Foot) left open, among≈øt who≈øe Ranks the Hor≈øe entering, put them into ≈øuch confu≈øion, that they lo≈øt all order, and ≈øhrunk together, notwith≈øtanding the endeavour their Commanders u≈øed to prevent it; and ≈øo far pierced they that came upon the Soldian of Per≈øia, who was retired thither from the Right Wing, again≈øt whom Prince Palmerin addre≈ø≈øed him≈øelf, and fought with him ≈øo long, that (fainting through wounds, and lo≈øs of blood) he fell dead; which ≈øo di≈ømayed his men, that they fled from that part, and left the Victory there intirely to the Chri≈øtians: But the Right Wing fighting ≈øtrongly, and the Left reinforced with Eight Thou≈øand Scithians, newly arrived to the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of Albayzer, Polinardus was over-born and ≈ølain by Ferrebroque, Captain of the Scyths, which greatly grieved the Princes, and gave the Infidels occa≈øion to take heart, and the rather becau≈øe with the≈øe new ≈øupplys came Pandolf a mon≈øtrous Gyant; but Florendos coming to the aid of his
friends, and finding the Gyant with a mighty Mace ≈ølaughtering the Greecian Souldiers, bore upon him with great fury, and after a terrible Combat, bur≈øt his Helm, at what time falling, he cut off his Head, and gave him an unlooked for welcome, for that this Gyant boa≈øted him≈øelf of ability to contend with ten of the Emperors be≈øt Knights, all at once.

Berolde Prince of Spain, yet ≈øeeking to revenge his Fathers Death, de≈øperately charged into the thicke≈øt of his foes, and there had been ≈ølain, had not the Soldian Bellagris come timely to his re≈øcue, and brought him out of the Battel; but ≈øo wounded was he, that his Souldiers con≈øtrained him to retire to the City, to have his wounds carefully regarded.

Yet the fight continued hot on all ≈øides; for now came Blandidon on with fre≈øh Troops, being the Subjects of the Soldian Bellagris, newly arrived, and with the≈øe he charged the Enemy in the Rear, where fought the King of Sparta, with his Vncle Anti≈øtes, and his Son Luimeno, but his battel being over-born, they were all ≈ølain; to revenge which Marlearque a Spartan Gyant advanced again≈øt Blandidon, and charging him at unawares, ≈ømote ≈øo forcibly upon his Head with an Iron Mace, that he ca≈øt him dead to the ground; which ≈øo inraged the Soldian Bellagris, that with all his fury he charged the Gyant, not leaving him till he had made him ≈øhorter by the Head: And ≈øoon after fell the King of Cambia and his two Brethren, with the Gyant Pi≈øi≈øtrato, the later of which had a little before ≈ølain German of Orleans.

And now Albayzer fighting with Florian, and carried wounded to his Tent, the Pagans began again to ≈øhrink together, which King Edoard perceiving, drew all the Forces out of the City, and charged upon the Right Wing ≈øo furiou≈øly, that broken and di≈øordered the Turks and Per≈øians (of which it was compo≈øed) fled, and in flying over-bore a Battailian of their own foot, which advantage the Chri≈øtians laying hold on, followed ≈øo fiercely, that all the Plaines were ≈øtrewed with the dead bodies, and the Ditches and Ponds coloured with blood, Albayzer him≈øelf hardly e≈øcaping in a Chariot to his
Ships; ≈øo that the Camp being quite abandoned, the Chri≈øtians entered, and found infinite Riches, as Gold, precious Stones, Embroideries, rich Carpets, bars of Silver, and Embroidered En≈øigns, together with an Emperial Crown, with which Albayzer intended to have Crowned him≈øelf Emperor of Con≈øtantinople. When having pur≈øued the Enemy out of the Emperor's Territories with incredible ≈ølaughter, the Princes entered the City in Triumph, being met by the Emperor, King Tarnaes, (who had the charge of the City committed to him) and divers others, they were conducted to the Pallace, and the Souldiers highly rewarded; yet ≈øome grief remained for the lo≈øs of ≈øo many Valiant and Renowned Knights; for this War co≈øt the Chri≈øtians no le≈øs than the Lives of Twenty Thou≈øand men of all degrees, and the Infidels thrice the number. But that which augmented the ≈øorrow, was the death of the Emperor Palmerin, who through Age and Infirmity gave up the Gho≈øt; his la≈øt words being, That now he was willing to lay a≈øide the ponderous waight of Empire, ble≈ø≈øing God that he had lived to ≈øee his Enemies overthrown, and his Empire left in quiet; whereof he commended to his ≈øon Primalion, de≈øiring his Nobles, from that time, to acknowledge him their Emperor; which they prom≈ø≈øed to do with the ≈øame reverence and ≈øervice that they had ever re≈øpected and ≈øerved him with.

div.head: CHAP. LXVIII.

argument.p: How Primalion was Crowned Emperor of Greece: And of the Coun≈øel taken for the Inva≈øion of Babylon.

div.p: THE Emperor Palmerin being dead, and his Death greatly lamented, his body was intered in a ≈øtately Sepulchre of Marble Ivory, and Gold, erected in the great Cathedral of Con≈øtantinople, after the ≈øolemnizing who≈øe Funeral, the Princes and States of the Empire a≈ø≈øembled to place the Emperial Crown upon the Head of Prince Primalion, Elde≈øt Son to the Emperor: In order to which great Pomp was provided, and he Crowned in the following manner:

In the Morning, ten days after the Interment, all the Princes in Cloth of Gold and Rich Embroidery of Pearl and precious Stones, came to Prince Primalions Chamber and ≈øaluted him Emperor, the Great Ma≈øter of the Hou≈øhold; laying before him upon a Velvet Cu≈øhion embroidered, Gold and Diamonds, the Emperial Crown, Scepter, and Regal Globe; while≈øt his High Chancellor held the other Ornaments of Maje≈øty; on which Primalion laying his Right hand, in token of having taken po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion thereof, the Trumpets and loud In≈øtruments of Mu≈øick ≈øounded, which the people that were crouding round the Pallace hearing, with vniver≈øal ≈øhouts proclaimed the Choice; Then being again ≈øaluted Emperor, he was lead by King Edoard and King E≈øterlant, to the Great Cathedrall, in this order: Before him went a Hor≈øe in rich Traping of Gold; then followed a Herauld, proclaiming his Titles, and bearing the Armes of the Empire; after them followed the Servants of the Hou≈øhold, leading many Hor≈øes in Silver Trapings, ≈øounding all manner of loud Mu≈øick; next went the Nobles, two and two, according to their degree; then ≈øix En≈øigns, bearing the Armes of the ≈øix Provinces his
Father and him≈øelf had anexed to the Empire: After them four E≈øquires, one bearing his Sword, the other his Shield, the third his Helmet, and the fourth his Armour: Then went the Great Ma≈øter of his Hou≈øhold, and High Chancellor; the fir≈øt bearing the Emperial Crown, Scepter, and Globe, and the later a Coronet done of Gold for the Empre≈øs: After them followed the Emperor, lead by the afore≈øaid Kings, and was followed by the Empre≈øs and her Ladies in a Chariot covered with Cloth of Gold, and ≈øhe ≈øucceeded by a number of other Chariots, covered with Gold and Silver interwoven. And in this order pa≈ø≈øed they through a Lane of Armed Knights to the Cathedrall, where they were received by the Arch-Bi≈øhop, and all the Clergy of the City, ≈øinging Anthems, and conducted to the High Altar, where a Chair of State being ≈øet, the Emperor and Empre≈øs placed them≈øelves, and were by the Bi≈øhop Crowned after the manner and cu≈øtom of the Empire; when having received the benediction of the Church, they returned in the ≈øame order, and were all the way ≈øaluted with the Ioyfull Acclamations of the People; when as all manner of Pa≈øtimes were ordained, together, with fea≈øting in abundance, for all that would come; with many new and pretty devices, ordained to divert the Ladyes, and make them forget the ≈øorrow they conceived for the lo≈øs of their friends, but the impre≈ø≈øion in mo≈øt of their minds was too deep to be ≈øo ≈øoon obliterated. Twenty days la≈øted this fea≈øting, and pa≈øtime, at the end of which a Grand Council was called, to ≈øettle the Affairs of the Empire: When after a long debate, it was re≈øolved, That ≈øince Albayzer had ≈øo treacherou≈øly dealt, as to invade the City of Con≈øtantinople without cau≈øe, ingratefully requiting ≈øo the kind entertainment he and his Prince≈øs Targiana had received at the hands of the Emperor Palmerin, the wary ≈øhould be carryed into his Country, and the Siege layed to his City of Babylon.

This re≈øolution greatly plea≈øed the Princes, and Knights at Armes, who ≈øwore they would (as much as in them lay) a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Emperor in the undertaking; whereupon great preparation
were made again≈øt the Spring, both of Shiping, Arms, and Provi≈øion; yet did they what they could to hide the De≈øign from the Ladyes, le≈øt it ≈øhould admini≈øter new cau≈øe of Grief, ≈øo that every Prince ≈øent ≈øecretly into his Country to leavy Forces, to be ready at the time appointed.

div.head: CHAP. LXIX.

argument.p: Of an Adventure that happened in the Court: And how the late married Ladyes were delivered of divers fair Sons and Daughters.

div.p:
THE Face of Ioy being a little re≈øtor'd at Court, and the lo≈øs of Friends by little and little pa≈ø≈øing out of Memory, it ≈øo fell out: That (while≈øt the De≈øports la≈øted) there came to the Court a Damzel, attended on by a Dwarf, bringing with her a Rich Mantle, fringed with Gold, lined with Ermins, and embroidered over with Pearles, Diamonds, Saphyres, Iacinch, Ia≈øper, Cry≈øolites, and all the Glory of the Indies, de≈øiring it might be viewed by all the Ladyes of the Court, and that they would give their opinion of it, which they did, acknowledging it to be the faire≈øt that they had ever ≈øeen; when viewing it well, they ≈øaw divers Characters upon it, of which they earne≈øtly de≈øired to know the meaning; whereto the Damzel replyed: That It was wrought by the Hands of the Enchantre≈øs Mirza, for the Beautifull young Prince≈øs Luceana, Daughter to the King of Aegypt, who≈øe Father left her in Cu≈øtody with my Lady Mirza, giving it her in charge, That ≈øhe ≈øhould be≈øtow her upon the Wi≈øe≈øt and mo≈øt Valiant Prince of her time; the Prince≈øs not exceeding Ten Moneths old at pre≈øent: Wherefore my Lady contrived by her Art the≈øe Characters, a≈ø≈øuring her ≈øelf, that none but ≈øuch a one
as is worthy the Prince≈øs (with whom likewi≈øe, when ≈øhe comes of Age, he is to have the Kingdom of Aegypt,) can interpret them; wherefore ≈øhe directed me to this Court, knowing there are many beautiful Ladyes lately contracted, as hoping from the effects of ≈øuch Nuptials may ≈øpring a Prince, who may effect the de≈øire of my Lady. Then know further, that each of you having ≈øeen it, who≈øoever it is that Dreams the en≈øuing Night, ≈øo as to de≈øcribe the Beauty of the young Prince≈øs, and the place wherein ≈øhe is kept, that Lady ≈øhall bring forth a Son, who is to enjoy the Happine≈øs de≈øigned, and prove one of the wi≈øe≈øt and valiante≈øt Knights in the World, being likewi≈øe able to read and expound the≈øe Mi≈øtick Characters.

This greatly incouraged the Ladyes, every one being de≈øirous to have the happie≈øt Off-≈øpring: When after various delights, night covering the Earth with darkne≈øs, each retired to their Lodgings big with expectation, hoping next morning to reveal Wonders: Nor was the night altogether unplea≈øant, for they dreamed of various matters: But among≈øt the re≈øt, the Prince≈øs Polinarda being over-power'd with ≈ølumber, and ≈øweet ≈øleep hanging on her eye-lids, (well plea≈øed to favour ≈øo rare a Beauty) fancied her ≈øelf to be delivered of a fair Son, when together with him ≈øhe was carried through the Ayr, in a Whirlwind, over Citys, Forre≈øts, Sea, and Rivers, till at la≈øt coming to a high Mount, who≈øe top ≈øeemed to tran≈øcend the Clouds, ≈øhe was ≈øet down; when gazing round, ≈øhe beheld a ≈øpacious Ca≈øtle, Watered round, and graced with plea≈øant Groves, Gardens, Orchards, and all that could any way appear plea≈øant and delightful to the eye, every Shrub and every Flower yielding odours, and the Fountains every where ≈øpouting purling ≈øtreams of Water into the Ayr: But while≈øt ≈øhe was admiring every part, a grave Matron in a Mantle of Crim≈øon Sattine, ≈øpangled with Ro≈øes and Lillies of Gold, come out of the fair Fabrick, having in her hand a Silver Wan ‚Ä¢ , and after ≈øalutation, conveyed into it; where ≈øhe no ≈øooner entered, but ≈øhe beheld a ≈øtately Palace, adorned with
Cedar, Gold, and precious Stones, which glittered like Lamps; and all round were hung Pictures of Knights and Ladyes, renowned in Arms and Beauty; where (among≈øt the re≈øt) ≈øhe fancied ≈øhe beheld her Lords and her own, with divers others, re≈øembling the Knights and Ladyes of the Emperors Court; when pa≈ø≈øing on through a ≈øpacious Gallery, of va≈øt length, ≈øupported with Alaba≈øter Pillars, at the end thereof two folding Doors of Cedar, hinged with Gold, and wrought with divers works of Imagery; interpo≈øing, the ≈øage Matron took from her ≈øide a Key of Gold, and turning in the Intrecacys of the Lock, open they ≈ølew, with a re≈øounding Harmony, as if a Symphony of plea≈øant Mu≈øick had wound the Ayr, and ≈øtraight di≈øcovered a Room furni≈øhed out mo≈øt gloriou≈øly, all o're perfumed with Lamps that con≈øumed Spicie Oyls; when at the upper end ≈øhe beheld a Cradle, glittering with Gold and Gems, and by it three beautious Damzels, ≈øinging Songs of Love and brave Exploits, ever and anon looking into the Cradle, as if ≈øome mighty Charge was there; and ≈øo it proved: For being de≈øirous to ≈øatisfie her Curio≈øity therein, lead by fancy, ≈øhe approaching, ≈øaw (or ≈øuppo≈øed ≈øhe ≈øaw) the Royal Infant, of whom the Damzel had made her relation, ≈ømiling in innocent Beauty, and adorned with all the perfections of Nature, ≈øympathi≈øing with her Son, that ≈øhe fancied ≈øhe held in her Armes, which greatly joyed her; and while≈øt ≈øhe remained as it were in an exta≈øie, ≈øhe heard a voice like the ≈øound of a Trumpet, ≈øaying, Behold the Wonder of Chivalry, and Mirrour of Beauty: happy and glorious will be the Court, wherein the≈øe flouri≈øh; when looking about her to ≈øee from whom the ≈øound came, ≈øuddenly a Dragon de≈øcending from the Roof, ≈ønatched her Son out of her Armes; whereat ≈øhe ≈øhreiking, awoke, and all the illu≈øion vani≈øhed; yet greatly was ≈øhe concerned at what her imagination had impre≈ø≈øed on her memory.

In the morning the Ladyes ri≈øing, and the Damzel yet waiting for the relation of their Dreams, great was the expectation of the Court: Many related what their fancies had
contracted; but ≈øome again (blu≈øhing) refu≈øed to tell, by rea≈øon of ≈øome ob≈øcenety, or wanton thoughts, that the foregoing actions of Love and dalliance had cau≈øed them (≈øleeping) to fancy over again; others dreamed of the many hazards and dangers their Lords had undergone for their ≈øakes; and ≈øuch Ladyes as were deprived of their happine≈øs, imagined they embraced for them their empty ≈øhade, and ≈øaw their Gho≈øt tempting them to follow to the ble≈ø≈øed Elizium ≈øhades: But when all had related, except the fair Polinarda, and none approved, ≈øhe in the manner afore≈øaid delivered the roveing of her fancy; at which the Damzel greatly rejoycing, fell at her Feet, ≈øaying, She alone ≈øhould produce a Prince worthy her Mi≈øtri≈ø≈øes Love, who ≈øhould be renowned above Mankind, and do ≈øuch Wonders, as had not in any foregoing Age been known; but that ≈øhe would lo≈øe him in his Infant≈øie, but find him again when ≈øhe had greate≈øt need of his aid.

This having ≈øaid, ≈øhe pre≈øented the Mantle for his u≈øe, when born, al≈øo divers Iewels of value; and after leave taken, retired without the Court, where ≈øuddenly ≈øhe was caught up in a pitchy Cloud, and conveyed out of their ≈øight.

This ≈øtrange Adventure being known, cau≈øed various di≈øcour≈øes; but above all, the thoughts of lo≈øing the young Prince (when born) greatly troubled Prince Palmerin, and his fair Prince≈øs Polinarda, yet they comforted them≈øelves as well as might be, in hopes that he would be carefully di≈øpo≈øed of and provided for. Now while≈øt ≈øuch thoughts la≈øted, Nature having accompli≈øhed her work, the fair Prince≈øs fell in labour, and after ≈øome ≈øtrugling pangs, (the effects of the forbidden Fruit ta≈øted in Eden) ≈øhe was delivered of a fair Son, who was chri≈øtened by the Arch-Bi≈øhop, and named Palmerin, after the name of his Father and Great Grandfather: The ≈øame day the fair Prince≈øs Miragarda brought forth to Prince Florendos a Son likewi≈øe, who was at the Fount named Primalion, de≈øtined to ≈øucceed him in the Empire, as will hereafter appear: And the next day Leonarda was delivered of a Son, who was called Florian, after the name of his Father:
To Dragolant Prince of Navar the fair Arnalte brought forth a beautiful Daughter, and named her Athenia: Nor was the beautiful Sidalla behind, to ble≈øs Prince Berolde with a Son, who was afterward known by the name of Burnami≈ø≈øa the renowned King of Spain: Arme≈øia brought forth to her Lord Pompides, a beautiful Son and Daughter, the former of which was named according to his Father, and the latter known by the name of The Fair Ca≈øtoria: Arleucea likewi≈øe overjoyed Dramu≈øiand with a Son, who was chri≈øtened by the ≈øame name. Nor were any of the Nuptial effects in vain, for the≈øe Heroick Knights were as dexterious and active in the ≈øoft Wars of Venus, as in the dreadful Field of Mars, and could as well and ≈øurely aim the one Launce as the other.

The Court being thus repleni≈øhed with young Princes and Prince≈ø≈øes, con≈øiderably abated the ≈øorrow, conceived for the lo≈øs in the late War, all of which were put into the hands of the mo≈øt skilful Governe≈ø≈øes, during their tender years, and Tutors appointed, to educate them in accompli≈øhments, when their years were capable to retain it; ≈øo that now Fea≈øting and Mi ‚Ä¢ th abounded in every place, the better to obliterate the di≈ømal effects of the War: But the Prince≈øs Polinarda deating on her Son, who≈øe promi≈øing Beautys and ≈ømiling Innocence greatly wrought upon her fancy, and remembring the ≈øaying of the Virgin, ≈øhe ordained two Knights and four Damzels to guard and attend him night and day, thinking by that means to prevent his being conveyed from the Palace, but all proved in vain, for the Enchantre≈øs out-witted them, as will hereafter appear.

div.head: CHAP. LXX.

argument.p: The Expedition again≈øt Babylon; and what happened before the Emperor Primalion and the Princes Layed Siege to it.

div.p: SPRING approaching, and a great concour≈øe of armed men arriving daily at Con≈øtantinople, to attend the plea≈øure of their Lords, the Ladyes began to ≈øu≈øpect what was intended, and with tears intermixed with ≈øighs, ki≈ø≈øes, and earne≈øt intreaties, ≈øo dealt many of them with their Beloveds, that they got the ≈øecret from them, which again admini≈øter'd new cau≈øe of grief; yet many rea≈øons being given for the nece≈ø≈øity of the War, as That the Soldian was again leavying huge Forces, and to ≈øuffer him again to lay Siege to the Emperial City, would eclip≈øe their Glory, and the Glory of the Empire; That they ≈øhould, by carrying the War (≈øo much ≈øought by him) to the Walls of his Babylon, ≈øave their own Country from ≈øpoile and de≈øolation, and live upon the ≈øpoil of their Enemies, being the better enabled thereby to maintain a vigorous Encounter, and revenge the many injuries and Di≈øgraces that Albayzer and the Great Turk, together with the Soldian of Per≈øia, had put upon the Emperor Palmerin, and by dint of Sword convince them of their treachery and ba≈øe ingratitude.

The≈øe and many the like pregnant Rea≈øons ≈øo wrought upon the Ladyes, that upon their Lords promi≈øing to make as ≈øpeedy a return as victory, would permit they were ≈øomewhat pacified, being as de≈øirous of revenge as them≈øelves, e≈øpecially tho≈øe that were left as Widow-Turtles, to mourn for the Lo≈øs of their Dead. And now the Army being mu≈øtered of all Nations, there were found One Hundred Thou≈øand fighting men, the valiante≈øt, and mo≈øt hardy, Europe could boa≈øt of; who imbarquing on Three Hundred ≈øail of Ships, with the ≈øounds of all manner of Warlike In≈øtruments, pa≈ø≈øed the Hele≈øpont,
to the A≈øian Coa≈øt, where Landing, they covered the affrighted ≈øhores, on which for three days they encamped, to put them≈øelves in order to march, for that fre≈øh news arrived that Albayzer and the Great Turk were on their marth, with what Forces they could rai≈øe, not doubting to ≈øurprize the City of Con≈øtantinople.

During the Armys ≈øtay, the Princes took leave of their Ladies, who with tears in their eyes intermixing ≈øighs and ≈øoft ki≈ø≈øes, (as loath to leave them, ≈øome of whom they mu≈øt never more behold) followed them to the ≈øhore, and then returned to their re≈øpective Chambers, to weep out the grief that overwhelmed their tender ≈øouls, and pray for the ≈øafety of their Lords. ‚Ä¢ f this Army King Edoard was appointed General, as before, and Prince Palmerin appointed his great Leiutenant; Pompides lead Six Thou≈øand Hor≈øe; as the forlorn Florian had the Command of Ten Thou≈øand Foot, Dramu≈øiand Charge of the Right Wing, con≈øi≈øting of Grecians, Germans, French, and Engli≈øh; Florendos being bravely mounted, was joyned in Commi≈ø≈øion with Prince Berolde, to command the Left Wing; and the re≈øt were divided into four Battailians; one lead by King Polendos; another by Palmerin, who kept his ≈øtation to the Rear-ward; a third by the Soldian Bellagris; and the fourth by Prince Floriman; and in this order they marched through the Emperors A≈øian Terretories, till they came into the Countries of the Great Turk, who then po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed all the le≈ø≈øer A≈øia, called now Aenatolia, and all that part of A≈øia the greater, that borders upon Per≈øia, even to the Walls of Tauris, on the one hand, and Babylon the other, where they took divers Towns, and enriched them≈øelves with great booty, cau≈øing the fearful people to fly into the Mountains with what ≈øub≈øtance they could carry, although the Princes had given ≈øtrict order, that no Souldier (upon pain of death) ≈øhould kill Man, Woman, or Child, that re≈øi≈øted not, but might take ≈øuch Goods as fell to their ≈øhare.

The news of the Chri≈øtian Armys approach having by this time reached the ear of Albayzer, and alarumed all his Provinces,
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
„Äà1 page duplicate„Äâ
he in as much ha≈øte as might be increa≈øed his Forces, compelling by force his unwilling Subjects to the War, who for the many Cruelties his Father had u≈øed towards them, greatly hated the Son: Yet ≈øuch and the like means, together with the ≈øupplys ≈øent him from Judea, Pala≈øtine, Aegypt, and Armenia, he forced a huge Camp of Babylonians, Turks, Jews, Sarazens, Aegyptians, Armenians, and the like; with which (well Mar≈øhalled, and in good order) he marched, hoping to meet the Great Turk, his Father-in-Law, who was marching at the head of his Forces to his aid, as being greatly de≈øirous to revenge the affront put on him by the Emperor Palmerin, for refu≈øing to ≈øend Prince Florian of the Forre≈øt: But e're the Turk could arrive, he was encounter'd by a detached power under the Command of the Soldian Bellagris and Prince Florian, who laying an Ambu≈øh for him, as he was about to pa≈øs a huge Forre≈øt, bur≈øt out with ≈øuch fury, that over-≈øetting his Battail, the affrighted Turks lo≈øt all their courage; ≈øo that after a bloody fight, wherein the Great Turk him≈øelf, and mo≈øt of his Nobles were ≈ølain, they in great confu≈øion betook them≈øelves to flight, and were followed with dreadful execution, till Night ≈øheltered them from the fury of their pur≈øuers; at what time ≈øome got into fenced Cities, others to Albayzer's Camp, filling all with fear and con≈øternation at the news of that dreadful di≈øa≈øter.

The≈øe great Captains having made ≈øo ≈øucce≈øsful a beginning, with the lo≈øs of a few of their own men, returned with huge ≈øpoiles to their General, who highly welcomed them, and cau≈øed publick thanks to be given to Almighty God, for the Victory he had been plea≈øed to grant them, over the Enemies of his name: And ≈øo having refre≈øhed them≈øelves, they ≈øet forward to meet Albayzer, whom they under≈øtood, by ≈øome ≈øcouts of his, to be on his March towards them: Nor were they mi≈øinformed, for the next morning they could from the tops of the Hills di≈øcern the fore-runners of his Army: Whereupon the General called a Council of the Princes and great Captains, to re≈øolve what was to be done, whether they ≈øhould pa≈øs the hills
to meet the forward Enemy, or imbattail them≈øelves there, to expect him in the Plain? The rea≈øon for the former were, That the forwardne≈øs of the Chri≈øtian Army, in attempting to meet them, would in ≈øome ≈øort di≈øcourage the Enemy, and give new vigor to the Souldiers on their part: But it being urged on the contrary, That they were in a ≈øtrange Country, with which they were altogether unacquainted, the Enemy might lay ambu≈øhments to intrap them, or might hide his power in divers Forre≈øts, and thereby by perpetually renewing his Battail, might greatly di≈øcourage the Souldiers, who would be apt to ≈øuppo≈øe, that (like Hydra's heads) the more they cut off, the more they increa≈øed: Whereupon it was agreed, that the Battail ≈øhould be fought on that Plain, if the Enemy dur≈øt attempt it; and if he delayed, then ≈øhould they March on towards the City of Babylon. VVhereupon all that night they kept great Fires, and a ≈øtrict watch, to prevent any ≈øurprize that might happen to their prejudice.

div.head: CHAP. LXXI.

argument.p: Of the great Battel fought in A≈øia, between the Chri≈øtians and Infidels; And of the great Victory obtained by the former.

div.p:
THe afore≈øaid re≈øolutions being taken by the Princes, Albayzer early the next morning (as they wi≈øhed) drew up his Army on the top of the Hills, and there incamping, ≈øent down a Herauld to defie the Chri≈øtians, and to denounce to them all them≈øelves attendant on VVar, ≈øwearing by Mahomet, that not one of them ≈øhould remain alive; but had an≈øwer returned him by King Edoard, in the name of the re≈øt, That the Princes were come ≈øo far to ≈øeek him, that
≈øo they might fini≈øh that revenge his flight would not permit them to do under the walls of Con≈øtantinople; and that if he refu≈øed or ≈øhunned the Battail, they would be≈øiege him even in his Capital City of Babylon.

Albayzer having received the an≈øwer afore≈øaid, groaned with anger, and thorowly fired in hopes of revenging the indignity put upon him, cau≈øed his Army to be ≈øet in array, dividing it into ≈øix Divi≈øions: The fir≈øt con≈øi≈øting of Twenty Thou≈øand Hor≈øe, him≈øelf lead; the ≈øecond of Thirty Thou≈øand Footmen, he gave to the King of Cambia; the third con≈øi≈øting of Ten Thou≈øand Hor≈øe, that made the Left Wing, he gave to Tomandarus his Cozen, at that time Prince of Pala≈øtine; the fourth con≈øi≈øting of Fifteen Thou≈øand Hor≈øe, he committed to the Charge of Gondrominus, Son to the Soldian of Per≈øia, ≈ølain in the Battail before Con≈øtantinople, and the≈øe he ordained for the Right Wing; the la≈øt Battail he committed to Salmanzer Son to the Great Turk, and Brother to the fair Targiana, con≈øi≈øting of Twenty Thou≈øand Foot, which he ordered for a Re≈øerve, ≈øetting Framu≈øtant the Gyant as Guardian to his Per≈øon, by rea≈øon but young, and unexperienc'd in Feats of Armes.

All things being in a readine≈øs, Albayzer commanded the two Wings to move, as al≈øo the gro≈øs Body of his Foot, and that the re≈øt ≈øhould keep their ≈øtation, till further order. The Chri≈øtians beholding them de≈øcend the Hills in great ha≈øte, ≈øtood from in their order, to prevent being over-born; when each Captain encouraging his men, to incite them to noble and brave Exploits, King Edoard commanded the Charge to be ≈øounded; whereupon the Armies joyntly moved, and King Pompides with his Six Thou≈øand Hor≈øe charged the Enemies Left Wing with great bravery, over-bearing all that ≈øtood before him, and with his Spear wounded the Prince of Pala≈øtine, to who≈øe re≈øcue on all ≈øides his Men came in, and pre≈ø≈øed ≈øo furiou≈øly, that Pompides (weary with killing) was obliged to retire within the Ranks of his Men, to recover breath.

By this time the gro≈øs of the Armies joyned with ≈øuch fury, as made the Earth beneath them tremble, and the Hills eccho with the ≈øhouts of the vanqui≈øhers, and crys of the vanqui≈øhed: There might you at once behold Men fighting like Lyons, and others flying like timerous Deer; when to give the more encouragement to his men, Albayzer left the command of his Squadron to Orcadamus his Lieutenant, and accompanied with Morcador, Arock, & Gramandor, three terrible Gyants, he went from place to place to give orders, till at length he came to the Right Wing, where he found Prince Palmerin fighting at the head of Six Thou≈øand cho≈øen men, making piteous ≈ølaughter, which ≈øo moved him, that he interpo≈øed between the Prince and ≈øuch as were in confu≈øion, that they ‚Ä¢ ight have the better leave to put them≈øelves in a po≈øture, and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t-face their fear; of which the Prince was very glad, as de≈øirous of nothing more, than to be revenged on him, that had been the cau≈øe of the death of ≈øo many of his friends; when without any words a ≈øharp Combat en≈øued, ≈øo that wounds were given and received in a plentious manner, till their Armour was di≈øcoloured with their blood; their men fighting the mean while as eagerly on either ≈øide them, ≈øo that the ≈ølain lay ≈øcattered round them; which Prince Palmerin perceiving, and w ‚Ä¢ ll noting the havock the Gyants made of his men, redoubled his force ≈øo furiou≈øly, that with a full blow on Albayzer's Cre ‚Ä¢ , he ≈øo dented his Helm into his Head, that (≈øtunned thereby) he ≈øtagger'd ≈øix paces backward, and fell to the ground; but e ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e the Prince (who laboured to take him Pri≈øoner) could effect his de≈øire, the Gyants came to his re≈øcue, two of them carrying him off, while≈øt the third (viz. Gramandor) combated with the Prince, but had not ≈øo good luck as his Ma≈øter: For after a terrible fight, he falling through wounds and lo≈øs of blood, had his head ≈ømitten off in ≈øpight of the endeavours that were u≈øed to re≈øcue him.

The di≈øa≈øter of Albayzer greatly di≈øheartened his Souldiers, in≈øomuch, that they began to ≈øhrink together; of which he having notice, wounded as he was, would again have taken
the Field, but his great Favourites that were about him, would not permit it; yet immediately he ≈øent orders, for the Re≈øerves to de≈øcend, and if po≈ø≈øible, by wheeling about, charge the Chri≈øtians in the Rear; which ≈øtratagem being perceived by Florian, he drew of Ten Thou≈øand men, and went ‚Ä¢ o meet them, giving them a furious charge, till breaking through the Ranks, he found Framu≈øtant and Salmanzer, again≈øt both whom he fought with ≈øuch fury, that in the end he ≈ølew the Gyant, and carried off the other Pri≈øoner, though his ‚Ä¢ an laboured at the expence of many of their lives to prevent it. And now come on Berolde and Dramu≈øiand, making fatal havock; while≈øt Prince Florendos with a detached party brake through the advanced Squadrons of Hor≈øe, and entering the Ranks of the F ‚Ä¢ t u≈øhent, put them into confu≈øion, opening a pa≈ø≈øage to charge them on every ≈øide; which they perceiving, and that the Right Wing was almo≈øt all cut in pieces‚ñ™ gave ground amain, of which the Chri≈øtian Princes taking the advantage, advanced with Ten Thou≈øand fre≈øh men and put all it confu≈øion; Prince Floriman like Lightening breaking through the thicke≈øt Squadrons, but being unfortunately wounded between the joynts of his Harne≈øs with a Per≈øian Arrow impoi≈øoned, he ≈øoon after (to the grief of all the Princes) ‚Ä¢ yed in Babylon.

The Infidels now in rout, ≈ølaughter raged ≈øo dreadfully, that all the Plains were crim≈øoned afre≈øh with the blood of the ≈ølain; Albayzer (weak as he was, and in a mad mood) in vain endeavouring to rally his men; when finding he mu≈øt yield to nece≈ø≈øity, he retreated in the be≈øt order he could with his broken Troops, being pur≈øued till the Chri≈øtians (tired, and night coming on) were by the order of their General re≈øtrained, lea≈øt the Enemy taking the advantage of their ≈øtrugling, ≈øhould turn Head, and again di≈øpute the Victory.

In this Battail the Soldian lo≈øt Thirty Thou≈øand of his be≈øt men, among≈øt which were many of his Chief Commanders, and Twenty Thou≈øand the night following de≈øerted him, and privately retired to their re≈øpective Countries, filling
all places with fear and amazement, upon rumouring the approach of the Chri≈øtian Army: Which Albayzer well noting, and finding him≈øelf far too weak to hazard a ≈øecond Battail, in great perplexity returned to Babylon, to encourage the Citizens by his pre≈øence to defend it till new ≈øupplys ≈øhould come from his Alys, if the Princes ≈øhould approach; as al≈øo to have the company of his fair Sultane≈øs Targiana, who≈øe beautious eyes during his ab≈øence were never dry from tears. But ≈øcarcely had he put things in a po≈øture of defence, e're he had notice, That the Chri≈øtians approached, having all the Towns in their way put into their hands.

div.head: CHAP. LXXII.

argument.p: How the Army of Chri≈øtians be≈øieged Babylon, and took it by ≈øtorm; And what happened during the Siege.

div.p:
ALbayzer from the Watch-Tower (weak as he was) taking a view of the Chri≈øtian Army, and in what order they marched, re≈øolved to ≈øally with the chief of his ≈øtrength, for two rea≈øons, the one to amate the Chri≈øtians, lea≈øt they ≈øhould conclude him utterly vanqui≈øhed; and the other to keep up his credit with the Ladyes and men of War, to whom at his ≈øetting out he had promi≈øed ≈øuch great things: Whereupon with Forty Thou≈øand well appointed men he Marched out at Four Gates; when placing the Per≈øian and Median Archers in the Front, he cau≈øed the Charge to be ≈øounded, and with a dreadful ≈øhout charged the Avaunt-Guard, but they (being ≈øeconded by Prince Florendos) fought ≈øo manfully, that many on both ≈øides were ≈ølain; which horrible conflict made the Ladies (who from the Wall beheld it) fill the Ayr with ≈øhrieks and crys. And now Prince Florian (de≈øirous to let his quondam Mi≈øtri≈øs the fair Targiana, know what he was able to do) layed on ≈øo
furiou≈øly, that being ≈øeconded by the Squadron and Battailian lead by his Brother and Dramu≈øiand, he cau≈øed the Enemy to retire to their main Battail, where ≈øtood the Standard of Albayzer, when killing the Standard-bearer, and divers that undertook to re≈øcue it, they threw it down, which ≈øo di≈øheartned the Pagans, who ≈øuppo≈øed their General was killed, that they began to retire under the City Walls, and had pre≈øently fled, had not Albayzer ≈øhewed him≈øelf, though fatal it proved: For being about to draw up his men, a Greecian ≈øhot his hor≈øe into the head, who falling on him, brui≈øed him, that of the brui≈øes, and through grief for the di≈øgrace he ≈øu≈øtained, he in three days after dyed, filling the City with Lamentations for his Death.

This ≈øecond misfortune of the General cau≈øed the re≈øt of the Pagan Captains to de≈øpair of ≈øucce≈øs; whereupon ≈øounding the Retreat, they retired in as good order as they could into the City; but being furiou≈øly pur≈øued, Palmerin, Florian, and Dramu≈øiand with Six Thou≈øand men, pre≈ø≈øed in with them before they could clo≈øe the Gates, or let down the Portculls, and fought bravely for the pa≈ø≈øage, in≈øomuch, that the ≈øtreets ran blood, the Citizens and Souldiers earne≈øtly labouring to de≈øtroy the Princes and their followers, having for that purpo≈øe by this time inclo≈øed them on every ≈øide; but their danger being known to the remaining part of the Army without the Walls, they in a great fury ≈øtormed the Bulwarks at Twenty ≈øeveral places; to defend which the Pagans running from every part, Dramu≈øiand with a ≈øtrong Bar of Iron forced the Gate, and let in the Squadron under the leading of the Prince Florendos, making good his ground; but as he advanced to his ≈øtation, (where the Princes fighting, drove whole ≈øtreets before them) a huge ≈øtone was ca≈øt from a Turret, which falling upon his Helm, bur≈øt it in ≈øunder, and ca≈øt him dead upon the place, ≈øo that he (who was never but once vanqui≈øhed in fight) dyed, by the cowardly hand of ≈øome ba≈øe Artifice.
The Death of Dramu≈øiand known, the Princes gave order to fire the City, which was done in divers places.

During which con≈øternation, King Edoard, the Soldian Bellagris; and divers other great Commanders, had ≈øeized on the Towers and Bulwarks, and planted their En≈øigns thereon: Yet the defendants fought in every corner, hurling Stones, Tyles, melted Lead, Pitch, Tar, and Rozen on the a≈ø≈øailent, in≈øomuch that many brave Captains were killed and wounded; King Edoard him≈øelf having received a wound in the Arm by an Arrow from a Loop-hole, and Prince Florendos grievou≈øly hurt by the fall of ≈øcalding Sulpher, which almo≈øt roa≈øted him in his Armour: But in the end the ≈øtreets being paved with the ≈ølain, and Albayzer not pre≈øent, by rea≈øon of the great grief he ≈øu≈øtained to animate them, they threw down their weapons, and begged quarter; yet ≈øuch was the fury of the Souldiers, that notwith≈øtanding the Generals expre≈øs order to the contrary, that they killed a great number of them: But in the end, the ≈ølaughter being ≈øtayed, the General drew up before the Palace, (which yet held out) and ≈øummoned it, but was an≈øwered by a ≈øhowre of Arrows and Stones from the Walls, Loop-holes, and Towers, which greatly inraged the Souldier, ≈øo that having prepared combu≈øtable matter, they fired it in divers places; whereupon (contrary to the mind of Albayzer, who lay grievou≈øly ill of his brui≈øes) a parley was ≈øounded; when as the Princes pittying the loud laments and di≈ømal ≈øhreiks of the Ladies, who were for their ≈øafety retired thither, drew off; whereupon giving their promi≈øe that no violence ≈øhould be offered, the Gates were opened to the Conquerors, and they as many as thought convenient entred: Of which Albayzer having notice, in a de≈øperate mood ≈ønatched a ≈øword from one of his attendance, and wounded him≈øelf ≈øo deep in the brea≈øt, that by rea≈øon of it, and through the angui≈øh of his brui≈øe, and the greater angui≈øh of his mind, he expired, which many of his friends ≈øeeing, fell upon their ≈øwords, accompanying him in death, whom they had ≈øo faithfully ≈øerved in their life-time, leaving the fair Targiana and her Ladies in tears; yet ≈øo compa≈ø≈øionate were the Chri≈øtian Princes, that they comforted them in the be≈øt wi≈øe, promi≈øing that no further
harm ≈øhall befall them; e≈øpecially Prince Florian, for the love he bare to Targiana.

The Princes having been thus far revenged, thought it ≈øufficient: And after having refre≈øhed them≈øelses, and ≈øettled the affairs of the City, in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of Targiana, and at her reque≈øt relea≈øing her Brother, in con≈øideration that a Camels load of Gold ≈øhould as Tribute be payed to the Emperor of Con≈øtantinople, they with ≈øuch ≈øpoiles as they had taken (after having honourably buried their friends) returned to Con≈øtantinople in Triumph.

div.head: CHAP. LXXIII.

argument.p: Of the Death of the Emperor Primalion, and Florendos his Son; And the Lo≈øs of young Prince Palmerin, Son to Prince Palmerin of England; And what el≈øe remarkably happened.

div.p:
THe Princes thinking them≈øelves ≈øufficiently revenged for the Injuries ≈øu≈øtained, and de≈øiring to keep their promi≈øes with their Ladies, in triumph returned the ≈øame way they came, and in a ≈øhort time arrived upon the ≈øhores of the Hele≈øpont, where they found the Royal Fleet ready to waft them over: When upon their approaching the City, they were met in great Triumph, and conducted to the Palace; where after they had Fea≈øted liberally, and di≈øcharged the Souldiers with large Rewards, they ordained a Turnament for ten days: But before it began, the Emperor Primalion falling ≈øick of a Feavor, cau≈øed by the inflamation of the wounds he had received, that were not throughly healed, he after three days ≈øickne≈øs dyed to the great grief of the Court; but ≈øo exce≈ø≈øively grieved his fair Empre≈øs Gridona, that refu≈øing to be comforted, ≈øhe fell at la≈øt into ≈øuch a melancholly, that ≈øhe ≈øoon after followed her Lord to the happy Elizium of bli≈øs, both
of them being buried in a ≈øtately Sepulchre, near the Emperor Palmerin their Father, who≈øe death Prince Florendos (who≈øe Right it was to ≈øucceed his Father in the Empire) took ≈øo much to heart, that leaving his young Son under the tutorage of Sage Aliart, he together with the fair Miragarda, who would not leave him for the plea≈øures of the Greecian Court, travelled to the Holy Land, and never returned more; ≈øo that young Primalion being grown up to Maturity, was Crowned Emperor, and for a long time peaceably enjoyed that Empire.

Affairs being ≈øetled as well as might be, the Princes were de≈øirous to depart to their re≈øpective Country: King Edoard and his fair Queen Flerida were for England, having per≈øwaded their Son the Renowned Palmerin to accompany them; As likewi≈øe did King Pompides and his Queen Armi≈øia. But Prince Florian having the Kingdom of Thrace, in right of his Wife the fair Leonarda, he took his Iourney thither, with a ≈øplendid Equipage; where upon his arrival he was received by all the Nobles, and ≈øolemnly Crowned KING, where for many years he Reigned gloriou≈øly.

King Edoard his fair Queen Flerida, Prince Palmerin and his Prince≈øs Polinarda, with their young Son, Pompides and Armi≈øia, being by this time put to Sea, a great Tempe≈øt aro≈øe and ≈øcattered the Fleet, con≈øi≈øting of twenty ≈øhips, and continued ≈øo terrible for the ≈øpace of three days, that neither Sun, Moon, nor Stars appeared, which greatly troubled the Ladies (now altogether Sea-≈øick, and out of order); but at the end of the time afore≈øaid, the Heavens (to their great comfort) cleared up, and they found them≈øelves ca≈øt upon an I≈øland, where ≈øtood Mountainous Cliffs, that ≈øeemed to reach the Clouds; when going on ≈øhore to refre≈øh them≈øelves, and pitched a Royal Pavillion, but had not long repo≈øed, e're the Heavens again blackned, and ≈øuch Thunders and Lightning happened, as if the di≈ø≈øolution of all things were at hand, which put them into a great con≈øternation: But whil≈øt they were wondering at many dreadful ≈øights in the Ayr, as fircy Drakes, Pillars of Fire, Metors, and Comets, that blazed horrible, a huge flame de≈øcended
and invironed the Pavillion, making it ≈øeem all on a flame, which cau≈øed the Ladies to fall into a Trance, and ≈øomewhat amazed the ≈øtout hearts of the Heroick Princes: but that which wrought more terrour, out of the flame i≈ø≈øued a dreadful Dragon, whom in vain they ≈øought to wound, and ≈øeizing in his paws the Cradle, wherein young Prince Palmerin lay, he ≈øpread his Wings, and bore it through the dreadful Gloom in ≈øpight of all re≈øi≈øtance. This unhappy accident greatly troubled all pre≈øent, and the Prince his Father would have gone in ≈øearch of him; but being per≈øwaded to the contrary, and remembring what had been foretold, as al≈øo the Prince≈øs Polinarda's Dream, de≈øi≈øted.

And now all being clear and calm, and mo≈øt of the ≈øhips that had been ≈øeparated, brought in by the wind, they ≈øet ≈øail, and arrived at England, being received with great Ioy: But ≈øoon after King Edoard dyed, his Renowned ≈øon Palmerin was Crowned in his ≈øtead, flouri≈øhing gloriou≈øly many years.
